PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and Senators in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the film ``The Last Temptation of Christ'' portrays Our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ in a blasphemous and offensive way and is calculated to outrage the feelings of Christians.

2. That the decision of the Film Censorship Board to allow the importation of the film and to classify the Film with an ``R'' classification, rather than banning it, shows that the Film Censorship Board has failed in its statutory duty.
3. That in failing to exercise his powers and ban the Film the Attorney General has, as with his failure to ban the Film Hail Mary in 1986, failed in his duty to the people of Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will express its lack of confidence in the Attorney-General and the Film Censorship Board and pass laws which will ensure that no more blasphemous or offensive films will be permitted to be imported and/or screened in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace Trust Fund Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
At present all Australians, including those who conscientiously object to war and the preparation of war, are required by law for a portion of their income tax to be spent on military use.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Peace Tax Trust Fund Bill 1989 which has been presented by Western Australian Independent Senator, Jo Vallentine. This Bill does not propose that anyone be permitted to withhold tax, but that the law should be changed to allow conscientious objectors to divert the military portion of their tax into more positive and socially useful programmes.

PETITION.TITLE: Parental Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned strongly object to the Legislation which is being recommended by Professor Duncan Chappel, Department of Criminology, that parental rights to discipline our children by spanking (if necessary), being taken from us.

If we are not allowed to discipline our children at home, in love and according to God's Word we fear that we will have a nation of completely rebellious children on our hands. God's Word says, ``Spare the rod and spoil the child'' and also that ``Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child, but the rod of correction will drive it far from him''. We would therefore appreciate your consideration of our rights as parents to correctly and lovingly discipline our own children, and feel that if this right is taken from us we would lose the respect of our children.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws attention to the Senate of their concern regarding proposed changes to the laws governing credit reporting as suggested in the Bill ``The Privacy Amendment Bill 1989''.
The proposed reforms will:
Restrict the legitimate use of credit checking by businesses who sell/supply goods and/or services to their customers on credit terms.

The proposals/reforms will prevent businesses from determining the solvency of their customers and will increase the financial risk of credit providers, leading to an increase in company liquidations and individual bankruptcies.

Additional costs to business from bad debts due to the lack of adequate credit checking information will result in increased prices/charges and will result in credit providers refusing credit facilities.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will call on the Government to refer these proposals restricting credit checking to a Senate Standing Committee for further consideration before proceeding with the matter.

PETITION.TITLE: States Grants Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

that the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act, 1988 includes legislation, Part III-Changes to Non-Government Schools and New Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
reconsider the application and implications of this legislation in the light of justice, equity and freedom of choice for parents and have the unfair sections (Section 8 (2), 8 (15) and 11) repealed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Jones (from three citizens) and McMullan (from 66 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's attack upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has cast grave doubts over the future viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide much-needed service to the community, including particularly those in rural areas;
The proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will further jeopardise the viability of pharmacists;
The latest decision to slash the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme payments to pharmacists by an average of $1.05 per script is simply unacceptable and will force the closure of many pharmacies.

Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure adequate remuneration levels for pharmacists, so that they may be able to provide a high quality health care service which is the right of every citizen of Australia.
As in duty bound, your petitioners, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Botanic Gardens, Education Unit: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's decision to abolish the Education Unit of the National Botanical Gardens is a betrayal of the Federal Government's professed commitment to conservation, protection and management of Australia's unique flora.

The Education Unit fulfilled an important role in increasing the knowledge, appreciation and enjoyment of Australia's plant heritage of visitors to the National Botanical Gardens, including many school children.

Therefore your petitioners request that the Senate require the Government to recognise the importance of the work carried out by the Education Unit and reverse its decision to withdraw funding for the Unit.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Circuses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament

The petitions of Citizens of Australia points out that the future employment of Australian Circus performers and employees is in jeopardy and request that future tours of foreign circuses be limited to specific areas and 5 (five) yearly intervals. The Federal Government notes the financial effect that foreign circuses will have on Australia's family circuses that have been part of out history for over 100 years. Circuses calls on the Government to investigate the legitimate claims of the circus industry in Australia and reviews the granting of visas to foreign circuses that will affect the viability of circuses'.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Maritime Safety Authority Headquarters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia being employees of the Department of Transport and Communications showeth that:
The Government's decision to base the, to be formed, Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) in the city of Newcastle is strongly opposed by employees of the Department.

The move to Newcastle is not based on any sound operational reason. It has been found that the reason for moving personnel from Melbourne, a maritime port, to Canberra in 1982 to be successful. Therefore there is no justification for a further move back to a Maritime port. Indeed the now Maritime Operations Division including the Sea Safety Centre, marine pollution, survey and marine navigation aid functions were moved to Canberra to be close to the Minister's office and those intra-departmental agencies with which they currently liaise. The operations of ships, including certification, is already handled by regional offices and not by Canberra personnel.

Intra-Departmental submissions recommended that the cheapest and most efficient option for basing the AMSA headquarters would be in Canberra. The move to Newcastle, estimated by the Government to be in the order of $5,000,000, but which is probably closer to $12,000,000, is to be funded from the present portfolio, resulting in a degradation in other projects such as roads, navigation aids and maritime safety.

Two hundred and five (205) personnel and their families will suffer an unwelcome upheaval. Spouse or partners career and employment will suffer; there will be a detrimental affect on children's education due to the differing standards of education in New South Wales as compared with the Australian Capital Territory; and the personal suffering, trauma and financial burden of moving from home, friends and environment will have a lasting effect on personnel and their families. Previous compulsory transfer has indicated that the government is not interested in redeploying personnel who, for personal or medical reasons, are unable to relocate.

The Government's decision to move to Newcastle is an attempt at political point scoring to shore up the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping's electorate which is suffering from Newcastle's failed frigate building bid.
We submit that the headquarters of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority should remain in canberra.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, notices of motion Nos 2, 3 and 4 standing in my name, for three sitting days hence, for the disallowance of: Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 267 and made under the Migration Act 1958; Quarantine (Animals) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 272 and made under the Quarantine Act 1908; and Interpretation Ordinance 1989, as contained in Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands Ordinance No. 3 and made under the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Act 1933. For the information of honourable senators and others, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief description of the scrutiny of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and its correspondence.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
MIGRATION REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1989 No. 267

The Committee's concerns with this instrument related to a discretion given to the Minister to exempt a class of persons determined by the Minister from the payment of a fee for a temporary entry visa.

The Committee always prefers that provisions for exemption from fees should be as objective and as precise as possible. In this case there were some categories where these criteria were met. The spouse or child of an applicant, for example, is exempt. The concerns of the Committee, however, related to this entirely open-ended power which has no criteria, either objective or subjective, to guide the Minister. In this case the power relates to a ``class'' of persons and is thus a classic legislative function, as it provides a mandatory rule for a group. The power is such that the Minister could in effect amend the Regulations themselves. In cases where an instrument of delegated legislation provides for determinations which are legislative in effect, the Committee believes that tabling and disallowance requirements are appropriate. If the power had been to exempt individuals from payment of the fee then the Committee would have been equally concerned. In such cases, however, the remedy should be review by the AAT of the merits of an adverse decision.

In this case the Minister advised that the defective provision was being repealed and replaced on 19 December 1989. These new provisions will include definitive lists of classes for the payment of visa fees and for exemptions, with no discretion to exempt. If this was not the case the Minister indicated that the Regulations would be amended to provide that the determinations are subject to tabling and disallowance.
The Committee thanks the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator the Honourable Robert Ray, for his co-operation.
22 November 1989
Senator the Honourable Robert Ray
Minister for Immigration, Local Government
and Ethnic Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Migration Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1989 No 267, considered by the Committee at its Meeting of 2 November 1989.

The Committee noted that new r.29BF(3) exempts refugees, applicants under a special humanitarian program, or the spouse or child of an applicant, from payment of the application fee for a temporary entry visa. The Committee raises no concerns relating to these objective categories.

Under new r.29BF(3) (d), however, the Minister may by determination in writing exempt a class of persons from payment of the fee. This power is open-ended, and is not limited in its exercise by any criteria, objective or otherwise. The power is in respect only of a ``Class'' and may therefore be categorised as essentially legislative in character, making as it does a rule for a common group of persons. The Committee believes that determinations of this type should be subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament. The power given to the Minister under r.29BF(3) (d) is a power to alter the operation of the Regulations themselves. The Committee carefully examines any power to exempt a person or a class of persons from payment of a charge or fee. In cases where the power relates to exempting individuals then a right of review of the merits of any decision to refuse exemption will often be appropriate. In cases like the present, where the power is so sweeping that it may be used to nullify virtually the entire operation of the Regulations, tabling and disallowance is appropriate.

The Committee would also appreciate your advice whether it is possible for the Minister's power under r.29BF(3) (d) to be delegated. The Committee believes that arguments in favour of tabling and disallowance are much stronger in cases where the power may be delegated to a person whose actions are not personally answerable to the Parliament.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
Senator Bob Collins
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Collins

I refer to your letter of 22 November 1989 in which you express your Committee's concern at the open-ended nature of the power in Regulation 29bf of the Migration Regulations which enables me to exempt a class of persons from payment of the temporary entry visa fee by determination in writing.

I have no objection to your Committee's suggestion that determinations of this type should be subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament. The regulation could be amended to specify that determinations are subject to tabling and disallowance. If Regulation 29bf were not to be repealed and replaced on 19 December 1989 with other regulations that do not contain this defect, then I would make the regulation subject to the tabling and disallowance requirement you suggest.

You also sought my advice as to whether it is possible for the power in question to be delegated. The short answer is that the power has not been delegated and will not be delegated before its repeal. The regulations to commence on 19 December 1989 will provide a complete list of classes for payment of visa fees and exemptions. There will be no ministerial power to exempt classes of persons from payment of the fee.
Yours sincerely
ROBERT RAY
QUARANTINE (ANIMALS) REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1989 No. 272

The Committee's concerns related to the removal of apparently mandatory forms from the Regulations where they are, of course, subject to the scrutiny of Parliament and to the possible sanction of disallowance. This instrument provides that the forms not only will no longer be subject to the supervision or even the knowledge of Parliament, but that they will merely be required to satisfy the Director of Quarantine, a public official. The forms will not even be required to be placed before the Minister, who is subject to personal questioning in the Parliament.
The explanatory Statement gave no explanation for removing the forms from Parliamentary Scrutiny, apart from stating that the changes were desirable.

The Committee examines closely any legislative instrument which may dilute the existing powers of Parliament. All delegated legislation exists only because of the express authorisation of an Act of Parliament and the Committee is vigilant in safeguarding the rights of Parliament to control this legislation in appropriate ways.

In this case the Minister explained that amendment of the forms by an administrative rather than legislative action was more expedient and less costly. The Committee does not regard such advice as conclusive in itself, as its principles safeguarding personal liberties and parliamentary proprieties take precedence over such considerations in the absence of other compelling reasons. It will, however, be taken into account by the Committee in its deliberations.

The Minister also advised that the type of information required by the forms was set out in the parent Quarantine Act 1908 and in the principal Regulations. Again this was not conclusive by itself but was considered by the Committee. The Committee examined the subject matter covered by the forms and considered that no outstanding issue of personal rights was involved.

Finally, the Minister assured the Committee that the changes would assist the public and improve the services offered. Taking all the above matters into account the Committee decided to accept the Minister's explanations.
The Committee thanks the Minister for Resources, Senator the Honourable Peter Cook, for his co-operation.
22 November 1989
Senator the Hon. Peter Cook
Minister for Resources
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Quarantine (Animals) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1989 No. 272, considered by the Committee at its Meeting of 2 November 1989.

Apart from the correction of a small drafting error, the Committee noted that the sole purpose of the Regulations is to remove quarantine forms from the Regulations and thus from the control, or even knowledge, of Parliament. Furthermore, the new Forms will not even be approved by the Minister but only by the Director, a public official. Thus not only is Parliament deprived of its former opportunity to scrutinise these instruments, the use of which appears to be mandatory, but the Minister, who is subject to personal scrutiny in the Parliament, need not even be informed of changes made.

The Explanatory Statement advised that ``There is now a need to update the forms to bring them into line with current forms design. To effect this and to facilitate any future changes which may become necessary, amendment . . . is desirable to enable a form to be revised without amendment of the Regulations''. There appears to be no other explanation provided for this important change.

The Committee would appreciate your full advice as to why the forms cannot be updated by amendment of the Regulations and why it is desirable to enable a form to be revised without amendment to the Regulations. In particular, the Committee would be grateful if you could relate the question of desirability to the exclusion of Parliament from supervision of mandatory legislative instruments in favour not even of the Minister, who is answerable to personal examination of his or her actions in the Parliament itself, but to a public official.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
13 December 1989
Senator Bob Collins
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator Collins

Thank you for your letter dated 22 November 1989 on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, concerning Quarantine (Animals) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1989 No. 272, which was considered by the Committee on 2 November 1989.
The Committee sought advice as to why quarantine forms cannot be updated by amendment of the Regulations and why it is desirable to enable a form to be revised without amendment to the Regulations.

There is no reason why forms cannot be updated by amendment of the Regulations. However, it is considered more expedient and less costly if forms may be updated without the need to amend the Regulations. The essential information to be provided by the public on these forms is and will continue to be, stipulated in the Quarantine Act 1908 or subordinate legislation and will only vary format in the way information is requested. For example, in respect of Form A, Regulation 7 provides and will continue to provide that-

`` . . . The Master of any vessel on which is any animal intended to be imported from any country (except New Zealand) from which animals of the particular kind are permitted to be imported shall, immediately on arrival at the port where that animal is to be landed, deliver to the Chief Quarantine Officer a notice and declaration in accordance . . .''.

It is expedient and good administrative practice that the actual format be subject to change in accordance with administrative procedure, at any time and for inclusion of data which will facilitate administration of the legislation, assist the public and improve the services offered.

Having considered the proposal and my subsequent approval on 13 September 1989 to delete reference to prescribed forms A, B, C, D and E from the Quarantine (Animals) Regulations, I am satisfied that the reasons as submitted to me, justify the changes.
Thank you for the opportunity to clarify the matter for the Committee.
Yours fraternally
Peter Cook
INTERPRETATION ORDINANCE 1989
TERRITORY OF ASHMORE AND CARTIER ISLANDS ORDINANCE NO. 3 OF 1989

The Committee's concerns related to the legislative policy which led to the form in which this Ordinance was made. The Committee is not, of course, concerned with the policy merits of delegated legislation which it scrutinises. This is one of the reasons for the effective operation of the Committee over 57 years, during which time the Senate has never failed to support one of its recommendations. Mere assertion of policy considerations, however, will not be sufficient to explain to the Committee an apparent breach of its principles. In such cases the Committee believes that the protection of individual rights and parliamentary proprieties takes precedence.

Assertions of policy may be one factor which the Committee takes into account and which will be given some weight if accompanied by other advice. In a recent case one Minister explained that a particular provision was prompted by high government policy. The Committee replied that this was not sufficient explanation by itself. The Committee will, however, give more weight to policy determined by say, Cabinet, than by a public official. This is because the originators of such policy are subject to personal scrutiny in the Parliament.

In this general context, the Committee raises concerns where legislative policy may impinge on its principles. In the present case the Committee's express concerns related to the legislative policy which resulted in this Ordinance being drafted by reference to provisions of other statutes which are cited by reference to numbers only, with no indication of content. The result is that at least six separate Acts, as amended up to the present date, from three separate jurisdictions external to the Territory, must be consulted to ascertain the state of the law. Some of the provisions of these statutes, cited only by number, are themselves amended by the Ordinance in a somewhat cryptic fashion.

The Minister replied with advice on the policy of the parent Act and the particular considerations which led in this case not to a discrete instrument, but to an ordinance based upon incorporation by reference. The Minister also pointed out the lack of resources to make a self-standing Ordinance expressly for the Territory, which has no permanent inhabitants. An explanation was furnished to the Committee with respect to incorporation from each relevant jurisdiction.
The Committee thanks the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator the Hon. Graham Richardson, for his co-operation.
22 November 1989
The Hon Clyde Holding MP
Minister for the Arts, Tourism
and Territories
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Interpretation Ordinance 1989, Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands Ordinance No. 3 of 1989, considered by the Committee at its Meeting of 2 November 1989.

The Committee was confused by several definitions in s. 4 (2) ``Interpretation''. In a law of the Territory, unless the contrary intention appears, ``Consolidated Fund'' is defined as meaning the ``Consolidated Revenue Fund'', while the ``Consolidated Revenue Fund'' is defined as the ``Consolidated Revenue Fund of the Commonwealth''. ``Northern Territory Government Account'' means the ``Consolidated Revenue Fund'', which of course is defined as the ``Consolidated Revenue Fund of the Commonwealth''. Thus, unless the contrary intention appears, all four funds or accounts appear to be the same. The Committee seeks your assurance that the operation of the Ordinance will not result in confusion due to this inter-relationship of definitions.

The Committee also has a broader concern with the legislative policy behind the making of the Ordinance. It appears to be difficult for anyone to ascertain the actual state of the law. The Ordinance incorporates provisions of the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Act 1933, the A.C.T. Interpretation Act 1967, the A.C.T. Evidence (Laws and Instruments) Act 1989, the A.C.T. Subordinate Laws Act 1989, the Commonwealth Crimes Act 1914, the Commonwealth Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and the Northern Territory Interpretation Act. The Ordinance also refers to other statutes. The incorporated provisions also include any amendments to those Acts which may be made in the future. The above references are in addition to applied Northern Territory law in force in the Territory.

Some of the incorporated provisions are extremely complex. Sections 4a, 4b, 4c, 4d, 4e, 4f, 4g, 4h, 4j, 4k, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19a, 20b, 21, 21b, and 21c of the Crimes Act 1914, for example, apply generally to laws of the Territory, apart from an applied Northern Territory Law, subject to changed references, the omission of a provision of subsection 4d (2) and the omission of a reference to words (second occurring) in s. 17 (1). There is no indication in the instrument of the content of any of these provisions, although the Explanatory Statement is of some assistance. The incorporation provisions in respect of the other Acts similarly merely refer to the numbers of individual sections.

Finally, from the provisions of s. 13 of the Ordinance, it appears as if issues of the South Australian Government Gazette published before 1 January 1911 are relevant for the purposes of the Ordinance.

The Committee is concerned at what considerations of legislative policy influenced the form of this Ordinance. The Committee appreciates that there may be special considerations relating to the Territory, which it understands has no permanent inhabitants. Nevertheless, the Committee believes that laws made by the executive through the authority of an Act of Parliament should be expressed as clearly as possible. This requirement is not met where an Ordinance incorporates some provisions, only by reference to section numbers, of at least six separate statutes from three different jurisdictions to apply to a fourth jurisdiction. The Committee asks whether it would not have been more appropriate to make a discrete Interpretation Ordinance.
Your advice would be appreciated.
Yours sincerely,
BOB COLLINS
Chairman
Senator Bob Collins
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Collins

I refer to your letter dated 22 November 1989 to Mr Holding outlining the concerns of the Committee in relation to the Interpretation Ordinance 1989 of the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands (ACI).
I would like to make the following general remarks before addressing the specific points in your letter.

The policy of the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Act 1933 is to apply Northern Territory law as far as possible to ACI. It is therefore appropriate to use the Interpretation Act of the Northern Territory to aid the interpretation of applied Northern Territory provisions. However, there are also specific laws that have been made for ACI (and may be made in future). To aid the interpretation of these laws, certain provisions of the interpretation legislation of the ACT have been incorporated in reference, because there were either no equivalent Northern Territory provisions, or the Northern Territory provisions were inappropriate. Examples of the application of the ACT interpretation legislation are as follows:
(1) Sections 29a and 29b of the Interpretation Act 1967 of the ACT concern delegation powers. The Interpretation Act of the Northern Territory contains no similar provision.

(2) Section 8b of the Interpretation Act 1967 of the ACT provides for the commencement of amending paragraphs or items in a Schedule to an Act amending another Act. The Interpretation Act of the Northern Territory does not contain separate commencement provisions for self-contained parts of an Act.

ACI requires a complete and technically accurate interpretation law covering both the Northern Territory-derived and non-Northern Territory-derived components of its legal regime. However, resources to produce such a law in a self-standing, territory-specific form, and in a reasonable time, for islands without permanent inhabitants, are not available. In my view, it is better to have the laws of other populated jurisdictions incorporated by reference from time to time, rather than to re-make virtually identical provisions in a detailed ACI Interpretation Ordinance that would require updating each time the model on which it is based is updated.

This has resulted in a complex Interpretation Ordinance for ACI. However, a judgment has been made, which I support, that it is better to have a complex up to date law (which seldom needs to be referred to) than an easy to read but lengthy law that may quickly become out of date.
I will now address the specific points raised in your letter.
Definition of Consolidated Revenue Fund

In relation to the Committee's concerns regarding the definitions of ``Consolidated Fund''. ``Consolidated Revenue Fund'' and ``Northern Territory Government Account'', I would point out that as the definitions appear in the legislation of the Northern Territory and the ACT as applied to the Islands it was necessary to define each one separately. Although perhaps appearing confusing, the three in fact make clear that each term constitutes the one fund (ie the Consolidated Revenue Fund of the Commonwealth).
Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Act 1933

Provisions from the head Act were ``adopted'' by the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Interpretation Ordinance to ensure that your Committee and the Commonwealth Parliament have full opportunity to review all subordinate legislation made specifically for ACI.
ACT Laws

The reason for the use of the ACT Interpretation Act 1967 is set out above. It is necessary to refer to three ACT laws because on the eve of ACT Self-Government, the ACT interpretation legislation was restructured and the ACI Ordinance, as a result, reflected the (perhaps more complicated) new ACT structure.
Crimes Act 1914 and Acts Interpretation Act 1901

Certain provisions of the Crimes Act were incorporated as ACI is a non self-governing Commonwealth territory and the sensitive area of criminal law should reflect current Commonwealth criminal law policy. For similar reasons, some provisions of the Northern Territory Criminal Code were excluded from applying in ACI by the Criminal Code Ordinance 1989.

Sections 15aa and 15ab of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 apply to laws made specifically for ACI to ensure that in interpreting those laws, regard is had to the purpose of the laws and, if necessary, to certain extrinsic material.
Interpretation Act of the Northern Territory

As explained above, Northern Territory law is the fundamental source of ACI law and therefore it is appropriate to use Northern Territory legislation to aid in its interpretation. The process of incorporation by reference is complex, but as explained above is, in my view, the only way of ensuring both a system of law consistent with Commonwealth standards and a body of law that remains up to date in the absence of substantial resources to maintain a Territory-specific Ordinance. This is also reflected in the use of reference to section numbers rather than the re-making of each provision.
South Australian Government Gazette

Some South Australian pre-1911 law is still in force in ACI because it is in force in the Northern Territory. Therefore, for evidentiary purposes, it may be necessary at some future time to produce evidence, for example, of the gazettal of legislation made under such law. For this reason the Interpretation Ordinance for ACI contains a section providing for the proof in evidence of a South Australian Government Gazette.
I trust that this letter has addressed satisfactorily the concerns that the Committee has raised
Yours sincerely
GRAHAM RICHARDSON

SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to introduce into the review process the power of the Minister to substitute a favourable decision after the first tier of review. These amendments augment section 64u in the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989-the Act. That provision allows the Minister to set aside a decision of the Immigration Review Tribunal and substitute a decision more favourable to the applicant if the Minister thinks it is in the public interest to do so. The Minister's power to substitute a more favourable decision can only occur if the Minister thinks it is in the public interest to do so. The term `public interest' is not limited solely to public issues. Consideration of the public interest could involve consideration of the circumstances of the particular case having regard to unusual, unforeseen or other features that are deserving of a more favourable response against the background of Australia being a compassionate and humane society.

Concern has been expressed at the time it will take for a case to proceed through each tier of review before the Minister can use the power contained in section 64u. The parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations raised this point specifically. These amendments will meet those concerns and enable such cases to be decided by the Minister at an earlier stage of the process. The exercise of the power will be subject to an obligation to report to Parliament twice each year within 15 sitting days of 1 January and 1 July. Where the Minister has exercised the power under the proposed provision, no review by the Immigration Review Tribunal will be available.

The Government will keep under review those cases where the Minister's decision is more favourable than the first tier review decision, but not the most favourable, with a view to determining whether review by the Immigration Review Tribunal should be available in some circumstances. To remove confusion as to the operation of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 in relation to the Minister's powers after each tier of review, provisions have been inserted which provide that there is no duty on the Minister to exercise the power in individual cases.

The Bill provides that the Minister's powers cannot be exercised to grant an entry permit where the grant of a visa under S11D or the temporary entry permit under S11P is conditional upon the holder not being granted an entry permit while he or she remains in Australia. I am introducing these amendments as another Bill rather than as an amendment to the current Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill for the reason that that Bill is already in the Senate and, if amended, would have to be returned to the House of Representatives for reconsideration. As the House will not sit until after 19 December and as the Migration Legislation Amendment Act commences on that date, this would be inappropriate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (RIGHT TO STRIKE) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McLean) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to provide for the right to strike, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator McLean) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill comes to the Senate at a time when the relevance of the trade union movement is being questioned by the Australian public. With a growing number of people choosing not to join trade unions and the courts being increasingly inclined to uphold appeals brought before them concerning the right to strike it is obvious that the time has come for the Parliament to confront this issue.

A Bill similar to the one that is before the Senate today was introduced by the Thatcher administration in 1985. I must stress to the Parliament that this is not a Bill that has been conceived in a political void but is responding to the growing unease and confusion that is being felt within the Australian community following the recent common law decisions on the right to strike. This Bill will provide the legislators with the opportunity to affirm their support for the right of every Australian to be able to withdraw their labour and by such affirmation bring Australia into line with other post-industrialised societies.

This legislation will move Australian industrial relations from a dependence on immunity in law to providing Australian workers, in 1990, with a positive statement on their right to strike. This legislation will allow Australia to develop an industrial relations system which is based on negotiation and consensus.

It is through this legislation that the Australian Democrats intend to confirm their support for the vital role that freedom of expression must continue to play in any future industrial relations system in Australia. Consequently, we ask the ALP and the coalition to clarify their position on the right to strike before the next Federal election. If they fail to do so then their industrial relations policies will continue to lack the broad social acceptance that is needed in today's industrial relations climate.

The possible legal implications of the recent decisions on the Mudginberry, Dollar Sweets and the airline pilots disputes means that the issue of the right to strike must be resolved by Australia's industrial, legal and political leaders otherwise it shall become accepted, through precedent, that if one or more people go on strike then they can be sued, under common law, for breach of contract. The Australian Democrats believe that as long as the industrial action taken by the individual or association is not designed to cause physical harm or property damage and is sanctioned by the Industrial Relations Commission then it is within the rights of the workers to withdraw their labour.

The Australian Democrats believe that the right to strike is a device which must be used in only the most extreme circumstances and we have consistently criticised both major parties for their adversarial approach to industrial relations. Since 1981 the Australian Democrats have pursued a far sighted industrial relations policy which is designed to provide for greater employee participation in the work place, greater negotiation between employers and employees and a reduction in the level of industrial conflict. This Bill is an affirmation of this position and we wait to see if the ALP and the Coalition will continue to duck this issue in the lead up to the next election.

Just as the use of the right to strike should be seen as a last resort so access to tort action should be limited to those disputes that are not ratified by the Industrial Relations Commission or are designed to cause physical harm or result in property damage. This Bill is aimed at reducing the number of industrial disputes in Australia thus providing Australian industry with the opportunity to compete more effectively internationally as well as ensuring that Australian workers have the opportunity to seek out greater job satisfaction and financial reward. As has been shown by the recent airline pilots dispute the court action carried out by the airlines has failed to induce a return to work and has emphasised the fact that negotiation, not confrontation, is the only way to effectively resolve an industrial dispute. I commend this Bill to the Senate and call on the ALP and the coalition to meet the challenges that are raised by it.
