PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 December, on motions by Senators Robert Ray and Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the adjournment last night I was addressing the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989 and allied Bills that are now before the Senate. I was talking about the final part of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989. I recounted the history in relation to tariff concessions, how up to 1983 there was an unsatisfactory system of by-laws operating which was implemented by the Australian Customs Service, and how in 1982 there had been an Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) investigation which had made some very radical recommendations which became incorporated in 1983 into section XVa of the Customs Act. I was talking about how the problem was overcome by precisely defining in legislative form a series of definitions of what goods could be allowed in duty free because there were no equivalent Australian manufactured goods on the market and how Australian industry benefited from the tariff concession orders. I said that the proposed legislation intended to modify the existing legislation by throwing out that system entirely and going back to the imprecise and unstable system of using guidelines that we had before. I had started to talk about the problems that would happen.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument put forward by Customs following the recent court cases is that, since legislation is being interpreted on a narrow base, it needs the extension to broad guidelines to talk about a class of goods instead of particular goods to give it the flexibility to grant tariff concession orders. I said that I found this utterly illogical. Part of the Customs argument in private is that somehow or other many of the tariff concession orders that have been granted will be rendered invalid unless this legislation is introduced. Again, I cannot see the logic of that argument.

When I originally read this Bill and the second reading speech I found them very persuasive. I was clearly of a mind to support the legislation because I thought it was logical and reasonable. But when I got the Customs Act and read the amendments that were proposed in the legislation, I started reflecting on what was involved and I came very rapidly to the conclusion that it was quite the wrong way to go. I believe that whoever wrote the Minister's second reading speech either did not know what he was talking about or set out to mislead the Minister and the Government on this. I do not know who wrote that speech, but I do think they were not in possession of the information that they should have been in possession of to make the statement they did in the Minister's second reading speech.

One of the things that must be considered is that the present system works, and works reasonably well. It is not a matter of it being impossible to get tariff concession orders. They are not easy to get under the present system, but there are over 9,000 tariff concession orders at present operative, by the Customs own admission, and something like 150 applications a month are made. A legal opinion from one of Customs legal experts, a lawyer specialising in customs law, came to my notice yesterday. I would like to read part of it:

A reasonable person would have thought that there could be no more certainty than legislative definitions of particular terms to ensure uniformity of decision making in this area. The analysis and interpretation of such terms is the legitimate business of the courts. If the courts point to defects, then the legislation is usually amended to change them or to conform with the courts' interpretation. The other usual alternative is to make regulations which explain how the provisions of the Act are to be put into practice. In this instance, however, both accepted methods are to be abandoned and we may be witnessing the introduction of a regime which will very largely preclude the commercial community from any means of seeking review of departmental decisions, a backward step.
I agree with that completely. I think the present proposals do not follow the usual legislative practices. I also find them illogical.

One of the other factors to be taken into consideration here is the fact that the Industry Commission (IC), which is the successor to the Industries Assistance Commission, has already been tasked with reviewing the whole of the tariff concession order field. It will report, after a very detailed examination, in 24 months' time. So the certainty is that the legislation is going to be changed again. Additionally, the formidable resources of the Law Reform Commission are looking at customs legislation. It is just about to move onto this section of the Act dealing with tariff concessions. Again, in the immediate future, we are going to have a very authoritative report brought down. The certainty we face is that there are going to be significant changes to this legislation, if it needs amending, in the next 24 months. We have to question why we are throwing out the baby with the bath water at this time when the industry is quite able and prepared to work with it.

There are some useful points in the changes proposed to section XVa, and the Opposition will be supporting those. We support the earlier starting date for the application of tariff concession orders. We support the transfer of the decision-making process, in the national interest, from the Comptroller-General to the Minister, because that function is a rarely exercised one and it quite properly should be exercised by the executive government of the day and not by public servants. We will oppose the rest of the changes to section XVa.

We will be proposing that there be granted a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, under this section of the Act, for those decisions made by the Comptroller-General. We have chosen those words with care. We do not believe that the Minister's decision in relation to the national interest should be subject to appeal and challenge. The very nature of that decision is such that it should be a prerogative of the executive government of the day. At the present time there is simply no effective way of challenging decisions that are made under the provisions of section XVa of this Act, unlike other sections of the Customs Act. The only resort is to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act-the ADJR Act-whereby the appeal must be based on a narrow interpretation of the law. That flies in the face of the fundamental finding of the IAC when it investigated the tariff concession field in 1982. It said that commercial reality must lie at the heart of the granting of tariff concession orders. If one is appealing only under the ADJR Act, it is impossible to bring commercial reality into it. There is no way that that judgment can be made, so we will move an amendment that provides for appeals, for those decisions made by the Comptroller-General, to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

In summary, the present legislation works. It has a precision to it. It is incorporated in law. It is not left to the whims of public servants. It is free from variability of interpretation because the rules are in the Act. The Act means what it says. The Customs Service, with respect, seems to have difficulty reading Acts and knowing what they mean, as the judgment laid down in the Corinthian case makes clear. The proposed changes will introduce guidelines and will introduce a degree of instability and uncertainty. They are very much a retrograde step because of the imprecision that they will involve. The changes, in our judgment, are unnecessary, in view of the fact that the legislation works well at the present time and that the whole field is going to be subjected to the most intensive review by two responsible authorities, the IC and the Law Reform Commission, in the immediate future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In this package of Bills before the Senate are the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill 1989, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1989, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. I rise to address the Bounty (Photographic Film) 1989, which is the Bill about which there has been a great deal of publicity because it provides for a subsidy of some $36m to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd by way of a bounty for photographic film. Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd is the only company which can at this stage receive this bounty, so it is directed specifically at it.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I want to say to the Senate is that I have nothing but the highest of praise for the Australian staff and employees of Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd. I would not want anything I say during the course of this debate in any way to be taken as any criticism at all of those people. Indeed, I have made two visits to them now. The first visit was long before this subsidy was proposed. I was most impressed by the executive management team I met there and by the staff that I met as I toured the factory. Since then I have gone around Australia singing their praises. This is a company which has 18 unions operating within its framework, and it has managed to persuade those 18 unions to agree to two 12-hour shifts operating each day. I think you, Mr Deputy President, would appreciate that that is certainly not a management feat to be sneezed at, and it is one for which the union representatives need high praise too for going along with that arrangement. The plant is operating 24 hours a day, and that is something else which needs to be praised in this country. There are not enough companies operating 24 hours a day. As I have said, the management has persuaded the employees to work shifts of 12 hours.

I was most impressed with this management team. Indeed, I might say that one of the chief executive officers, if he stays with the company, struck me as being the sort of Australian who would have the ability to ultimately end up as the Chief Executive Officer of the international company, Eastman Kodak. He certainly was most impressive. The whole team under Chief Executive Officer Mr Ed Woods is certainly most impressive. Mr Woods is also a most impressive Chief Executive Officer, thoroughly devoted to his company, to the products his company produces and to exporting Australian-made produce, and concerned about the effect that the international company's direction would have on his company and on Australia's exports.

The Australian management team is not responsible for the need for the subsidy. Eastman Kodak in the United States, apparently concerned that it may be the subject of takeover because its performance in the United States has not been up to scratch, has determined to put a great deal of pressure on its international subsidiaries. One of the ways in which it could put on pressure was to demand from the Australian company that it withdraw from exporting to the Asian market to enable the Brazilian company, which was receiving a very substantial government subsidy, to enter that market. The Australian management, with a great deal of concern and expertise, faced that issue by flying to the United States, talking with the international managers about the problems, and coming back to Australia to work out means of overcoming them. It ultimately went to the Australian Government, pointing out the problems to it and seeking its assistance. As I say, I hold these people and the company in high esteem.

The fact that Kodak (Australasia) needs a subsidy of $36m demonstrates publicly the Hawke Government's failure in relation to the economic problems facing the nation at present. The Government has had many opportunities and the support of the Opposition to introduce the reforms which are necessary to address the basic problems of our economy. There is in Australia a hostile environment for businesses and investment in business. Honourable senators should ask themselves what investor would invest $10m or $20m in a new manufacturing plant in Australia at present. If an investor had those sorts of funds, he would probably look at investing in some sort of real estate-a hotel or office block-where he would be assured of a reasonable return on his investment and the maintenance of his capital. Very few investors would look at opening a new manufacturing plant with their available funds. Those already in manufacturing are not disposed to invest further sums to extend their plant because of the hostile environment.

A manufacturing investor is faced with high interest rates, high inflation and, in particular, heavy business on-costs and regulations. Those regulations have meant that many of them have had to employ one or two additional clerks simply to fill in the forms required by local, State and Federal governments. Rigidities are built into the system and the burdens which parliament imposed on manufacturers at times when they were making substantial profits are still being imposed on them. At a time when we felt we could pay high wages, our wage structure was arranged so that wages could be increased substantially. At a time when we felt that manufacturers were making substantial profits, we imposed upon them a 17 3/4 per cent holiday loading so that when their staff go on holiday their wages increase. We have granted ourselves holidays for any reason we can think of and, whenever a holiday is on a Tuesday, we can bet our bottom dollar that many people will simply take the Monday off. In addition, our management personnel have developed a lazy way of thinking. Frequently one will discover that the management is not in the office on a Wednesday afternoon because that is the day the local yacht club has its yachting race or the golf club has its golf day. If they are not satisfied with taking a Wednesday afternoon off, they nearly always take a Friday afternoon off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about solicitors' practices?

—No, I am not talking about solicitors' practices. I am also not talking about farmers, because I know they do not take those sorts of holidays. I invite Senator Panizza this coming Friday afternoon to wander around the Australian Capital Territory and see what sort of service he can get here, whether in the Public Service or the private sector, and how many people he can get to do something on a Friday afternoon. If an electrical appliance breaks down, one can bet one's bottom dollar that it will not be attended to before Monday morning at the earliest.
—We do not live over here, so we would not know.

—I do not live here either; I live in Port Fairy. The implication was that I live here, and that is not right. I have a house here, as do many other people. It will sit vacant from 22 December when the Government lets me go home until I come back some time in February. I also have a unit in Melbourne and a house at Port Fairy. I have to maintain those three residences because of the sort of job I have here, thanks to the Government keeping us here all days of the week.

SPEECH.PARA: There is undoubtedly a very hostile environment here for investors. Over a period, we have developed a `that'll do' attitude. Clearly, these problems have to be addressed. This Government has not addressed them. Until it does, there will continue to be a hostile environment for business. Few investors will be prepared to put their funds into business and businesses will continue to be uneconomical. That is the fundamental problem with Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd. Notwithstanding the fact that it has two shifts working 12 hours a day and the plant is operating 24 hours a day, because of the underlying problems in this country-interest rates, inflation, high wages, on-costs, and rigidities built into the system-its profitability and its ability to make a contribution to Eastman Kodak have not been as good as they should have been. This has resulted in pressure being applied by the multinational company, and it has ended up with this subsidy to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd.

Following the 1987 election, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that micro-economic reform was to be the centrepiece of this third term agenda. We use this jargon `micro-economic reform' and people wonder what it is. We are talking about addressing the fundamentals of the difficulties of this nation so as to reduce the problems and burdens imposed upon our productive sector. The Opposition praised this course of action proposed by the Prime Minister but, like many of his other promises, it has simply not been fulfilled.

There has been much talk by senior Ministers about achieving micro-economic reform, and indeed some of the first halting steps have been taken along that path. I refer in particular to the so-called corporatisation of government business enterprises, whereby the government business enterprises became public companies and so have been managed as if they were public companies although wholly owned by the Commonwealth of Australia, but at least operating under a public company structure. That was a step in the right direction. Of course, the Government knew that it should have taken the path towards privatisation, but the Labor Party back bench refused to allow the Government to go down that path. So the corporatisation has been the only step taken in relation to government business enterprises.

So far as the other areas of micro-economic reform are concerned, in particular coastal shipping, the waterfront and the problems of the transport and communications industry, nothing has been done. Certainly, nothing has been done since Minister Willis replaced Minister Evans. On 25 May 1988 the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, announced a program of phased reductions in tariffs. He said:
Years of sheltering behind protective barriers had taken their toll on the productivity and dynamism of Australian industry.
He was referring to the protective barriers which had been created in the past. He went on:
. . . to allow revitalisation and restructuring to take place.
He continued:
An important component is the phased reduction in Government support, particularly through reductions in tariffs, and greater concentration on the underlying determinants of competitiveness.
Senator Button then went on to say:

Having put in place a consistent and phased approach to tariff reductions industry was better able to concentrate on areas vital to the building of long term international competitive advantage. These areas include quality, design, marketing, and research and development. There has been a fundamental change in industry approach away from Government assistance towards firms themselves addressing those factors so crucial to their success.

Fine words. At the same time, Senator Button's colleagues were excelling in their rhetoric about what should be done. But what was actually happening was that in some cases effective protection was in fact being increased. In the textiles, clothing and footwear area in particular, thanks to the problems in relation to the quota area, effective protection was increased very substantially.

Senator Button made that speech back in May 1988, and since then he has made many speeches about what he has done in this area. He keeps comparing what he has done in this area with what former Liberal-National Party governments have done. He even goes back to the time of Sir John McEwen and talks about protection under the Liberal-National Party Government then. Of course, that is a nonsense comparison. If he is going to talk about a comparison with Sir John McEwen's times, he should also be looking at what the Labor Party policies were at that time, and they would have been in favour of more protection than Sir John McEwen was providing. Senator Button needs to compare his and his Government's performance with what is happening with our international competitors, and with what the Liberal and National parties are calling upon this Government to do at present.
As recently as September this year, Senator Button was telling the Manufacturing Outlook Conference:

Perhaps our greatest achievement has been to persuade the community that Government hand-outs and regulation are not the route to long term international competitiveness, and that change is essential.

Very fine words. They went down very well at that conference. I support those words. But at the time that he was uttering them, he was in fact taking to Cabinet this proposal to provide assistance to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd. He was saying, `Our greatest achievement has been to persuade the community that Government hand-outs and regulation are not the route to long term international competitiveness' but at the same time he was taking to Cabinet this proposal for a hand-out to Kodak. His explanation was that Kodak is the only company manufacturing what are called elaborately transformed goods. In other words, there is not some simple procedure involved in manufacturing, but a complicated manufacturing process, and Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd is the only company in Australia producing elaborately transformed goods which is not receiving a government hand-out. So the Government had to give it one.

I have been saying to Senator Button for a long time that the only way that manufacturers of elaborately transformed goods in Australia can continue under this Government is by being propped up through the taxpayers' pockets. They should not have to be propped up. The Government must turn its mind to the fundamental problems of the economy and do something about them. We do not want just words; we have heard the words. We want to see some action. That, of course, is what the Liberal and National parties' Economic Action Plan is all about-addressing these fundamental problems of the economy and so turning this nation away from this path whereby the only way that companies producing these sorts of goods can survive is by getting a subsidy from the taxpayers of Australia, and turning the manufacturers away from that path and bringing them to a stage where they will be able to stand on their own two feet without this sort of assistance.

I see Senator Panizza in the chamber. This Government was prepared to take action to deregulate the domestic wheat market, as he would recall, but it was not prepared to take action to fix up the problems on the waterfront or with regard to coastal shipping. It was not prepared to take action where there might be some pain for the Australian Labor Party (ALP) because of the strength of the trade union movement in those areas. But it was prepared to take action in the farming community, where there are not so many votes for the Australian Labor Party and where the trade union movement is not as strong. As I said, Senator Button will come into this chamber in due course and try to defend his Government's actions by comparing its performance in this area with the performance of past Liberal-National governments, even going back to the era of Sir John McEwen. But that is an invalid comparison.

Where are the ALP policies to correct the problems of the economy? We know that the Hawke Government has already fallen down badly in this area, and I am sure that the 20:20 vision which hindsight gives us will in due course show how badly the Hawke Government has fallen down on the opportunities which it has had. Senator Button will complain about the era of former Liberal-National governments and, with the hindsight that 20:20 vision gives, say that the wrong thing was done in the 1950s and 1960s. We are saying that the wrong things have been done during the 1980s, and we believe that this will become more and more evident as we move into the next decade.

This bribe to Kodak shows the Government's complete contempt for the Parliament and the law. The Government's actions in negotiating the deal with Kodak were unlawful because they breached the provisions of the Industries Assistance Commission Act which require the Government, if it is going to provide this sort of assistance, to direct the Industries Assistance Commission to conduct an inquiry. When I challenged the Government on this matter, those on the Government side prevaricated until they realised that I was right, and then a decision was made, practically on the spot in the chamber, when Senator Button indicated to Senator Walsh that he would introduce a Bill into the Parliament. So this Bill comes before us in order to overcome the provisions of the Industries Assistance Commission Act, which says that governments are not allowed to do this sort of thing and come along at the last moment with this sort of government assistance without a proper inquiry into whether assistance should be given to the industry under the provisions of the Industries Assistance Commission Act.

Indeed, when the Industries Assistance Commission Act was introduced by Mr Gough Whitlam, he said precisely that governments ought not to be making these decisions on the run for political purposes. So the Whitlam Government introduced the Industries Assistance Commission Act to require these inquiries to be made in the first place, and the Government has overcome that requirement by introducing this Bill. The Government has a provision in the Industries Commission Act which would enable it in the future to consider a Bill without acting illegally. The Government has been paying lip service to all of these sentiments yet, at the same time, has been acting unlawfully, as it did in relation to the Industries Assistance Commission Act.

It sets a very bad precedent. Who is next? Why not the companies who had to go offshore because they were not receiving this protection? I think of Ansell International, a rubber company and subsidiary of Pacific Dunlop Ltd, which is an Australian company. The Government did not provide it with a subsidy to stay in Australia. It allowed it to take its operations offshore. The company had a very successful operation producing rubber products and exporting them all around Asia. That company has left Australia and is now manufacturing in Malaysia. I have mentioned other companies from time to time. As I say, it sets a bad precedent. It is such a bad precedent that the Opposition is not prepared to support the Bill. We say to the Government that this Bill is a bad Bill. We are opposing it. We believe that what the Government should be doing is addressing meaningful micro-economic reforms of the nature I have indicated and trying to reduce the costs to industry of operating in this country so that Australian industry is able to become internationally competitive without having to dip into the taxpayers' pockets.

The purpose of the Liberal and National parties' Economic Action Plan is to turn this country around so that once again we are strong enough for Australian manufacturers to be able to produce their products at reasonable prices with sufficient quality that international companies and people will want to buy Australian made products and Australians will want to buy Australian made products-not only because they are Australian made but also because they are of such good quality and retail at such reasonable and moderate prices that we are proud of them. We will be able to do that only if this Government gets around to addressing the fundamental problems of the economy and gets those right first. Until we have achieved that, Australian manufacturers, as I say, will have to dip into the pockets of the taxpayers of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill 1989, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1989, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. I confine my remarks to the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill, which is a totally inappropriate measure and could set a dangerous precedent, as has already been pointed out, within Australian industry. Above all, this legislation is preferential, not only as to the product but also as to the location of the industry. In the past few years certain products have attracted bounty and subsidies. I mention a few of these products, in declining order of magnitude: textile yarn, books, metal machines and robots, printed fabric, computers, ships, bed sheeting and ship repairs. The Australian Government has been gradually trying to phase out bounties. In a similar way, tariff assistance has been reduced gradually and is due to be eliminated by 1992. This is in line, we presume, with the Government's commitment to a program of micro-economic reform and a level playing field. The Government has told us time and time again how well we are going with this reform.

SPEECH.PARA: Bearing this in mind, I take this Bill to indicate only one thing, and that is the absolute failure of this Government's industry policy. It is an absolute admission by the Government that its policy has failed. Not only is it an admission of failure, but also it has caused a lot of companies around Australia to wonder whether they are doing the right thing in sticking to the path of micro-economic reform. They could be excused for taking the easy path and asking the Government to treat them like it treated Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd and get a bail-out-and that is exactly what it was; nothing else. The Government is setting a bad precedent, and it will have to live by its actions in the future. The Government's industry policy is obviously now being administered by knee-jerk reaction. The pattern is becoming clear with other knee-jerk reactions occurring around Australia in matters of policy and management.

In addition to the Government's reaction over Kodak, we have the cave-in over Coronation Hill. We had a chance to develop Coronation Hill into probably Australia's richest goldmine which would go a long way towards correcting our overseas trade imbalance. But the Government caved in, as usual, to the greenies. Another example is the deal with the banks over interest rates whereby the banks were able to get more interest on their statutory deposit to help selectively certain users of credit. The Government has given $755,000 in subsidies, to the end of November, to the airlines. Hopefully, the Government will recoup some of that subsidy that has been paid when the airlines get the damages that they have been awarded by the court. In fact, on 16 January the court will determine the exact amount of those damages. A few weeks ago in this Parliament Senator McGauran asked whether, when the airlines got their damages, they would repay the subsidy that they have received from the Government. Of course, the Government has provided assistance, although very belatedly, of about $31.25m to the tourist industry.

It is well known and generally acknowledged that Australia's biggest single problem is overseas debt, which is a result of our huge and unbearable trade deficit. In other words, there is an excess of consumption as against internal production. There are only two ways of improving the trade deficit: first, by increasing productivity and, secondly, by increasing our savings. In fact, we do not even have a choice between the two-we have to do them both and do them quickly. As I have often said in this chamber, for far too long Australia has relied too heavily on the only efficient industries in Australia-agriculture and mining-to keep us afloat. While the primary industries have struggled to do this, the Government has deregulated the domestic wheat market but has not been game to deregulate the waterfront and some of our transport industries. While the primary industries have kept Australia afloat, the rest of Australia has fallen further and further behind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Richardson is kicking them to death too.

—Yes, he is doing his best; he has marginal agricultural land on his agenda, which we have to look into very soon. The manufacturing industry, aided by the trade union movement, has been put in a declining phase with extinction in sight. This Government's decisions of expediency have not helped. I have already cited some points but there are many other examples, such as Coronation Hill, of resources being locked up and projects cancelled to appease this green lobby. An example of this is the Wesley Vale pulp mill, which Senator Button wanted and, I believe, still wants. So what are we doing instead of going ahead with the Wesley Vale mill? We are chopping down forests, sending wood chips to Japan and then importing the value added paper. This is utter madness. At least Mr Kerin has had the fortitude to say, `Enough is enough'. He has seen for himself that Australia is going down the path of self-destruction by listening to radical people that this Government still kowtows to. If one reads this morning's Sydney Morning Herald one sees that Mr Kerin, having seen the light and which way Australia is going, has incurred his third rebuke from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Who are these people that the Government kowtows to? They are people who want a high standard of living and yet want to close resources; people who eat meat but do not want farmers to have animals in captivity; people who live in timber houses but do not want forests cut; people who must have the best of jarrah furniture, especially in Western Australia where the jarrah grows, but want jarrah forests locked up; and people who want electricity but do not want coal burnt. I could go on and on.
—Not to mention the ducks.

—Yes. If the Australian Democrats get their own way we will not be able to have a duck or two for the festive season. Why has Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd had to ask for this bounty? If one takes the Hansard from the other place as a reliable source of fact-I am not saying that it is unreliable but Mr Campbell, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, is always saying that the Senate Hansard is not worth reading-one sees that the problems may have been imported. The worldwide rationalisation program that the parent company, Eastman-Kodak, is conducting has a lot to do with a patent libel suit currently taking place in the United States. Australia was to be part of that rationalisation. The Government should have delved into these matters before going ahead with the bail-out. It should have looked to see what was causing the problem. I now consider this bail-out to be preferential.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators may remember that I spoke in this chamber in June 1989 on legislation introduced by the Government to cut the subsidy paid to Australian manufacturers of certain products under the Subsidy (Cultivation Machines and Equipment) Act 1986 and the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Act 1985. Although the legislation had a sunset clause of 30 June 1990, the subsidy was cut from the date of the 1989 April statement. This resulted in a saving of $29.4m That is a very significant figure. It almost lines up with the amount that the Government is giving away to Kodak. In 1988 Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd had an operating profit of some $22m and its retained profit was $89m. Where has that $89m gone?

TALK.START.PARA: —It's reinvested.

—Having it reinvested would have been prudent but I suspect that it was expatriated. It is on record that Kodak has been engaging in some transfer pricing. Chemicals available in Australia have been purchased from its United States parent company at 10 times the price. What better way is there to expatriate profits and reduce tax liability? As I say, this is an exportation of profit. This way, the profit of the Australian company is non-existent. Any profit transmitted increases the profit in the United States. This has also been the case with Kodak (Australasia) paying excessively for Kodak technology from Kodak United States. The same applies to second-hand equipment being bought from Eastman Kodak of the United States at three to four times its value.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, before deciding upon this quick $35m bail-out, the Government should have looked further into this matter. I repeat that this measure is very preferential. I have already said that the Government cut a subsidy of $29.4m in respect of the manufacture of cultivation and harvesting equipment. It is very coincidental that $29.4m was removed at the time. Senator Robert Ray mentioned the April economic statement and in his second reading speech on the Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, he said:

As outlined by the Treasurer . . . in the April economic statement, the Government is determined to ensure that fiscal policy is kept tight in order to maintain downward pressure on Australia's trade deficit.

He then went on to tell us that the savings would be used to offset cost measures mentioned in the 1989 Economic Statement, which would assist families and pensioners. Obviously, that is a strange change. While the Government was cutting subsidies of $29.4m to Australian manufacturers we had a complete bail-out of a multinational-and one whose shots are called from the United States. Speaking during that debate, I cited the example of John Shearer Ltd, a manufacturer in Adelaide. It is an Australian company which has been manufacturing in Australia for 125 years. The Government sought to cut its bounty, which had only until 30 June 1990 to go. At the same time, that company had been brought almost to its knees by the trade union movement when the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union had a strike for two weeks over compulsory unionism. The Government did not offer to help in that case; it left the company to its own devices. It then added insult to injury and cut the bounty 12 months early. The Government refused to pay bounty even on machines that were on the order book or going through the factory. However, I believe that it did back down on that a little later on. Of course, the firm was in Adelaide and probably in a secure seat, not in Melbourne in the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Farm machinery and primary industry are of lesser concern for this Government; they are there simply to carry on for Australia. The Bill is very selective. Shearer Ltd may have to go offshore to manufacture Australia's best tillage machinery and then import the machinery back into Australia. One cannot be more selective than that.

Of course, this is the modus operandi of the Government as we run down to the election. The honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) made some interesting comments in the House of Representatives. He said that Kodak and many other Australian companies were not on a level playing field because of what governments do on foreign shores-something we know very well. He concluded:

It is also worth while going back to see why these kinds of things occur and why the Australian economy, any government in Australia or any State government is so vulnerable to these kinds of approaches and this kind of blackmail. It is blackmail; there is no question about that, and I am not afraid to accept that and I have used that term in the past regarding other companies.

There we have a full admission that this approach by Kodak is blackmail and nothing else. Even though it is admitted that it is an efficient firm, and we know it is an efficient firm, we are being blackmailed into helping it out because of decisions that were made in other places. When we talk about non-level playing fields on other shores, not only Kodak but every other company around Australia, and especially the agricultural and mining industries, has to put up with the distorted economic systems in other places. However, as I have already said, this does not excuse the Government selectively helping companies; worse still when that selectivity is directed towards a multinational company in Australia rather than an Australian manufacturer such as John Shearer Ltd of Adelaide. All other Australian export reliant industries bear the same problems. The problem does not belong only to Kodak (Australasia). In return for this government hand-out one would assume that Kodak (Australasia) would do whatever was possible to ease the balance of trade problem. The Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) said in the House of Representatives:
The signals from Eastman Kodak also suggested that a window of opportunity existed not only to overturn the closure decision-
I presume of Kodak in Australia-
but to press for a commitment to enhance Kodak's Australian operations in the Asian region in return for temporary assistance from this Government.

That is not quite what happened. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald indicates that a Canberra-based firm had received an order from Shanghai for $1.2m worth of colour film and that Kodak (Australasia) refused to supply it. The reason given was that Hong Kong agents handled all Kodak's business in China. An approach to the office of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) asking why Kodak (Australasia) had refused to supply such an order, considering the $36m of taxpayers' money that is being granted to it, resulted in much stalling. I refer again to the House of Representatives Hansard, in which Senator Button's letter was cited. When the Minister finally responded, his letter stated:

While the Government is keen to encourage a greater export commitment by Australian industry generally individual marketing arrangements and decisions by firms need to take account of the nature of particular agreements with distributors and the complexities of particular overseas markets. In the case of Kodak, arrangements between the company and its agents or other traders are matters of a commercial nature which are best left to the parties involved.

That is what Senator Button had to say in his letter when he finally gave an answer as to why Kodak (Australasia) refused to supply that $1.2m worth of colour film. The Government should have sorted these things out before and made sure that Kodak was willing to supply any market, especially in South East Asia. So much for reciprocal arrangements towards reducing Australia's imbalance of trade.

This bounty is bad for Australia and for industry in general. It does nothing for the small manufacturers at the mercy of record interest rates. It does nothing for the farmers around Australia, who are under the same burden as Kodak and any other company or industry in Australia that is burdened by record interest rates. Those industries are still carrying Australia. The Opposition will oppose this Bill and our Leader has undertaken to reverse the decision when in government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill 1989, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1989, The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. I wish to address myself to the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to provide a bounty of $3.75 per square metre of photographic film that is sensitised and finished in Australia for three years from 1 January 1990 to 31 December 1992. If the second reading speech presented with this Bill indicates the basis of a Cabinet decision to provide this bounty, it is an indictment of the decision-making process of this Government. I doubt that I have ever seen a document so full of inconsistencies. Government is supposed to be the guardian of the taxpayers. In this case it is quite apparent that the Government sacrificed taxpayers' money for what it saw as political expediency in the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It shows again how arrogant and out of touch this Government has become. It also has the same foul smell about it as Western Australia Inc.

By comparison, it is interesting to note that a small garment factory in Queensland, which makes clothing for Stubbies, last week fired 100 people; this week a further 150 people from Stubbies have been fired. There was not a whimper from this Government. In a period of just 10 days, in the little town of Gympie and in Brisbane, we have seen 250 people put off. Honourable senators will recall that one of the major reasons given by the Prime Minister at the time as to why he would give this hand-out to a foreign company was that he wanted to save the jobs of 500 people, at a cost then of $60m. It has subsequently been reduced to $36m. That was the excuse given. The Australian Financial Review editorial of 20 September, in referring to this opportunism, said:
The more disturbing implication-
this is of the Kodak bounty-
is that in its senility this Government has decided that the level playing field is too remote a concept, that-with an election around the corner-it would instead move into Lady Bountiful mode.

The question we must ask is: why was Kodak chosen to receive the largess when hundreds of Australian companies are in import replacement or the export business, or have the potential to export, and would and could expand with a fraction of this hand-out of taxpayers' money.

I have also noted that the conditions for Kodak to receive the bounty are that it will be required to engage in the sensitising process for only three years and in the finishing operations for only five years. The sensitising process-preparation and coating-is the tricky business in film making. After three years Kodak will be free to import rolls of sensitised film from anywhere-presumably from Brazil because, according to the information obtained by Senator Austin Lewis, Eastman Kodak's original proposal was to shut down the operations in Australia and supply the Asian market from Brazil.

After three years the company will be free to import rolls of sensitised film. Having got $36m of taxpayers' money from the Federal Government and another $6m from the Victorian taxpayers, it will be able to go anywhere and buy its sensitised rolls. We could see rolls of sensitised film coming in and, after another two years, we will be left with only the mechanical process of cutting and packaging the film, a process which is not new but has been going on for many years, as my colleague Senator MacGibbon will know, in the medical, dental and industrial x-ray film market where rolls of film are brought in, and just cut up and packaged.

The introductory paragraph in the Minister's second reading speech states that the Bill provides bounty for Australian manufacturers-notice it is plural-of sensitised photographic colour film. It should be pointed out-although most people probably realise-that only one company is involved, Kodak Australasia, a wholly owned subsidiary of Eastman Kodak of the United States of America. As such, it is not an Australian manufacturer at all. The second reading speech is misleading. Kodak is a foreign company manufacturing in Australia. It is a pity that the Government was not more honest when it came out with these sorts of statements in the second reading speech. In support of the bounty Senator Button claims that Kodak's Coburg operation is Australia's second largest exporter of what is termed these days `elaborately transformed manufactures' or ETMs. That itself is an indictment of the Government's industry policy after seven years. But if, after three years, the plant is to be reduced to cutting and packaging imported film, will the process still be classified as elaborately transformed manufacture even if there is some export? Senator Button also says that even Eastman Kodak recognised the efficiency of the Australian operation but that it was planning to shut it down for a host of other reasons-strategic reasons, the existence of better tax regimes in other countries, high tariff walls in other countries, et cetera.

One thing I note-I think the general public has come to realise it-about this Government is that there is always a range of excuses as to why it is someone else's fault and why it is not better or possible to manufacture in Australia. The Government never addresses the real problems. It refuses to confront the real issues of what is termed micro-economic reform-particularly in the rigid industrial relations area-which everyone knows would increase productivity and reduce unit costs of production. It is apparent that not even Senator Button believes the nonsense about being efficient and competitive. On page 3 of his second reading speech-this is what I termed earlier `inconsistencies'-he states:
. . . if Kodak Australasia could substantially improve its economic performance, Eastman Kodak would undertake to maintain and develop its Australian operations.

He cannot have it both ways. Senator Button cannot say that everyone recognises that it is an efficient, profitable operation from the parent company down and then go on to say, `However, if you can substantially increase your economic performance we will keep you alive'. However, the question we have to ask is: How was this to be done? How would the company increase its economic performance to enable it to continue in Australia, having been here for decades? This is not a new industry that has sprung up, has had problems and has suddenly deteriorated. It has been here for decades. For decades Kodak had a virtual monopoly of the film market.

I have shown the appalling inconsistencies in Senator Button's second reading speech. The measures which are proposed lack credence. However, for what it is worth, the scheme is that Kodak is to undertake to deliver $20m per annum in productivity improvements. Nowhere has it been spelled out how this is to be achieved. Senator Lewis gave some examples from the industrial relations point of view where the company has moved to two 12-hour shifts and so on, but how will it deliver $20m? Is it true? We have to have doubts.

Labor governments are wonderful on hand-outs of other people's money. The Victorian Government said it would give $6m of Victorian taxpayers' money for three years on condition that the Federal Government provided further assistance. Here we have the pincer movement. Kodak was promised $6 by the Victorian Government if the Federal Government would come to the party. If the Federal Government came to the party the company would not shut down, and so on. Hence we had the remarks about blackmail which were made earlier by my colleague Senator Panizza.

Initially the Federal Government agreed to provide $60m over five years. That was subsequently reduced to $36m over three years. That is all taxpayers' money. As I mentioned a number of times earlier, I suspect that the final result will be that after three years we will have a plant which will be engaged in the cutting and packaging of imported film, not sensitising it, making it or doing the tricky expensive parts of the process. In regard to the efficiency of Kodak I have extracted key figures from Kodak Australasia's annual return for the years ended December 1988 and December 1987 and have applied the bounty and assistance package to the figures. I seek leave to have the resulting table incorporated in Hansard. I referred it to Senator Ray earlier, and he agreed.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures show that, with the assistance package, Kodak Australasia-and thus Eastman Kodak, because Kodak Australasia is a wholly owned subsidiary-has been given as special tax holiday for three years. If the figures for 1988 are repeated in the next three years-the operating profit for 1988 was $35m or thereabouts--
—Thirty-five million?

—A $35m operating profit. The income tax expense was $13m so the profit after tax was $21.7m If we add the assistance package of the $12m per annum from the Federal and $2m per annum from the Victorian Government, using 1988 figures-which were inflated because of the Bicentennial last year; if they were less the effect would be worse-the company would end up with an effective operating profit of $48m with the bounty and assistance. After deducting tax at 39 per cent, or $19m, the profit after tax would be $30m. That makes an effective company tax rate of 15 per cent. A foreign company is being given a tax holiday for three years of 24 per cent of the tax it should pay compared with the normal company tax rate of 39 per cent. If Kodak slipped back to the pre-bicentennial year's progress and brought in a profit equivalent to that of 1987, it would have the luxury of a negative tax of minus 36 per cent. That would be the effect.

SPEECH.PARA: Offering tax holidays was a particularly successful method of attracting new industries to the growth countries of Asia, particularly Taiwan, Korea and more recently, I believe, Thailand. It would not be successful in Australia on its own, particularly while we have a rigid centralised wage fixing system, which may have had some relevance in the distant past but which today, with all its archaic entrenched rackets and rorts, continues to destroy the potential productive capacity of this inherently rich country. The fact that this Government has applied such a package to a foreign company which, as I mentioned, has been here for decades and which has had a virtual monopoly is testimony to this point. It is not as if the Government is offering across the board tax holidays to investors prepared to invest in value added manufacture which would help our export industries. It is applying the package to a company that has been here for years. If a coalition government had pulled a stunt like this for short term political expediency it would have, quite rightly, been pilloried by the Labor Party.

Our country, with its inherent wealth and highly educated population, should be one of the most affluent countries in the world. It should be a place in which everyone wants to invest, adding value to the resource wealth we have. But people do not. We know why and the Government knows why. Unit costs of production are too high. The costs and delays on our waterfront are a worldwide scandal. If the Government addressed the corruption of the economy by its comrades in key areas, it would go a long way to getting our great country back on track and returning our standard of living to what it should be. A bandaid solution to the Kodak problem is only postponing the day of reckoning.

5 Senator Button in recent times has been talking an awful lot-ad nauseam-about philosophical justification. He attempts to criticise the opposition. Let him explain to the Senate his philosophical justification for a taxpayer hand-out to a foreign owned company in Australia which has been here for decades, with no assurances whatsoever of the continued long term manufacturing of photographic film in this country. As pointed out on 3 November in the Australian, Senator Button is right about the $30m subsidy being an aberration. It is a scandal. Senator Button makes the irresponsible scattering around of public money no more palatable by expressing qualms about it. Rather, he makes it look as if he is losing his grip on his portfolio.

As mentioned by previous speakers, the Opposition will oppose this Bill. When in government we will remove the bounty. It is an incredible situation that a package has been put forward which is, from the second reading speech, totally illogical and inconsistent. Statements on one page conflict with statements on the next page. There is no doubt that it is yet again political expediency. It just happens that the plant we are talking about is in the Prime Minister's electorate. People can draw their own conclusions from that. If we are to go down this course, let us make it across the board. Let us not just pick out a company. If one is going to pick out a company one should be clever enough to pick one out that at least is Australian owned and where one could be sure that the payment out of taxpayers' money would guarantee that we would continue to be in import replacement and export down the track. But this package does not guarantee that.

As I have mentioned a number of times, within three years the whole sensitising plant could well be shut down, and it probably will be. Then, at the end of five years, there is no guarantee that the company will be cutting and packaging the import of sensitised film. We may be importing the lot. The Opposition opposes this Bill and we look forward in the committee stage to hearing some of the justifications by Senator Button of the claims he has made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, rise to speak in this cognate debate on the package of customs Bills and bounty Bills: the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4), the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). However, I will confine my remarks entirely to the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill, as has Senator Parer and one or two other speakers. I do so for a variety of reasons, but the prime reason is that in all my many years of experience either in politics or in the Public Service dealing with economic and industry matters I have never seen a more flagrant, politically oriented approach to any use of taxpayers' money for industry purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government stands absolutely condemned for its decision on this Bill. The Opposition will vote against this Bill. If we do not win the day on that, when we win government next year we will repeal the bounty. As the shadow Minister for industry and commerce, Mr John Howard, has said in another place, the arrangements contained in the Bill are wrong in principle. They are economically bad. If we are to have some kind of export encouragement it should apply to everybody; it should not be provided just on ministerial whim and in a particular electorate. As has been pointed out, the Kodak plant is, or was until the recent redistribution of the boundaries, in the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is now just marginally out of it, but for all intents and purposes it is in the Prime Minister's electorate.

The whole handling of this matter has been quite extraordinary. We discovered the original proposal only by flushing out the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, through a series of questions in September. In that context I pay tribute to the role that my colleague Senator Austin Lewis played in forcing the Government to disclose-or drawing it out, inch by inch-what it was on about. Fortunately, the Government's original proposal, which was a bounty spread over five years and totalling $60m, has now been reduced by two years to three years and the figure, accordingly, reduced to $36m-nevertheless, a very large amount of taxpayers' money. The original proposal was to make this deal without having special legislation to effect it. In that context, the original proposal was illegal because, as we know, under the Industries Assistance Commission Act there is specific prohibition of the provision of assistance to a particular industry for a period exceeding two years unless the Minister administering the Act, that is, the Treasurer, has received a report from the Commission about the matter. Indeed, the Act prohibits a Minister from taking any action with respect to this matter until the report is received.

The Government proposed to ignore absolutely that legislative provision in the Industries Assistance Commission Act and to make an illegal payment. It was only through questioning in the Senate that that was disclosed. As a result, the Government has now brought forward this extraordinary piece of legislation in an attempt to legitimate the proposal in terms of the financial arrangements. The Parliament through the provision in the Industries Assistance Commission Act has very deliberately prohibited long term grants of assistance to industry without proper inquiry. This is not a temporary payment, as the Minister tries to argue in the second reading speech-three years is not temporary. There has been no inquiry into this assistance package. In other words, the Government has been prepared to overturn the whole basis of the process established by governments and parliaments of this country for the examination and provision of assistance to industries. It is simply another example of the Government's preparedness to spend taxpayers' money unendingly in an attempt between now and the next election to cling to power.

It is quite clear that many Ministers are very concerned about this decision. The so-called responsible Minister, Senator Button, obviously is concerned about it. He was so concerned that in September when the negotiations were still taking place, before the present arrangements had been finalised-when the $60m deal was still on the go-he told journalists to use `black type to emphasise that the Kodak deal was not a precedent'. The Minister was tested as to this role in bringing the matter to Cabinet. He said, `I have had a part in the decision-that's all'. He was then tested as to what had been taken to Cabinet. He did admit that he took the matter to Cabinet in the sense that he took a document. When tested as to what that document was, he said that it was a memorandum; it was not a Cabinet submission at all. There is a very real question as to what was contained in that memorandum. What size was it? What analysis did the memorandum contain? What basis did it give for Cabinet to take the decision that it did? In an article by Michelle Grattan in the Age on 31 October the Minister is quoted as saying:
If one had one's life to lead in a completely academic, remote world, one wouldn't have made a decision like this.

In other words, the responsible Minister was admitting that this was a decision that was taken on purely political grounds and without any real substance and basis. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), when asked about the matter in September, was quoted in an article in the Australian Financial Review as saying:
. . . it's one we have had to make a judgment about.
It was not a matter of my judgment.

If the responsible Minister, Senator Button, and the person who is in control of the Industries Assistance Commission and the purse strings of this country, namely the Treasurer, walked away from this decision and were not party to making it, in the sense of wishing to see it happen, how was this decision taken? Who really took this matter to Cabinet? Senator Button has said that he took the memorandum but he has never been prepared to say that the Prime Minister did not initiate his taking that matter to Cabinet. Under pressure and under questioning here, Senator Button has never been prepared to dismiss the Prime Minister's involvement in initiating this matter. An article by Paul Cleary in the Sydney Morning Herald on 28 September stated:

Official sources said yesterday that they did not believe that Senator Button was fully behind giving help to Kodak, and that they believed Mr Hawke was the initiator because the plant was located in his electorate . . . It is also understood that Senator Button had taken the matter to Cabinet on behalf of Mr Hawke.

If any better demonstration of the political nature of this exercise is required, I do not know how one could find it. Who really took the matter to Cabinet? In my view there is very strong evidence that the whole matter was initiated by the Prime Minister against the wishes of the responsible industry Minister, Senator Button, and against the wishes of the Treasurer. On whose judgment was this deal made if it was not Senator Button or Mr Keating? Why was the deal taken? Why was the deal made at all?

As Senator Parer put very well in his remarks today, the circumstances surrounding Kodak are those which relate to a small subsidiary-a big company by Australian standards-of the Eastman Kodak empire, said to be efficient in the course of a very inconsistent and illogical second reading speech which was incorporated in Hansard by Senator Robert Ray where contradictory statements are made in succeeding paragraphs. One paragraph on page 2 of the speech says:

The Australian operation is recognised, even by Eastman Kodak, as an efficient and world competitive operation. However, for strategic reasons, Eastman Kodak is unwilling to close down its less efficient operations in other parts of the world.
In the following paragraph of the speech the Minister says:

. . . an undertaking from Eastman Kodak was obtained that if Kodak Australasia could substantially improve its economic performance, Eastman Kodak would undertake to maintain and develop its Australian operation.

So, either the company is now efficient or it is not. I believe it is obligatory for the Minister, when he sums up at the end of this debate, to tell us whether the Government believes that we are dealing with an efficient operation or whether we are dealing with an operation which could become efficient. When we look at the second reading speech which contains what the Minister purports to be the major commitments wrung from Eastman Kodak and Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd as part of this deal, the whole thing looks more and more peculiar. The first commitment said to be given by Eastman Kodak is that Kodak (Australasia) will be retained as a manufacturing plant for colour film, employing sensitising operations for a minimum of three years and finishing operations for a minimum of five years. Senator Parer has commented on that aspect and I will not go into it further. It is a very open-ended undertaking in my view.

Secondly, Kodak (Australasia) will retain its corporate mandate as the sole producer of Kodacolour 100 colour film for Australia and at least those Asian and other markets currently supplied by the company. That undertaking should not be seen as a great, positive achievement. I am a very strong supporter of foreign investment in Australia-I think it has added greatly to Australian industry and real living standards over many years. So I am not in any way decrying foreign investment in Australia. But what does concern me is that we should have situations where Australian-based companies are restricted by their parent companies in terms of where they can conduct their export operations. To say, `We have wrung a commitment from Kodak that it will at least maintain the Asian and other markets currently supplied by the company', seems to me to be something that we should have expected in any case, regardless of any deal that has been done. Similar comments apply to the third so-called commitment, which reads:
. . . Kodak Australasia will retain its export mandate into those Asian and other markets currently supplied by the company, and be entitled to seek further export markets in these regions.
Of course, it should be entitled to do that. It should not need to have a shonky deal with the Government to make that sort of arrangement. The second reading speech continues:
Fourth, Kodak Australasia will implement significant productivity improvements through award restructuring, inventory, overheads and production line improvements.

Any company worth its salt-and, hopefully, all Australian companies-is doing those things now. Why is $36m being paid to a single, particular company that the Government has plucked out of the air to benefit at the cost, therefore, of all other companies in Australia on the basis of, among other things, a commitment to do things that it ought reasonably to be doing and which one would expect it to be doing in any event?
Similarly, another commitment states:
. . . Kodak . . . will be broadening its research and development activities . . . over the next five years.

Again, I would have thought any far-sighted and reasonable company would be doing that in any event. On close examination, the positives that are outlined by the Government as the quid pro quo for the use of taxpayers' money in this outrageous way add up to very little indeed. One is inevitably led back to the argument that this whole matter is entirely political.

It is not just the Opposition that is concerned about this matter; so too is a whole range of the private sector. Industry has been unanimous in saying that the package is inconsistent with the Government's own stated policies, that it is politically motivated and that it will set a very dangerous precedent. That criticism and comment has come from a broad base of industry. Mr Bill Henderson, the National Executive Director of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, said that the Kodak proposal would lead to a flood of requests for government assistance from other companies. Why not? Why should it not lead to a flood of requests from other companies? What is so special about Kodak that it should be fenced off from other companies in Australia? The chief economist of the Australian Chamber of Commerce, Mr Brent Davis, has strongly criticised the proposal. He is quoted in the press as follows:
``The aid package would basically represent a transfer of money from Australian taxpayers to the US shareholders of Eastman Kodak.
``Throwing money at these sorts of companies will not solve their fundamental problems of poor productivity. The Government is merely bribing Kodak to stay in Australia for another five years.''
The Executive Director of the Business Council of Australia, Mr Peter McLaughlin, is quoted as saying:
The Government should not have become involved in the first place . . .

So, it is not just the Opposition which sees this arrangement as extraordinary and of a purely political nature, governed essentially by the requirements of the Prime Minister and a desperate attempt by this Government to buy votes at the next election with taxpayers' money. If this were just a one-off example of the Government acting in that way, that would be bad enough. But it is part of a pattern that we have seen increasingly in recent months of the Government taking shoot from the hip, ad hoc political decisions involving a great deal of taxpayers' money and distorting the whole investment field and economic climate in this country, the long term consequences of which will be very dangerous.

One example which readily comes to mind and which occurred at about the same time as this decision was the deal done with the banks to give them a higher return on their non-recallable deposits to keep down the level of housing interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you oppose that, Senator?
—I oppose, very strongly, deals of that nature being done, because the whole of the Australian community, and Australian taxpayers--
—You would prefer interest rates to remain high, would you?

—If this Government could get its act half together in terms of running the country and having economic policies which are designed in the interests of this country, it would not have to do the continuing shonky deals for which it is now getting a very dirty name, and rightly so. The Government should be doing what it can to get interest rates down across the board. Australia has, under this Government, the highest interest rates in the Western world. It will not solve that problem by doing behind-closed-doors deals with the banking system. It will do it by getting its policies right. The Government has shown absolutely no prospect of doing that. That is why the sooner the Government occupies the Opposition benches, and we take its place in this Parliament, the better. That is the only way to get interest rates down.

SPEECH.PARA: The deals are legion. The biggest dealer of the lot with the Government is the trade union movement. If one wanted an example of that, one would have only to look at what Bill Kelty said when he was introducing Paul Keating to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) congress in September this year. Never has Mr Kelty's power been more clearly explained than by Mr Kelty himself when paying tribute to Mr Keating. Brad Norington, the industrial editor of the Sydney Morning Herald, referred to the power that Mr Kelty `has as the unseen senior Cabinet Minister in the Hawke Government and the voice of the trade union movement'. In paying tribute to Mr Keating at the ACTU congress, Mr Kelty said:
. . . I must say that when things get tough dealing with the Government, the bloke you go to see is Paul Keating.

He rattled off a litany of favours that Paul Keating had done for him and the trade union movement. In this respect, one need refer only to the disgraceful deal on superannuation in 1986 and the unconscionable involvement of the ACTU in determining the taxation policy of this country. This Government does not move on any economic policy without getting the imprimatur of the trade union movement. The Government has put itself in this disgraceful, anti-democratic situation.

Perhaps the most telling criticism of the Kodak decision comes from Senator Button himself. Just a week or so before the details of the Kodak negotiations broke, Senator Button addressed the Manufacturing Outlook Conference. He stated:

Perhaps our greatest achievement has been to persuade the community that Government hand-outs and regulation are not the route to long term international competitiveness, and that change is essential.

That is a statement which we, the Opposition, totally agree with. Yet in one stroke, just a few days later, Senator Button shot down in flames everything that underlies that very laudable statement because with the Kodak decision Senator Button-or the Government-has told industry that the easiest profits come from the taxpayers' pockets and that under the Hawke Government the hand-out mentality is alive and well. The Government will have to live with the consequences of that. The implications are very profound indeed, not just for the taxpayers. One wonders how much longer Australian taxpayers can operate and exist under the enormous burdens being imposed on them by this Government.

As well as being concerned about that, one fears greatly for the future of this country if our economic activity is to be distorted week in, week out, month in, month out, by Government decisions which are taken on a totally irrational, illogical basis and which remove any concept of the level playing field, which I thought was a bipartisan view, as an absolute necessity in this country. Week in and week out that level playing field is being rutted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The old mates taking over.

—The old mates are taking over, as Senator MacGibbon says, and any semblance of rational, economic policy-making is going out of the window. The Kodak decision is just one of those examples-it is, perhaps, the most notorious. The Government stands condemned for this decision. The Opposition will oppose it in the strongest possible terms and, on return to government, assuming that the Bill does go through and is enacted and that the present Government does not have a change of heart in the next short while and say, `Enough is enough and we have done wrong'-I do not know what the attitude of the Democrats is; I hope very much that the Democrats will look at this matter on its merits because if they do they will have no alternative but to support us in opposing the Bill-we will reverse this decision immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We must really be entering an election phase because quite a deal of what Senator Short has said was clearly of an electioneering type rather than addressing the issues before us. For instance, he dealt with who might have made the decision in relation to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd and said that he was sure it was Mr Hawke and not Senator Button. It does not make a great deal of difference who made the decision; it is the decision that we should be looking at. The implication is that, irrespective of whether the decision was a good one or a bad one, presumably the Opposition would reverse the decision precisely because it could have been made by Mr Hawke. That is not the issue we are here to debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal with only two of the Bills. I will pick up, first, the Bill that Senator Short devoted so much attention to; that is, the Bill that is quaintly called the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989. It could well have been called the `Kodak Assistance Package'. We certainly agree in general terms with some of the principles outlined by the Opposition in relation to the desirability of not picking off and advantaging particular companies. If one is supporting a government move to spend money to prop up certain companies, one needs to bear in mind the alternative advantages which might come from an investment of a like amount of money in other areas. Indeed, Senator Short has eloquently quoted the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) in support of his criticism of this Kodak Bill. I will be returning to that shortly in relation to the other Bill to which I wish to draw attention, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4), because the IAC has had quite a bit to say about the matters that lie behind that Bill.

The Australian Democrats believe that one should not slavishly follow ideology to that extent. I think that one does need to look at the particularities of the Kodak situation and in the light of that make a determination whether what is being proposed by the Government is in the best short term interests of Australia. If that is the case, one clearly makes an exception.

Kodak (Australasia) has been operating in Australia for a number of years. I understand that it employs some 1,500 workers. It has sales which run to some $472m and exports throughout South East Asia of about $164m. It is said to be the second largest exporter of manufactured goods from Australia. Clearly if such an industry suddenly were to disappear from the Australian scene, enormous penalties would be imposed on the Australian economy through that disappearance. I believe it is more difficult than was outlined by the Opposition to decide whether some support for such an industry is or is not in the best interests of the Australian economy and the Australian people. It seems to me that the figures work out in such a way as to indicate that it is of advantage to Australia in this particular case to offer the support which the Government has offered, particularly in view of the conditions which attach to that support should Kodak (Australasia) renege on those undertakings, so the Government and the people of Australia, represented by the Government, are in a safe and secure position with respect to the offered help.

I do not know how much tax is paid by 1,500 workers in Kodak (Australasia), but I suspect that it runs to the order of over $6m a year. On the total sales of $472m I imagine that Kodak pays substantially more in company tax and various other charges than is being offered back to it by way of $12m a year which the Government is offering to that company. For those reasons it seems to the Democrats that, on balance, this proposal should be supported.
