We note, for instance, that the safeguards that the Government has extracted from Kodak (Australasia) are that it will be retained as a manufacturing plant for colour film employing sensitising operations for a minimum of three years and finishing operations for a minimum period of five years. Certainly the Democrats considered the technology which Kodak is employing because we are aware, as many other honourable senators will be aware, that photographic technology is undergoing a considerable revolution. There are already prototype cameras which can record images digitally through an electronic device onto something like a floppy disc. Eventually these things could be recorded on a type of compact disc. That technology has enormous advantages over the present technology.

We considered the possibility that if Kodak (Australasia) was not developing that technology here we may well be left behind by offering this sort of support. That was a consideration we had in mind. However, it is equally clear that there must be hundreds of millions of cameras using film around the world, particularly in Australia and South East Asia, and that those cameras will continue to use film for a very long period. Under those circumstances there is clearly a reasonably long term opportunity to sell colour film even though that technology may, over the next 10 or 15 years, become obsolete. The assistance being offered is for three years only and again, it seems to the Australian Democrats that it would be unwise to kill off that industry and deny ourselves the short term advantage which would come from being able to supply the Australian and South East Asian market from Kodak (Australasia).

Kodak (Australasia) has also given an undertaking that it will retain its corporate mandate as the sole producer of Kodacolour 100 colour film for Australia, and at least it will retain its export mandate in the Asian and other markets currently supplied by the company. It will implement significant productivity improvements through award restructuring. In the event that Kodak (Australasia) does not maintain its mandate in the region over the next five years, it has agreed to pay back any Federal Government assistance provided.

It is absolutely true, as several honourable senators on the Opposition side have said, that many of these things should be done by companies operating in Australia. I do not know whether we can call Kodak (Australasia) and Australian company as it is wholly foreign owned, but companies operating in Australia should be carrying out these things anyway. The fact remains that Kodak (Australasia) was not planning to carry out these things. It was intending to shut its doors. It is against that sort of background that we need to consider the alternatives of providing this short term assistance and maintaining the industry in this country for a time; of allowing it to go to the wall; or of seeing where else in the economy we could spend that $36m and derive the same or a greater benefit.

The Democrats will support the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989 because we believe that, while in principle these sorts of decisions should not be entered into lightly, in this particular case there are sufficient and significant advantages to the Australian economy and to the Australian people for the Government to take this course of action.

The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 seeks to correct an anomaly which has appeared as a consequence of the challenge to the law as it is. My understanding is that the provision of commercial tariff concessions under the commercial tariff concession system has been operating for a number of years under a law which more recently has been given an interpretation by the courts which has thrown into doubt the way in which that law has been hitherto interpreted by the Australian Customs Service.

It is important to look at the report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) on commercial tariff concessions with respect to PVC foam blocks and DC electric motors. The IAC drew attention to several important general issues which arose out of that inquiry. These issues are very much the matters which underlie the Bill before us. The IAC drew attention to the fact that in providing these commercial tariff concessions orders, or CTCOs, there were two criteria that the Australian Customs Service should take into account and that neither of these criteria was really satisfactory. The criteria were the likeness or similarity of goods for which tariff concessions were being sought compared with similar goods manufactured or potentially capable of being manufactured in Australia. So on the one hand there was the likeness of the goods and on the other hand there was a characteristic relating to a broader interpretation of likeness-whether there would or would not be a significant cross-elasticity of demand. That impacted, of course, on the matter of whether the potential sale of similar but not identical goods manufactured in Australia would be affected. The IAC says:
The cases under review-
and here the IAC is drawing general conclusions from the particular cases that were being reviewed-
suggest that these Sub-sections-
and these are the subsections to which the present Bill addresses itself-
have obscured rather than clarified that objective.
The objective is the consideration of the general tariff concessions. I will read several sections of the report because they are important in understanding what the IAC is talking about. It says:
The effect of interpretations by the Federal Court of ``identical goods''-
and that goes to the first characteristic-
and the Attorney-General's Department's opinion is that the Act and Regulations confer no power on Customs to change the description of a class or kind of goods provided in a CTCO application . . .

So the effect of the court interpretation which has been given in the last five or six years is that Customs must take very precisely and narrowly the description or class of goods for which the CTCO application has been made. The report goes on:
The legislation would appear to enable, if not encourage, applicants to specify their CTCO applications in narrow terms exclusively to suit their commercial interest.

My interpretation of that is that, given the court ruling in this matter-and I am referring to the Federal Court decision in the Corinthian Industries Pty Ltd case-it would be possible to import an enormous range of goods provided one could sufficiently narrowly draw the terms of the application. The IAC report continues:

The Commission doubts that the end result of such practices would necessarily be different than under previous arrangements, because an artificially narrow description designed to be compatible with ss.269b (3) would still encounter problems with ss.269b (4) and, conceivably, with s.269e . . . The processes involved in administering the system, however, would be more fragmented and cumbersome, as would processing of imports under CTCOs.

Clearly, the IAC there is drawing attention to the complexity of dealing with a potentially much larger number of necessarily much more narrowly drawn applications for tariff concessions. Dealing with the second criterion by which these applications for concessions are to be measured, the IAC report says:

The requirement, in ss.269b (4), that Customs satisfy itself that there would be no significant cross-elasticity of demand between locally produced goods and those which are the subject of a CTCO application can, in practice, only be applied qualitatively.
It goes on:
. . . cross-elasticity of demand is useful in many economic analyses. But it cannot be measured in prospective market situations-

That is precisely the situation in which the Customs Service must consider these applications because these are applications for goods to be imported and goods which are likely to impact on Australian manufacture. So the Customs Service is being asked to take into account cross-elasticity of demand under circumstances in which, according to the IAC, such a prospective consideration is impossible. The Corinthian Industries interpretation really puts the Custom Service in a catch-22 situation. In relation to cross-elasticity the IAC report says:
But it cannot be measured in prospective market situations or with respect to the closely specified goods which are usually the subject of CTCO applications.

Putting those two things together-goods which are very narrowly specified, which is a requirement under the court's interpretation, and at the same time the necessity to consider the question of cross-elasticity-the problem becomes almost an insoluble one. Concluding that paragraph on these general issues arising from this inquiry, it says:
In the Commission's view, the wording of ss.269b (4) [and 269b (3)] now encourages confusion rather than precision in assessing whether goods serve similar functions.

I was particularly interested to hear Senator Short draw upon IAC opinion when he was dealing with the Kodak Bill-the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill. It seems to me that, if the IAC is to be taken seriously, the Opposition should also be looking quite seriously at what the IAC says about the interpretation of these clauses which are the subject of amendment in the Bill before us today. I will just mention briefly the other problem to which the IAC draws our attention in these general remarks-the difficulties faced by applicants for CTCOs. The IAC quotes several people who gave evidence to this inquiry. Among other things, it says:
. . . the applicant does not-and in most cases, cannot-obtain full information without the co-operation of local manufacturers.

That means that, in applications which have to be narrowly drawn and cannot, in any way, be modified by Customs, the onus is entirely upon the applicant to ensure that there are no conflicts between those narrowly described goods and local manufacture, whereas under the Act, as it has been interpreted, the Customs Service is able, by interpreting more generously the form of the application, to satisfy itself that it can assist in inquiring into the conflicts which might arise with local manufacture. The IAC report says:
. . . where manufacturers make claims they cannot necessarily substantiate but which require the applicant to decide whether to under `an exhaustive market survey' to prove his case.

Placing the onus of proof on the applicant for a concession was part of the original design of the CTCO's and was intended to facilitate administration of the scheme. However, experience has shown that this can create difficulties, as local manufacturers who object to a proposed CTCO are often reluctant for commercial reasons to divulge much more than the fact of their objection to the applicant.

Again, the operation of the law as it is, as interpreted in the Corinthian Industries decision, would place very considerable impediments in the way of importers, who would have to obtain all the information themselves and draw their application sufficiently narrowly so that it did not fall foul due to potential conflict with potential Australian manufacturers. One wonders whether the Opposition, in its proposed amendments, is seeking to protect more broadly Australian industry-something that would surprise me somewhat-or whether it is trying to do the reverse of that and to allow a wider range of goods to come in. If it is the latter, I think it must realise that the amendments which it is proposing put a very considerable potential hurdle in the way of those who would import goods under the commercial tariff concession system.

I outline those matters to indicate the difficulties which bedevil this Bill and the way in which, through a court interpretation, a procedure that has stood in place for a number of years has come to be threatened, and in which the Government is seeking, through amendment, to restore to the Act those conditions which were believed to apply to that Act but which had been found, through that court decision, not to apply. I think this piece of legislation is one which has considerable difficulties associated with it. We will be very interested to hear further debate from both the Opposition and the Government in the committee stage of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak on the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989 first, which is the Bill that has generated the most discussion. I think it is fair to put the debate in its true perspective. I suggest that maybe Senator Coulter is the only speaker in the Senate who has, in fact, done that. We are talking about a major exporter and manufacturer in Australia with world wide operations; about implications to revenue, to industry, and to employment in this country; and about laying the foundations for an expanded industry in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the point was made that it is very easy to look at all these issues that come before the Senate in an ideological fix, in an ideological frame, but in reality what is involved is the future of Australia's second largest exporter of elaborately transformed manufactures. It is an operation that already contains a major research and development and manufacturing and distribution capability employing some 1,500 people. For 1989, Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd forecast that of its total sales of $472m, exports of $164m would be generated, so we are also talking of implications in terms of the wider economy. The point has been made: why, in view of the fact that the company here is operating so well, has the Australian operation been chosen for closure. The second reading speech has already traversed these arguments quite well, but it needs to be stated that Kodak in Australia was not targeted for closure for the reason of efficiency. It was chosen very much because of strategic company operations worldwide.

I have already mentioned briefly the costs and benefits of the implications of this legislation. I will go through them very briefly because we do not have that much time. If one looks at exports and compares the figures for exports if the plant were to close with those after the bounty, one sees that over the years 1990-94 in 1989 dollars we are talking of a net benefit of $1 billion. In terms of company tax over that period we are talking of a net benefit of $120m. In terms of wages to employees we are talking of a net benefit of $155m, and 970 jobs. Our balance of payments is positive by $100m over five years. Closure of the operation would turn that positive balance into a negative one of $1.3 billion over five years. Whereas on the one hand governments-State and Federal-are putting in in the vicinity of 442m, the benefits from this injection of funds to society, to revenue and to the balance of payments cannot be underestimated.

It is not an unconditional bounty. Senator Coulter went through some of the conditions involved. Basically, we are talking about a money-back guarantee. We are talking about a commitment which would involve a significant contribution in terms of increased productivity in an area where it must be acknowledged we have a most efficient operation. We are talking about a significant contribution in terms of jobs. In terms of those conditions agreed to by Kodak and the Government we are also talking about a very clear intention to enhance Kodak's operations not only within Australia but within our region. We are leading towards the development between the Government and Kodak of a photographic industry development agreement containing a detailed work program for research and development and investments. Obviously the Senate should take that into account when looking at all the implications of what is involved.

As I said, we are talking about a money-back guarantee, the bottom line of which, in the Government's view, will allow, facilitate, support and enable the company to complete its restructuring satisfactorily, expand its export base substantially and enhance its research and development capabilities. It is easy for honourable senators to come in here in an ideologically fixed frame of mind and complain about what the Government is doing, but in view of the decision's impact on the immediate society and community and its wider economic implications, it will go down as a good one.

It is also very easy to come in here with an ideological fix and criticise the decision when so much of what is argued against it is based on ignorance and a lack of willingness to understand the truth. Senator Short, for instance, said that the Government is acting illegally as there is a prohibition in the Industries Assistance Commission Act on ministerial action without an IAC reference. This legislation is an acknowledgment of the role that Parliament has, that parliamentary action can change the legal framework in which these decisions are made. That is precisely what is happening here. We are not talking about any illegal action; we are talking about the Parliament acting in response to a real life situation.

We were asked why the reference was not sent to the Industries Assistance Commission in Accordance with the IAC Act. In this case, we have a couple of very specifically peculiar problems related to the issue in question. When faced with an overnight closure, governments need to respond very quickly. That is what happened in this place. By injecting funds, the Government was able to obtain a number of performance guarantees, a number of conditions for the future operation of the company involved. In that case, obviously, we need to respond with flexibility. That is precisely why we have taken this approach.

A number of other arguments were raised in the context of the debate. One of the pitfalls of the Senate is that much of the debate that take place here can be anticipated if one reads the Hansard record of the debate in the House of Representatives. The point raised by Senator Panizza about transfer pricing and so-called opportunity for export to China which was made available to Kodak were answered in the debate in the House of Representatives. In respect of the first point, it was very clearly canvassed in the other place-and here we are talking about assistance for activities for which much of the raw material involved was purchased from Australia companies with very minor opportunity for significant cash transfers by way of a transfer price system. In terms of his second point, it should be recognised that, as was explained in the House of Representatives, the approach made offering this $1.2m export order came from an unreliable source, one that is still being followed up.

I do not think I need to go into the other Bills which are listed as part of the cognate debate. I summarise by saying that in this particular circumstance we have a decision which, despite the cynical response which has permeated not only the Opposition but much of the media in this country, by its immediate and long-term financial implications and creation of opportunities is a good one.
Question put:
That the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989 be read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is: That the remaining five Bills be read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few weeks ago I raised in the Senate the question of the behaviour of the Headmistresses Association of the Independent Girls Schools in Victoria concerning the sale of a very valuable property, Invergowrie, which was given to them nearly 50 years ago. I hoped then that the headmistresses would see their way to using the property for a purpose which would have been approved by the donors, rather than taking the money from the sale and using it for their own purposes. These hopes have been dashed. The property has been sold, and the Headmistresses Association has pocketed the money. The Headmistresses Association is very much richer, but the community is much poorer.

SPEECH.PARA: The headmistresses were given Invergowrie by the McPherson family, and here to make clear the points I intend to make I shall have to repeat some of the background information I gave to the Senate last time I spoke. The McPherson family have been remarkable benefactors of education in Victoria. They gave the Emily McPherson College of Domestic Economy, the Engineering School at Swinburne Institute of Technology and, in a different field, the Jessie McPherson Wing of the Queen Victoria Hospital. My particular concern is what is happening to the donation they made of their family home, Invergowrie, an historic building in the inner Melbourne suburb of Hawthorn, to the Headmistresses of the Independent Girls Schools. This gift was made, nearly fifty years ago, partly so the headmistresses could run a homecraft hostel, designed to fill a large gap in the education system as it then was, that is, teaching girls to run homes economically, but more importantly to preserve the historic Invergowrie homestead.

The house itself was built in 1846, and is by any standards one of the most important historic buildings in Victoria. It was, for instance, the site of the signing of the Deed of Separation of Victoria from New South Wales. Even more important are its nearly three acres of park-like surroundings including a tree which is a remarkable Aboriginal relic, because from this tree we can clearly see where the Aborigines carved out a canoe. By any standards the preservation of this historic building and surroundings should be of great importance to the entire Australian community.

Here I should reveal a personal interest. My wife was a McPherson, the daughter of one of the donors of Invergowrie. This has, of course, the advantage that I am well informed about what went on, and what the family intentions were.

It must be accepted that the concept of a homecraft hostel, teaching girls how to run homes, is no longer viable. Girls who until the 1970s would have attended Invergowrie now go to university, though whether or not they learn more there how to run households efficiently could be a matter of dispute. Whatever one feels about that, the fact is that people are no longer going to come to a homecraft hostel to be taught how to run a home.

But that is not the end of the matter. The crucial question is whether the headmistresses held the property in trust, and if so, was it a moral or a legal trust? Representatives of the headmistresses have repeatedly stated, in speeches and in writing, that the property was held in legal trust. For instance, the headmistresses own published history of Invergowrie, written by Miss Daniels, the Headmistress of Ruyton, one of the independent girls schools, referred to the gift as being in perpetual trust to the youth of Victoria, and their solicitors repeatedly stated, in writing, that the property was held in trust. When the matter came before the court, they changed their minds and said that they had made a mistake and there was no legal trust. As Mandy Rice-Davies said in the Profumo case, `They would say that, wouldn't they?'.

About a month ago the Victorian Supreme Court decided that there was insufficient evidence that there was, in fact, a legal trust. The main reasons for this judgment seem to be that much of the available evidence about the trust was not presented to the Court by the Victorian Attorney-General, for technical legal reasons, and many of the contemporary documents which dealt with the nature of the trust, and which were held at Invergowrie itself, have disappeared. One cannot help wondering if someone's shredder was working overtime. But if there is no legal trust, surely there must be, on the headmistresses own admission, a moral trust.

Nevertheless, a decision having been made by the court that the property legally belonged to the headmistresses, they tried to sell it quickly, boasting that it was to be sold without any restrictive covenants. Some trustees of an historic property the headmistresses turned out to be! How quickly they were able to forget about its being held in perpetual trust to the youth of Victoria. At the auction, the headmistresses could not get their reserve price, but they have since sold it for $5.5m. This price, although in the present unsettled property market well below its real value, was substantially higher than the price they could have expected if they had put proper covenants on it to preserve it. Worse still, I understand the purchasers intend to use it for office accommodation, which will destroy its character. Some trustees the headmistresses turned out to be! The only hope now is the Hawthorn Council, which is better than most councils in the protection of historic sites. Throughout all this saga one could see the bright glint of dollar signs in the eyes of the headmistresses. The money goes to the Headmistresses Association. There is no trust. What is the money to be used for-overseas, so-called `study' trips for headmistresses, or scholarships for their own schools? Neither of these would ever have been contemplated by the donors.

The headmistresses have consistently refused, in any serious way, to consider alternative uses for the property which would have been compatible with the inclinations of the donors. They left all the arrangements to a single headmistress who was both obstinate and uncooperative. Nevertheless the headmistresses as a whole must take responsibility for the behaviour of their agent. What they really wanted was no trouble and lots of money. They always pretended to be interested in alternative uses, but in practice they raised insuperable barriers. For instance, they refused to give plans of the property, refused access to it, and refused to give any information about the running costs. They pretended cooperation but in fact were totally obstructive.

I will give honourable senators an example: the concept of Invergowrie being used as a centre for music performance. A proposal to this effect was put to the headmistresses on 3 November, and 11 days later a reply was received from the headmistresses' solicitors saying that the headmistresses were impressed by the principal aims stated in the paper. They went on to raise a series of questions which were quite legitimate, such as town planning constraints, Historic Building Act restrictions, upgrading of buildings, and finished by saying that, in their words, to be persuaded to withdraw Invergowrie from sale the headmistresses would need to have before them a properly costed plan for a use acceptable to them and consistent with their objects. They would need to be assured that money was available to implement the plan, and that the constraints on the use of Invergowrie would be overcome.

The Music Centre Development Committee worked hard, and I think effectively, to answer the headmistresses' problems, only to be told on 24 November that the headmistresses were not prepared to adopt the proposal. It is quite clear that what they wanted, and what they have always wanted, was the money.

I do not know whether the Headmistresses Association has a motto, but if it does not, perhaps I could suggest one, `Greed is Good'; as a gesture to their academic pretensions, I will give it to them in Latin, `avaritia bona est'.

I have watched this saga developing, and I think the behaviour of the headmistresses has been contemptible. As I said a moment ago, greed seems to be their dominant characteristic. So I can give one piece of advice to anyone who might be contemplating making a donation or bequest of any description to the Head Mistresses Association of the Independent Girls Schools in Victoria. That advice is `don't'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the latter part of July and in early August of this year I briefly visited Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Bangkok, Vientiane and Hanoi, and spent nearly a week in Pakistan. My trip, which was excellently assisted by officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, was designed in each case to allow me to meet with women parliamentarians, members of non-governmental women's organisations and, where possible, to visit projects associated with Australian aid which are of particular relevance to women.

SPEECH.PARA: In each of the six countries, the Australian mission had sensibly used my visit to make contact with leading women with whom it had previously little or no pressing reason to meet. The Indonesian Minister for Women's Affairs, for example, was delighted to discuss, for the first time, matters of mutual concern to women of her country and to Australia, and the response to my visit was equally warm and productive in each of the countries. We share a concern for the education and training of women, in order that they may become self-sufficient, or contribute to their household incomes, and perhaps even more importantly to expand the literacy without which women are unlikely to acquire the knowledge and capacity to enhance their own health and that of their children, and to control their own fertility.

Women who live in cities are much more likely to have access to education, public education campaigns and services, as is the case in Australia, where our remote communities are in some respects as difficult to reach as the scattered islands of Indonesia, the mountainous areas of Malaysia or the rural villages of Laos and Vietnam, where the roads are regularly washed out by torrential rains. The secluded women of rural Pakistan are in another category altogether-unimaginably isolated by custom as well as by geography.

In many countries, including those that I visited, domestic violence is recognised now as crime against the community and Australian initiatives to raise public awareness of the great cost in human and economic terms attracted considerable interest. Our structural arrangements, which have entrenched the status of women as a primary concern of government, also met with keen interest, and I have arranged for all the publications of our Office of the Status of Women, and its Consultative Council, to be sent to the relevant Ministers in each of the countries that I visited. Since my return, I have received a request from a group of women lawyers in Lahore through the Australian High Commission in Pakistan, for advice about how to set up refuges for battered women. This has resulted in an extensive exercise being undertaken by my electorate secretary and the coordinator of a nearby refuge who are combining the essence of a wide search of the literature and practical experience for the benefit of Pakistani women. I thoroughly recommend a Canadian publication in this regard entitled Battered But Not Beaten.

I hope that we can build on such links, learn from each other and, working closely with non-government organisations, develop an ever widening network of projects, backed up where appropriate with government services, or vice versa in Thailand, where I met with the Minister for Women's Affairs, Supatra Masdit. There is a very effective family planning program, in the course of which the use of condoms has become highly accepted, and the better education of women is also clearly a factor in control of population growth, and the capacity of women to participate in the very rapid growth in the economy of Thailand as a result of the investment of overseas capital in large amounts. One of my new Indonesian friends, a woman who manufactures clothing and cosmetics, believes that there is a simple answer to population problems, `Give the woman a job', she says, waving an elegant finger, and of course, she is correct, except that there are a number of prerequisites, like transport, child-care training and basic literacy.

In Laos and Vietnam the womens unions are part of the official structures, and their respective presidents are given additional status by being delegates to their parliaments. Literacy is still a problem for women in Laos, as is the delivery of health and family spacing advice, and of quite basic services. The cadre system of organisation, however, is very effective, and I was very impressed by the commitment of the union women, and their newly elected government Ministers who clearly recognise the value of enhancing the lives of Laotian women. As in many countries-not only those shattered by war economically and in many other ways-there is a serious shortage of nurses and other health workers. There is a real challenge, as in Australia, to train locally respected people, building on their traditional skills, and encouraging the retention of elements of, for example, birthing practices which are of advantage to the mother and child, while educating women about the dangers of other traditional practices. One of them was commented on yesterday at the United Nations Children's Fund meeting, that is, dressing the umbilical cord with dung, often resulting in infant death from tetanus.

In Vietnam, where literacy among men and women is not such a limiting factor and is said to be about 85 per cent, the Women's Union is also very active and well organised, partly funded by its own publishing house. Currently it has a campaign under way to encourage each Vietnamese woman to, `Grow a tree, keep an animal, and learn a skill'. Mrs Than, President of the Union, kindly arranged, in conjunction with our mission in Hanoi, a day trip for me to see the activities of a branch of her Union in the Thai Binh province where, with aid from Australia, funds had been provided for three fine pigs for the teaching of animal husbandry, and for a number of sewing machines, in use for some months now as the local women learned to make clothes for themselves and their children.

Other aid measures by Australia to Vietnam include the setting up of a condom factory, and the supply of large quantities of Australian tree seeds, which are given to the elderly village women to nurture into saplings ready for planting. As in Laos, it was apparent that the economic and social devastation of a long drawn-out war would take years to repair, and that Western nations should be, by now, accepting that they have a deep responsibility to assist such countries to rehabilitate.

My time in Pakistan was also well spent, thanks to a comprehensive program arranged for me by the Australian Ambassador and his staff including a meeting with the Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, whose determination to improve the lot of the women of her country must be among the most difficult challenges faced by any national leader. As the result of a rigidly fundamentalist interpretation of Islam, which condemns women to seclusion from the time of puberty to menopause-to which time few survive-women are consigned to illiteracy, poor health, total domination by their spouses and male relatives, early and repeated pregnancies, and often early death. The phenomenon of `son preference' has horrifying consequences for girls, as, for example, clinic staff reporting that 80 per cent of the children being brought for medical attention are boys. Some work that has been done by the United Nations Committee on Traditional Practices which Harm Women and Children indicate that countries with strongest `son preference' are Pakistan, Nepal, Bangladesh and Korea.

Additionally, the previous regime in Pakistan introduced ordinances which have resulted in women being gaoled for adultery in very strange and tragic circumstances. Prime Minister Bhutto cannot repeal these ordinances without the support of her Senate, which includes only two members of her Party. She has ordered that women so imprisoned be released from gaol, but they are inevitably rejected by their families and are therefore completely without resources. At least they are being fed and sheltered in gaol. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a paper which has been sent to me by a committee appointed by the Government of Pakistan which describes the Zina Ordinances.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PAKISTAN WOMENS LEGAL RIGHTS
COMMITTEE
Appointed by the Government of Pakistan
Ministry for Womens' Development
State Life Insurance Building
Blue Area, Islamabad
Chairperson
Regum Rashida Patel
Karachi
Phone Office & Res. 552119
ZINA ORDINANCE

The Women's Legal Rights Committee has considered exhaustively the Offence of Zina (Enforcement of Hadood Ordinance, VII of 1989). It is noted the Ordinance is undemocratic. It was promulgated by the Chief Martial Law Administrator having assumed the Office of President of Pakistan in pursuance of the Martial Law Proclamation 15 July 1979, read with Laws (continuance in force) order 1977. The Ordinance was the figment of few people in power interested in holding onto power. The Law was never put before any group of intellectuals or Islamists with forward looking views and it was never tested for its effaciousness (sic) by being presented, discussed in detail and candid consideration by any legislative body representing the people of Pakistan. The Law was suddenly thrust onto the people of Pakistan through the Television, Radio and Press. The people of Pakistan had nothing to do with the making of the Ordinance. The Ordinance was promulgated under false pretences namely ``circumstances exist which render it necessary to take immediate action''. In fact there were no such conditions. It was not as if the men, and women of Pakistan were increasingly committing the crime of Zina. There was no social menace of Zina. The menace of corruption, misuse of power for personal aggrandisement, unlicensed arms, drugs all were allowed to continue to make insecure, life and property in Pakistan which are inviolable is Islam. The fair name of Islam was exploited by those in power by bringing in the Ordinance on the pretext of bringing the Ordinance ``to bring in conformity with the injunctions of Islam the Law relating to the offence of Zina''. The Ordinance was part of the false stance of Islamisation. The Zina Ordinance is unIslamic in the content and spirit. It allows the long aim of the Law to harass, demean and falsely brand innocent men and women as adulters, fornicators, rapists etc. The Committee noted several reported cases of miscarriage of justice due to defective unIslamic Law. These included the cases of the blind girl, Sofia Bibi, who complained of rape but instead of punishment to the culprit she was convicted of Zina by reason of her pregnancy. There was a furore by the Women's Organisations. The Federal Sirafat Court perceiving the injustice Suo Motto ordered her release on bail on her own bond and finally acquitted. The shame and humiliations suffered by her can never be washed away. The story of Sofia Bibi has been repeated several times and several poor young helpless young innocent girls complaining of rape to the police have had to suffer the humiliation of being accused and for being falsely convicted of Zina. This possibility has become so pronounced that many women and their families prefer to desist from filing a complaint of rape and the rapist goes scot-free and continues to repeat his crime. Women have become much more vulnerable to rape over the past decade. The poor unprotected women of Pakistan suffer from a double jeopardy. Often when a woman is raped she suffers in silence or is forced to remain silent for the sake of family honour. When she finds herself pregnant she becomes liable to conviction of Zina. Can such a law be Islamic?

The other reported case was of Janmia, where a child of twelve was convicted of Zina because she had become pregnant. All know the vulnerability of the illiterate dependent girl-child in the family. How much does the Pakistan girl-child of twelve know to comprehend the crime if she is persuaded to willingness and what means does she have to protest or escape from being subjected to such treatment? The family is only concerned about their society only with blame and the State offers no support, but convicts. Children are the worst sufferers under the Zina Ordinance. Several children are born and live in jails all over the country awaiting trial or undergoing punishment along with their mothers. In a case reported by the Pakistan Women Lawyers Association Legal Aid Centre, a woman accused of Zina bore a child in jail. On being brought to Court the Legal Aid Centre Lawyers asked her if she would like to be released on bail and if she has any place to go to. The answer was no. On being asked what can be done for her, in tears she asked that she be allowed to see her son and daughter whom the police has snatched and given to the complainant. When the complainant was questioned about the children, he nonchalantly stated ``the children were by the previous husband and not my responsibility, the girl died and the boy is lost''. Does Islam allow such callous death and desolation of children which is perpetrated every day under the Ordinance, unsung and un-reported?

Many studies and interviews have clearly brought out that several men and women are accused and convicted for Zina not because they had any Mens-Rea to commit Zina but simply because are unable to produce proof of their previous divorce or present marriage. Islam bases a marriage by two adults on a proposal and acceptance, yet the law refuses to accept this Islamic precept. There are several cases where due to technical defects in the divorce proceedings such as notice to Chairman or unavailability of two witnesses, the women who have been genuinely divorced and remarried are often punished for Zina. The Islamic respect for the institutions of marriage is torn asunder. It is not unusual to accuse a person of Zina especially women in cases of enmity.

Several cases have come to light where the Zina Ordinance is misused for purposes of black-mail. Several women have been made to sign papers giving up their rights to children and foregoing Haq Mahers, allowing second marriages, even gifting their personal property to the husband under threat that the alternative will be a false complaint of Zina. Women are so afraid of being painted with the accusation of Zina that they often give up everything whereas for males in our society Zina is not a serious matter. Does Islam stand to dehumanise innocent women as is being done under the Zina Ordinance?
Custodial Rape

It was noted that the vast majority of women arrested by the police are those under the Zina Ordinance. On a complaint being lodged by any person against an innocent woman, the police are prone to make cursory investigations and for considerations, make out a case and arrest innocent women. The arrests are usually on Thursday to enable the police to torture, threaten, cajole and very often subject the women to sexual abuse while in lock-up. (Friday is the Holy day.)
Harrowing stories by women in jail of rape by policemen shakes the very basis of the Zina Ordinance. Can Islam allow a law which perpetrates custodial rape on women?

The Zina Ordinance has injured the image of Islam within the country in the hearts and minds of the people who have suffered through it. People were falsely led to believe that it is Islamic, all the crimes under the Ordinance are committed under the guise of Islam. Nationally and internationally the name of Islam is being coupled with this psuedo-Islamic law, leading people to the misconception that Islamic law is inhuman.

The Committee noted that several authorities have been concerned with resultant in-humanities resulting by convictions, under the law. Mr Justice Muhammad Afzal-Zullah, Judge of Shariat Bench of the Supreme Court-was quoted to have said that the Supreme Court had required the jail authorities to submit before it petitions for appeals by all women convicted under the Zina Ordinance and in several cases bail was granted on personal bond to women prisoners. (PLD 1989, Journal Section, ``Legal Aid Services''). Justice Dr Javed Iqbal (PLD 1988, page 198 ``Crimes Against Women'' Journal Section) has quoted several examples of the misuse of the provisions of the Zina Ordinance in his experience as a judge. ``In Multan a women, sought refuge with her sister in order to escape the physical cruelty of her husband and filed a suit for dissolution of marriage against him. The husband filed a complaint that she was committing Zina with her brother-in-law, on the basis of which they were both arrested. In view of the circumstances I released them on bail''.

The doors of many places of refuge have been closed to women due to the Zina Ordinance. The bashed wife, the abused daughter or daughter-in-law sexually violated sister are afraid and unable to seek refuge with family or friends for fear of being accused under the Zina Ordinance. Does Islam advocate such degradation of women?

Dr Javed Iqbal recounts ``Rabimyar Khaf a sixty year old man and his sixteen year old daughter-in-law were arrested on the charge of Zina because they refused to grease the palms of police patrol at the railway station. They had arrived in Rabim Tar Khan from Karachi at midnight after seeing off the girl's husband. They were forced to spend the night in the waiting room as there was no transport available to their village at that time. They were released on bail after spending twelve days in confinement. Those cases can be multiplied manifold. Several middle aged couples have been arrested by the police to produce their nikah names and allowed to go only after payment. Does the law of Islam require every married couple to carry the nikah with them? Does the law of Islam prohibit the daughter-in-law travelling with her father-in law?'' The Zina Ordinance states this question in Pakistan. It is the product of prejudiced biased unhealthy minds obsessed with sex. Islam allows conviction for Zina only on the evidence of four witnesses, but the Zina Ordinance makes it incumbent on the judge to award punishment even in the eye of witnesses. The male often goes free on the basis of benefit of doubt but the woman who has become pregnant even by valid marriage stands convicted. The Quranic ayat 2,4,5 and 13 of Surah a Al-Noor relate to the offence of Zina and prescribe the number of witnesses to prove this charge. In Ayat 15 it is explicitly mentioned that in case of failure to produce four witnesses by the prosecution the witnesses who might have appeared are liars in the eyes of Allah. Yet sadder the Zina Ordinance on the evidence of a complainant who is characterised as liar, (not having produced four witnesses) an innocent man or woman can be convicted.

The Federal Shariat (PLD 1989, p. . . . 5) in a recently decided petition has given the finding that in the present day circumstances accusations and complainants are made without giving due consideration. The words commission of Zina are used despite the fact that the required evidence is not available and even where the contents of the complaint do so point to the commission of Zina.

This finding by a full bench of the Federal Shariat Court supports the contention of unfounded allegations of Zina. Numerous instances abound of false complaints of Zina which have been taken cognizance of and prosecuted by the police bringing shame and disrepute to women, which makes them miserable for the rest of their lives. Can Islam be designed to perpetrate such misery?

In a society where witnesses can be bought, where police are most powerful and where false cases can be easily instituted can this Zina Ordinance be supported on the basis of Islam? The Quranic requirement of truthful unbiased weightiness are more often impossible to find, can the Ordinance be said to have provided Quranic justice to the people of Pakistan?

The Federal Shariat Court having realised the large scale of false evidence in Court going unpunished has in the said judgement recommended amendments so that false witnesses may be punished under the Qazf Ordinances. The present practice is for liars to go unpunished. No amendment in the Qazf Law can possibly protect the people of Pakistan from the unIslamic defective Zina Ordinance. It is incompatible with Human Rights and Kidati Fundamental Rights granted under the Constitution of Pakistan.

There has been a strong demand from the Human Rights groups and activists, women's Organisations and Welfare Organisations all over Pakistan to repeal the Zina Ordinance which is a Crime against the Women of Pakistan. It is incompatible with Human Rights.

It is noted by the Committee that there is nothing in the Eight Amendment which precludes the Government from bringing about the repeal of the Zina Ordinance by the Parliament. All that the Eight Amendment requires is the permission of the President of Pakistan for each repeal. The Committee having documented the above injustices, illegality, unIslamic, results in equities and terror on women under this Ordinance, hopes that no one will stand in the way of its repeal.

The Committee strongly recommends that in view of the foresaid evidence demonstrating the unIslamic, unjust, undemocratic, defective, inhuman nature of the Ordinance, this Government should take immediate steps to repeal the Offence of Zina (enforcement of Hadood) Ordinance VII of 1979.
The law should be reverted to as it stood before the Ordinance. The unruled Sections 366, 372, 373, 375 and 376 of Chapter VI and Section 493, 497 and . . . 1866).

In conclusion it is noted that the Ordinance has not in any manner diminished the incidence of Zina. Prostitution, rape, kidnapping, abduction, killing of women, enticing away women or any other related crimes against women. On the contrary the Zina Ordinance has lowered the regard and respect for women in our country. The Ordinance is among the reasons for the rising incidence of crimes against women which has been accentuated by the sexist attitude against women recently evident by the rise tide of crimes against women especially rape and custodial rape.
It is also noted that the psuedo-Islamic Zina Ordinance has affected the concept of Islamic equity and justice in the eyes of the international community under its inhuman consequences.
The recommendation for repeal of the Zina Ordinance is supported by all the following members of the Committee who attended the meeting/discussing on the subject:
1. Chairperson-Mrs Raahida Patel, Karachi.
2. Ms Tallat Yaqub, Lahore.
3. Ms Guishan Ara Alam, Lahore.
4. Ms Suraiyya Jabbeen, Peshawar.
5. Ms Shabnam Alladin Paracha, Quetta.
6. Ms Misbahsaboohi, Islamabad.
7. Ms Naseem Chaudhry, Multan.
8. Ms Mah Talat, Peshawar.

TALK.START.PARA: —The strong and forceful Minister for Women's Development has established committees of talented, educated women who are working on plans to provide legal aid and shelter for such women. I met with women who are members of an organisation called the Womens Action Forum which interestingly was based-since its inception in 1981 in Pakistan-on the Australian Women's Electoral Lobby. This is a progressive group dedicated to reform of Pakistan's oppressive laws and attitudes to women. Such educated women defend Islam as a flexible and compassionate religion, but bitterly condemn the ways in which it has been interpreted to oppress the women of Pakistan.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ambassador Mr Geoffrey Price-he is now the High Commissioner-took Mrs Price and me with him on an overnight trip to Peshawar. We drove up the Grand Trunk Road between rows of Australian eucalypt and callistemons in order that I might see work being done among the refugee women who are part of the 2.5 million refugees who cannot yet return to Afghanistan. At Peshawar, I met members of an Australian army engineers team who are teaching the refugees how to recognise and defuse mines, a little known or recognised contribution being made towards the rehabilitation of these refugees. We were dressed in our shalwa kemeeze and large shawls to conform with national standards of modesty. The only women seen on the street were wearing the burka, a tent-like garment which completely shrouds the wearer, and provides her with a little drawn thread work through which to see.

We were very interested to see a camp for Afghan widows, walled in as is the custom, of course. They were being encouraged to use and develop their traditional sewing and quilting skills, in order to be able to generate some income. The most delightful aspect of this particular camp was that the little daughters of the windows were being educated. Of the 150 schools for refugee children, only two are for girls. In this case, the daily issues of milk, vitamin A enriched, was ready for collection after the classes, so the bright eyed, clear skinned little girls came to the classes equipped with bowls and basins and collected also a little learning which would otherwise have been denied them. In response to questioning they told me that yes, they did tell their mothers about the classes and yes, they did pass onto their mothers the learning that they were receiving so that on the return to Afghanistan I think there will be some changes in some of the remote villages.

In conclusion, I say how very grateful I am to each of the six missions which helped to organise my trip and which, I believe, helped me to make good use of the time from their point of view and from mine. I sincerely hope and expect that out of the contacts we made there will be some intelligent use of the information that we are now able to exchange more freely and that this, in the long run, will be of benefit to women in a number of countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Giles is to be congratulated on the valuable work that she has been doing, as revealed in a most moving address to the Senate about uplifting the status and role of women in depressed countries. It has been brought to my attention, Mr President, that whilst the Australian Government has, over the last five years, changed the Australian taxation legislation with an alleged view to making the system fairer and more equitable, there are cases where the reverse has happened. In fact, the whole system of overseas income is hardly in the interest of either Australian corporations or individuals operating abroad. Today my mission is not so much to examine the problems of corporations but rather a specific group called the Australian Volunteer Development Workers. These people are generally employed for two years in developing countries as part of the Australian Volunteers Abroad (AVA) program. On returning to Australia they faced taxation bills in the order of thousands of dollars from the Australian Taxation Office.

SPEECH.PARA: The tax changes were designed to catch entrepreneurs who shift profits overseas into tax havens. For some they are tax havens but for others they are countries to which Australian volunteers provide much needed voluntary technical assistance. While some Australian volunteers pay income tax in their country of employment, others are not subject to such a levy and therefore must pay income tax to the Australian Government on the money earned overseas.

If the overseas income is subject to tax in the overseas country it is considered as exempt income for Australian taxation purposes and will not therefore be subject to double taxation in Australia. This exempt overseas income must, however, be included in the Australian taxation return and acts to `gross-up' any Australian income, therefore making the Australian income subject to the higher marginal rates of tax applicable in Australia. While this system might seem fair, it must be remembered that Australian volunteers, during their assignments overseas, merely receive a local salary with which to purchase food, equipment and medicines which are often sold to them at greatly inflated prices, due at times to a high level of consumption tax which operate in those countries. Such taxes do not affect the entrepreneur who does not live in a tax haven, let alone endeavour to exist on a local salary.

To quantify the effect that the foreign tax credits system is having on Australian volunteers, I offer three examples: in the Cook Islands a volunteer on local salary of $A11,000 pays local tax at a rate of 24.4 per cent which is equivalent to $A2,684. In Australia a person on the same salary would pay tax of $1,553, therefore the volunteer pays $1,131 more in overseas tax than would apply in Australia. If, while serving overseas, the volunteer had Australian income-such as bank interest, home rental-of $5,000 he is then subject to a further tax bill in Australia of $1,370 which represents a tax rate of 27.4 per cent. This is because the exempt overseas income of $11,000 is used to `gross-up' the Australian income of $5,000 so that the volunteer pays Australian tax on this $5,000 at the marginal rate that applies to the $11,000 to $16,000 bracket. Another volunteer in Vanuatu, receiving $11,000 while paying no income tax in that country, is nevertheless subject to a very high level of indirect tax on food, medicines and other essential household goods. However, for Australian taxation purpose, this income is treated as not having been taxed at all, and therefore the volunteer suffers Australian tax on the full $A11,000 on an amount over $1,400.

While Vanuatu is considered a tax haven country for companies which pay little or no company tax on profits, the foreign tax credits system discriminates against Australian volunteers who live there, and of course they have to pay a high level of consumption tax. A third volunteer in Botswana earning $A11,000 would pay tax in that country of approximately $1,100. This overseas income would be considered exempt for Australia tax purposes. However, the same situation as the Cook Island example applies when Australian income is earned; that is, if $5,000 Australian income is earned it is taxed at a rate of 27.4 per cent.

Section 23ag-that is, the general exemptions provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act-does exempt from Australian tax income earned overseas that is subject to overseas projects. An approved overseas project is typically one which meets certain criteria that focus on the project's commercial benefit to Australia. The Overseas Service Bureau which administers the Australian Volunteers Abroad project has been advised by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce that the AVA program would not be able to gain a blanket exemption as an approved overseas project under section 23af. This is regrettable.

In individual cases, however, some volunteers may be able to satisfy the criteria laid down for approval to be granted, although this is not clear and would only provide relief for a very small number of volunteers and would not be granted without going through an horrendous appeals process.

In light of the above it is requested that, firstly, the Federal Government provide a mechanism whereby the income earned by volunteers as a result of their work overseas as part of the Australian Volunteers Abroad program be classified as exempt income under section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. That would not be difficult because there are other classes which fall into this category if they are considered of commercial benefit to Australia. Perhaps Senator Gareth Evans should look at this closely.

Secondly, any other income earned by volunteers which is not classified as exempt under my first example, should be taxed at the rates that apply to Australians earning income solely in Australia so that they are not penalised as a result of their volunteer work abroad. This means that their Australian based income is not `grossed-up' by their exempt income. Again, this is a perfectly reasonable request. After all we are not asking for millions of dollars from the Australian Government.

Thirdly, the Federal Government should provide a mechanism whereby volunteers, whose sole income is earned overseas, are not required to lodge an Australian tax return until the end of the financial year following the completion of their term overseas. I understand that in June this year the Overseas Service Bureau requested that the Australian Government recognise the contribution made by the Australian volunteer development workers and provide the necessary mechanisms to overcome this additional onerous tax burden. Up to date no reply to this request had been received by the Overseas Service Bureau. Therefore, I take this opportunity now of drawing the Government's attention to this situation and calling upon it to give its immediate consideration. I ask for urgent action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the trials and tribulations of the job we occupy as senators and representatives of our States is that from time to time we receive numbers of letters from constituents and organisations. Sometimes those letters are particularly rude and offensive, and usually they are conveyed-certainly this is the case in my office-immediately to the rubbish bin. Last week I received one such letter which not only was highly offensive personally but also was highly impertinent. The amazing thing about it is that it actually came from an honourable senator who serves in this House. Senator Jean Jenkins, the Australian Democrat senator from Western Australia, wrote to me on 28 November 1989. She opened her letter by indicating how pleased she was to hear, when I spoke in the Senate some weeks ago, that I was one of the success stories in relation to epidural injections for back pain. I thank Senator Jenkins for her concern on the matter. At that time I was seeking to put the record straight and to indicate that this form of treatment did benefit some individuals, contrary to the views being expressed in this place and in the media throughout Western Australia. Senator Jenkins went on:

SPEECH.PARA: My impression from two years of research on this issue is that you are one of a fortunate few and you probably should thank your lucky stars. Until your comments and those of Senator Knowles, I had heard from just five individuals who claimed to have derived significant benefit from the procedure-one of whom was a doctor reporting that one of his patients had been helped. On the other side of the ledger I am now in touch with well over a hundred people who claim to have experienced adverse reactions to epidural Depo-Medrol.
I do not find that comment at all amazing. The fact of the matter is--

TALK.START.PARA: —The rudest member you could get.

—I certainly agree with Senator Knowles on that, but I do not agree with the comments Senator Jenkins made in the paragraph I have just quoted from. The reality of the situation is that, like me, Senator Jenkins is not qualified in medicine. I am not going to put down the medical opinion. The reality of it is that Senator Jenkins actively went out and solicited opinions from people who suffered ill effects from this form of treatment. She did not ask any of the tens of thousands of people who have received this treatment over a period to proffer their views. Not unnaturally, because there are people who have been hurt and have suffered adverse reactions, she heard from them but she did not hear from the ones who benefited. She then demands that the treatment ought to be stopped.

SPEECH.PARA: I am one of the lucky ones, although I am unlucky in the sense that I have a spinal injury which requires treatment from time to time. This form of treatment was recommended to me and administered by a top pain specialist who is renowned not only in Western Australia and Australia but also internationally.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is quite right. We have both been to the same one.

—I acknowledge Senator Knowles's interjection. The treatment provided me with a significant amount of pain relief, which I needed at the time. In my irregular visits to doctors and hospitals, both public and private, over a number of years I have come in contact with a number of other patients receiving this treatment, the vast majority of whom got benefit from the medical procedure administered. I continue from Senator Jenkins's letter:

SPEECH.PARA: You may or may not be aware that Mr Tony Cook-
that is incorrectly spelt-

of the TLC in WA is very concerned about these injections and the fact that many injured workers in WA have been pressured into having them by the threat of withdrawal of workers' compensation benefits. Some were incapacitated by the treatment and are now invalid pensioners.

I know Tony Cooke very well. Tony was actually compensation officer with the Trades and Labour Council whilst I was going through a compensation settlement and was aware of the treatment I was receiving at that time. I am also aware that from time to time individual patients are pressured to undertake procedures but, again, I do not have medical knowledge and cannot comment on specific cases. I have been talking to Mr Cooke about these matters and will again. Senator Jenkins's letter goes on, and this is where I think it becomes not only impertinent but, as Senator Knowles said in an earlier interjection, downright rude:

In order to make sure that we are not talking of different treatments, could I ask whether you have checked with your doctors and are in a position to state unequivocally that your injections were epidural injections of methylprednisolone acetate (Depo-Medrol)?
If epidural Depo-Medrol is confirmed, I would also be interested to know the answers to the following questions:

Then we get six questions, the first of which asks: how many injections did you receive? We are talking about my health, my treatment with my individual doctor, and it is nobody's damned business how many injections I had. I really think it is impertinent for the honourable senator to put this in writing to me. I have no problems about talking individually to any honourable senator about my medical treatment, as we are all prone to do from time to time. Honourable senators would be surprised by the number of people around Australia who have neck injuries. We all swap tales, do we not, Senator Newman? There are six questions in all Senator Jenkins asks about the intervals between the injections, whether the doctor informed me that Depo-Medrol was involved, and so on. The questions are there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our medical records are none of her business.

—They are nobody's business but ours. In my case, at that time I was going through a workers compensation case. It was the responsibility of the insurance company as well as my local general practitioner and was of nobody else's concern. I personally have undertaken this treatment around 20 times, on one occasion three times in the one week. Whilst I would not wish to go back and have that particular form of treatment again-it can be a bit nerve-racking-I would have no problem when the pain is severe enough about receiving the treatment again.

SPEECH.PARA: I felt the need to bring this matter before the chamber this afternoon and to put on the record just how I feel about this. I think Senator Jenkins is doing a great disservice to chronic pain sufferers, not only in Western Australia, my home State and that of Senator Knowles, but also throughout Australia. Here we have a practice that does categorically perform a service in pain relief to me as an individual. I know for a fact that it has provided pain relief for a vast number of people and I think the activity of one particular honourable senator who is putting that treatment in jeopardy is not to be applauded by this chamber or by anybody else. For the sake of the record I seek leave to have the letter from Senator Jenkins incorporated in the Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
28th November '89
Senator Jim McKiernan
S G 106
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Jim
DEPO-MEDROL EPIDURALS
I was pleased to hear, when you spoke in the Senate some weeks ago, that you are one of the success stories in relation to epidural injections for back pain.

My impression from two years of research on this issue is that you are one of a fortunate few and you probably should thank your lucky stars. Until your comments and those of Senator Knowles, I had heard from just five individuals who claimed to have derived significant benefit from the procedure-one of whom was a doctor reporting that one of his patients had been helped. On the other side of the ledger I am now in touch with well over a hundred people who claim to have experienced adverse reactions to epidural Depo-Medrol.

You may or may not be aware that Mr Tony Cook of the TLC in WA is very concerned about these injections and the fact that many injured workers in WA have been pressured into having them by the threat of withdrawal of workers' compensation benefits. Some were incapacitated by the treatment and are now invalid pensioners.

In order to make sure that we are not talking of different treatments, could I ask whether you have checked with your doctors and are in a position to state unequivocally that your injections were epidural injections of methylprednisolone acetate (Depo-Medrol)?
If epidural Depo-Medrol is confirmed, I would also be interested to know the answers to the following questions:
(1) How many of these injections did you receive?
(2) What was the interval between the injections?
(3) Before you had the injections did the doctor inform you that Depo-Medrol was to be involved?
(4) Did the doctor tell you that the manufacturer warns against injection of the drug into the joints of the spine?

(5) Did the doctor tell you that an application by the manufacturer for registration of Depo-Medrol for epidural use to the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee had been rejected because the submitted data did not demonstrate efficacy and because of safety problems?
(6) Did the doctor tell you that a wide range of adverse reactions are associated with the therapy and that some of them, e.g. arachnoiditis, are crippling?
Yours sincerely
JEAN A JENKINS
Australian Democrats
Senator for Western Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of weeks ago a report was tabled in the Senate by the parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Public Works. It was a report on the `Defence Housing Authority Housing Developments at Randwick, Holsworthy and East Hills, Sydney'. At the time I was unable to speak on this report and yet, as honourable senators would know, the housing of Defence Force families is a matter that has been dear to my heart ever since I became a senator and I would not wish the opportunity to pass without making some comments on this report and the work of the Defence Housing Authority generally.

SPEECH.PARA: As the report sets out, the Defence Housing Authority has a portfolio of about 23,000 houses and a current housing investment program in excess of $100m per annum. Back in 1986 we all recall that the Government gave a commitment that over the following 10 years it would introduce $750m to the program for defence housing. The need was that 60 per cent of defence housing had been classified by the Department of Defence as being substandard. At the time we had service families living in houses without hot water systems or with shared laundries in the case of flats. That was not something which this Government could be particularly blamed for. It was certainly something that had accumulated over the years.

The problem lay particularly at the door of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement which had meant that the ownership of many of the Defence Force houses remained with the States and had had inadequate maintenance over many years despite all sorts of attempts to improve the system. I commended the Government at the time for introducing the Defence Housing Authority as a statutory body to improve the housing of our Defence Force families.

I have noticed of recent times however that the current Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons) is claiming that his Government is putting $1 billion into Defence Force housing. I would like to put on the record that this is a very careless use of figures. What has happened is that the commitment of $750m a year has not been increased. In fact the $750m, not per year but over 10 years originally, was understood to be by way of grant. When the fine print was finally settled it turned out that this $750m was to be by way of loan. That in itself is bad enough but what the Minister is now talking about in terms of $1 billion, in fact, is the right which has been given to the company to go out into the commercial market and borrow money up to that amount. So it is, I believe, a rather careless or wilful misuse of financial figures and is designed to be misleading.

But putting that to one side I am glad to see that also the Government has introduced a proposal which I have been pushing ever since I came into the Senate, that is, to copy some overseas Defence Force housing arrangements whereby a housing authority can rent from the private sector and sublet to the defence forces. This has been an excellent way, in some countries, of helping the taxpayer from having to provide too many of these houses out of capital grants but to subsidise the rental, if you like, of houses which are provided by the private sector.

At last, from 1 November this year, the Defence Housing Authority will commence to progressively take over the housing function which was provided until now by the temporary rental allowance. That is, where there are insufficient defence married quarters, service men and women with families are entitled to go into the private sector and search for a house and eventually, after a great deal of bureaucratic measures, they can get some assistance with the rental and can finalise a lease. Unfortunately, however, being very much a bureaucratic process, the amount of the rental subsidy has never been up to date in terms of the current rental market. Some areas in Australia have not been surveyed for a rental subsidy increase since 1986, and we all know what changes have occurred in the cost of housing between 1986 and 1989. It has meant that servicemen have been in a very disadvantaged position in trying to find quarters in some of the more difficult areas in Australia.

The handing over of this area to the Defence Housing Authority will mean that servicemen will in decreasing numbers be required to go out and find a private rental themselves. They will be able to go straight to the Defence Housing Authority and be subtenants of the Authority in private homes that are leased by the Authority. The report talks in clause 21 about the implementation of the new arrangements, which can be expected to result in the Defence Housing Authority providing approximately 4,500 houses throughout Australia through leasing over the next three to four years. The report also says that 3,750 additional houses will need to be acquired over the next five years because there is such a shortage of houses available to Defence Force personnel.

One of the things the Housing Authority is doing to solve that problem, and I have seen a number of these houses myself, is go out and spot-purchase houses on the private market. Some of the housing that has been bought is of an excellent standard, and I am very glad to be able to commend the Authority on the quality of housing it is buying for our personnel. I remind honourable senators that these are not people who are at the bottom of the pecking order in this country; these are people who are very precious to us. They are people who have many skills. They are people who have had an enormous amount of taxpayers' money invested in their training and it is cost effective to keep them. One of the most important retention measures is to house them properly in housing that recognises their importance to us.

I also want to speak specifically to some of the items in this report. The defence forces have been looking for some time now at the possibility of providing extra housing in the Sydney area, and particularly to making use of the spare land at Randwick which was Defence Force stores land. I am glad that finally the Defence Housing Authority was able to purchase six hectares of land there in June this year through public tender. The question of the purchase of this land was one I have pursued for some time through the Defence estimates; I felt that the government departments were not entering into the spirit of things because they were making it extremely difficult for the Defence Housing Authority to acquire land which was already Defence land. I am glad to say that it finally did get this land.

The report states that the site is well located to a number of regional, community, educational, commercial and recreational facilities. It is, but there is one terrible lack: no child-care is available to Defence Force families in that area. Defence Force people come into an area on a two- to three-year posting, put their children's names on a waiting list for child-care, and do not expect to get to the top of the list by the time they are posted somewhere else. Any development of housing in that area must provide for child-care as well. There is an urgent need for Defence Force families who are without the support of their extended families to have child-care provided for in a crowded, congested area such as that, where the existing services are under so much pressure.

Another matter which has been raised with me by some service families relates to the Randwick development and the fact that it is going to be increased density housing. People are worried not just about whether there will be mixed play space for children but whether there will be private enclosed areas for play spaces for families. I urge the developers of the site, and it will be done in a joint development with private enterprise, to provide that sort of facility for Defence Force families in the medium density areas. I am glad to see that there is a recognition that there will be a choice of housing types for Defence families which will be consistent with community standards. It is extremely important, as I said before, that these people are entitled to standards of housing comparable with those in the community they are pledged to defend. I am glad to see that there will be a consistent quality of landscaping and streetscape development. That has been too often neglected in the past.

I am also glad to see that the Defence Housing Authority will dispose of some of the smaller housing in the Holsworthy village. All those things are important. I draw attention to the fact that future development in the Holsworthy village will mean that not only will there be a subdivision in Holsworthy, there will also be a shopping complex containing a group of shops, a bistro, a community centre and two cinemas. Long-day care centres will also be established in the village on land provided by the Commonwealth. There is also talk of a service station. The background to this is that it is meant to be a joint venture. Private enterprise is meant to be involved. There is a developer keen to get on, and the Government is dragging its feet in a most appalling fashion. This community centre and associated public works have been going on for too long; it is totally unsatisfactory. I believe that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, who knows very well that this has been so long awaited, should be condemned for the delays he has allowed to continue on that community centre which is so urgently needed.
