I do not wish to delay the Senate much longer, but I do point out that the Committee draws attention to the fact that holding costs for the East Hills property, which is to be developed when the environmental matters have been finalised, and they are working on those now, are at 18 per cent interest, which amounts to $20,000 a week. When we look at the development at Holsworthy that has been dragging on so long, when we look at all these developments, if there is administrative or governmental delay it is at great cost to the taxpayer. It is quite unsatisfactory for these delays to be allowed to continue. I am glad that the Committee has recommended that these projects go ahead. I simply draw attention to the fact that the Opposition's policy recognises the need for quality Defence housing.

Our defence science and personnel policy states that we will provide an incentive to the Defence Housing Authority to speed up the improvement of Defence housing based on the capacity of the Authority to improve its operating performance year by year. We will maintain a program for the disposal and or upgrading of remaining substandard family accommodation, with a view to raising standards for all ranks to reflect those in the community. We will maintain an efficient repair and maintenance system for married quarters. We will implement a program of management by the Defence Housing Authority of private rental houses for subletting to service personnel. In conjunction with those commitments on accommodation, we will facilitate the provision of family day care, occasional care, and long term child-care, with improved access for the children of Defence Force personnel. We will facilitate private enterprise to establish adequate shopping facilities on or adjacent to bases where such facilities are not readily available.

We know what needs to be done. The parliamentary inquiry into the losses in the Defence Force said that these were things that were meant to be done. The Government has started only on the first step. There is urgent need for more to be done, and until the Opposition is placed in government in this country I do not believe those steps will be taken. Nevertheless, I do wish to commend the work to date of the Defence Housing Authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to express my concern that once again the Australian Taxation Office is delaying, either intentionally or unintentionally, the refund of multimillions of dollars to Australian taxpayers that they have been owed since August or, at the very latest, September. The Australian Taxation Office has an obligation which it has yet again failed to meet, and that is to pay refunds promptly and properly to the many millions of Australians who pay their taxes on time and who are entitled to fair and reasonable treatment from the Tax Office. They are not getting it. In the Illawarra region, there are thousands of rebates that have not been paid, even though the tax return went in on time.

SPEECH.PARA: People are suffering needlessly; families are suffering needlessly in the run up to Christmas. They have not got the tax rebate on which they had been depending for not only paying such things as their huge mortgage repayments-that is as a result of this Government's high interest rate policy-but also simply to provide a decent Christmas for their kids. Last year we had this problem and the Tax Office said that it was a once-off occasion, that it was because of the tax amnesty which was diverting a lot of attention into pursuing that particular matter, rather than getting refunds out.

At that time I spoke in this place-in fact, on 25 November last year-complaining about the situation, reporting to the Senate a letter from the Tax Office saying, `Yes, we recognise that we are a bit behind, but we are trying to fix this up'. This, of course, is all in the context of the Tax Office having changed its system, theoretically, to speed up refunds for those people who are entitled to them, a system now which involves spot audits rather than individual pursuit of an individual examination of each tax return. It simply has not been working. I said at the time that the Tax Office and the Government had better smarten up their priorities. The priority of the Tax Office is to service taxpayers not to service this Government. The service to taxpayers involves giving taxpayers back money that this Government has been wrongly pocketing for months and months before it eventually gets around to giving the money back to the people it belongs to; that is, the taxpayers of Australia.

This delay is absolutely ludicrous. I have had repeated complaints from people in my region, the Illawarra region. I will give one example. It is just a tiny tax office in a small centre. Almost all this centre's tax returns went in by the end of August or early in September. There were only 609 of them. There are 160 tax rebates still outstanding, the bulk of them from returns submitted in August. It suits the Government, of course, to have all this money on hand, the money that belongs to taxpayers. It suits the Government to have it on hand, because it diminishes the amount of interest bill the Government must pay on money it has to borrow to finance its activities.

So, this Government, now as a matter of course-because it did it last year-is using taxpayers money, which is due to the taxpayer, to help offset its interest bill and is saving itself money at the expense of ordinary Australians. I think that this is absolutely intolerable. As I said, 160 returns from this small office, something like one-quarter, are still outstanding after months and months. The cynicism of the Tax Office in this situation is demonstrated by the fact that another large office that I know of in my region, having received very few tax refund cheques, all of a sudden, on 6 December, started to get a burst of them. It got 103 tax refund cheques for its clients in one day, having got two, three and four or so a day over the previous couple of months.

If the Tax Office is capable of processing 103 tax refunds in one day for the clients of just one tax accountant in the Wollongong region, why is it delaying so many other payments? What are the Tax Office's priorities and when will it get it right? I had a look at the Tax Office's annual report to see what its priorities are, to see whether it was even acknowledging its disgraceful performance regarding tax refunds. As I said, it had an excuse, it was the tax amnesty. What is the excuse this year? Have we heard anything from the Tax Office this year? Did it even admit in its annual report that it had fouled up last year in terms of getting money back in reasonable time to individual and honest taxpayers. The answer is no.

I looked through this annual report which, by the way, is still on the Notice Paper and will probably still be there by the time we get up. We will not have the opportunity of dealing with it, no doubt, although it is a very important report and also deals with the role of the Commissioner, which is a matter which has been concerning many members of the Opposition. In that report, when we look at the highlights of 1988-89, we see that one is that there was an increase of 15.2 per cent in the tax revenue collected. It does not say anything about what the increase was in rebates, or how long it took the Office to get the rebates out. That does not figure. What it does say is that audit methods have been designed specifically to ensure that everyone pays his fair share of tax. Good, the Opposition is in favour of that. It goes on, `More sophisticated selection techniques have been developed to minimise the inconvenience to those taxpayers who have got it substantially correct'. Minimise the inconvenience! They are maximising the inconvenience to taxpayers in my region and I presume it is the same throughout Australia with these disgraceful and unjustifiable delays in returning money that is due to taxpayers.

The supreme irony is that the Tax Office in its discussion of the future says, `We have designated 1989-90 as the year of service for the Australian Tax Office with the motto, Get it Right the First Time. We recognise that our task is not just to collect the revenue but to provide a service to those who provide the revenue'. I say to the Tax Office, `I would rather you cut out the flowery words and hurried up with posting the refund cheques'. This sort of excited statement, when it is not backed up by any meaningful effort to service the honest taxpayers of Australia, just adds ire, adds anger, to the justifiable disappointment of those people who are taking out their anger on the staffs of tax consultants, tax advisers, the people who are preparing these tax returns. They are getting abused because the clients quite rightly think, `What is the delay all about? It surely would not be the Government. The Government has promised to get our tax returns back. It has promised to be fair. This is the year of service where it is looking after the clients'.

I think the Tax Office might find that many of its own officers are being subjected to a lot of client abuse because of its failure to have a proper sense of priorities to get these tax refunds out. I then looked at page 22 of the annual report to see the performance indicators. There we see how the Tax Office is meeting its performance indicators. Under phone inquiries it says that the objective is that 95 per cent of calls are to be answered within two minutes. In fact, the Tax Office got around to 73.5 per cent of calls answered within two minutes. I will not deal with the failure to meet its objectives here.

All I can say, though, is that there is no stated objective of getting tax refunds out in reasonable time. It is not even important enough in the Tax Office's sense of priorities to be listed in its list of what its performance indicators should be. It is about time it was because this is, as I said, the second year in a row that the Tax Office has failed to meet any kind of decent standard. It does say that one of its key objectives in revenue collection is the processing of returns and remittances within agreed standards. I understand that the agreed standard-which is not stated here-is something like 10 weeks. I also understand that its way of measuring the 10 weeks is ludicrous. It does not start measuring it until about two or three weeks after most returns get in.

The annual report also says that, under the tax amnesty arrangements, returns for taxpayers with little or no liability have been deferred to concentrate on current returns with significant revenue implications. Once again, the ordinary, honest, decent taxpayer is being put second in the Government's priorities to pursuing current returns with significant revenue implications: not a fair distribution; they come second. It is not putting appropriate concentration on refunds to Australian citizens and appropriate concentration on those Australians who owe tax money. The priority has gone to those people who owe money to the Tax Commissioner, and the good, honest Australian taxpayer has come last yet again. The annual report states:

Due to the extended due date for lodgment and the commencement of work on redesigning jobs we have experienced delays in processing returns beyond our goal of ten weeks. We have, however, achieved significant improvements in the accuracy of system support facilities.

Great. So people wait a lot longer, but they can feel more confident that when they eventually get their tax assessments they may be more accurate. This is not chickenfeed. In the latest financial year 11.5 million individual and company returns were processed, generating 17.8 million notices of assessment. This was an increase of 6 per cent over the preceding year. In practical terms, these notices resulted in $5.4 billion in refunds. We are not talking about chickenfeed which the Government is cheating Australian taxpayers. Up to $5.4 billion is being held by this Government and not handed back in reasonable time to taxpayers, as a deliberate matter of policy within the Tax Office. Its priorities simply are not to pay back this money.

I just remind the Tax Office that Christmas is coming. It would be very nice if families who depend on their tax return to have any kind of Christmas could eventually get their tax refunds. I know the Tax Office and Christmas appear to be at opposite ends of the pole-those are almost incompatible terms-but it is about time this Government gingered the Tax Office. It is up to the Government to determine what the Tax Office should be doing in relation to people. It is not as independent an office as all that. It is the Government's responsibility to ensure that the Tax Office carries out the Government's policies. If the Government's policy is that it does not give a damn whether people get their tax refunds in reasonable time, then I think the Government should be reminded of that fact at election time.

One other simple and brief thing I want to mention is that, because of these ludicrous delays, there are many other government agencies which are not providing the assistance they are required by government policy to give because people who depend on that support have to provide their tax assessment forms from the Tax Office. One cannot get Austudy, for example, unless one can come along with a tax assessment. But there is no tax assessment, so what are people doing? They are being knocked back. Until recently, as I understand it, and particularly last year, because of the ludicrous delays from the Tax Office government instrumentalities were prepared to accept the copy of the tax return when it was done by a registered tax agent. There has been an administrative ruling that this will not take place. The Department of Social Security no longer allows those returns to be accepted. So people are being knocked back for social security and other things to which they are entitled because of the incompetence of the Tax Office and the incompetence of this Government, which probably does not even know any of this is happening. That is my guess. The Government does not know what is going on in its own departments and if it does know and has done nothing to fix it, it stands condemned.
Sitting suspended from 1.55 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the third prime ministerial reprimand in less than two months for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy as a result of Mr Kerin's public disagreement with the currently dominant Cabinet views of Senator Graham Richardson. How long will this farce be allowed to continue? When does the Prime Minister intend to enforce the principle of Cabinet solidarity and dismiss either one or both of these two squabbling Ministers who continue to send confused signals to the electorate and to the mining industry in particular?

—The suggestion in the headline of the Australian that the Prime Minister rebuked Mr Kerin is absolute nonsense. Senator Chaney should refer to the Sydney Morning Herald, which gives a much more reliable account of Mr Kerin's remarks. Mr Kerin and Senator Richardson are one on the issue and that is why Mr Kerin agreed to talk to the media yesterday. Interestingly enough, it was after a meeting of the Australian Mining Industry Council. Mr Kerin talked to the media in order to make it clear that there was no difference of substance between him and Senator Richardson. As I said, this was reported accurately in the Sydney Morning Herald.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I remind the Minister that on at least three occasions Mr Kerin has been reprimanded by the Prime Minister, which suggests some differences of opinion. We had Mr Kerin making his criticism of the Coronation Hill decision in October; we had Mr Kerin making his comment about Senator Richardson bagging the miners and farmers; and then we had the incidents that were reported yesterday. How can the Minister suggest that there have not been public disagreements between those two Ministers or between Mr Kerin and the Government?
—Senator Chaney's question was based on a newspaper report of this morning. Senator Chaney asked me about that incident and even in his supplementary question he referred to three occasions--
—The press got it wrong, did they?

—Yes, absolutely wrong. The Australian got it wrong. Honourable senators should look at the Sydney Morning Herald, which did not get it wrong. In his supplementary question, Senator Chaney referred to three occasions and included the one which is reported in this morning's Australian. That did not happen. So there are two occasions. Mr Kerin's major references to Coronation Hill and Senator Richardson bagging miners and farmers were in one speech.

—Has the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories been drawn to comments in today's Australian by North Broken Hill Peko Ltd that the Wesley Vale pulp mill project abandoned in March would have complied with the Federal Government's national pulp mill guidelines announced on Tuesday? Is this claim accurate? If so, why did the Government prevent the Wesley Vale pulp mill from proceeding? Does the Minister agree that North Broken Hill, by conceding that any new mill proposal will incorporate flexible technology to eliminate chlorine bleaching, is in fact accepting the sensible package adopted by the Federal Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I think North Broken Hill has adopted a very sensible attitude to this proposal since the Cabinet decision last March. I have had quite a number of meetings with it and have found myself in agreement with it on most points. It is heartening to see that it says it will be able to meet these much tougher guidelines. However, the claim that these guidelines were in fact good enough for the Wesley Vale pulp mill to pass last time is simply not true. The emission limits that have to be met to satisfy these Commonwealth guidelines are far more demanding in a whole range of respects than those that were set by the Gray Government in Tasmania. In the liquid effluent stream, the allowable levels for organochlorins, total suspended solids and biochemical oxygen demand are all lower. As far as air emissions are concerned, all of the levels for oxides of nitrogen, particulates, total reduced sulphur compounds, hydrogen chloride, opacity, sulphuric acid mist and sulphur trioxide are tougher, as set in the Commonwealth guidelines, than they were before.

ANSWER.PARA: These guidelines do not stop simply at emission limits either for air or liquids. The reality is that the guidelines specify that, as a prerequisite for consideration there have to be baseline studies. I think it was the lack of meteorological and hydrological studies done prior to an approval for Wesley Vale that caused so much strife. There was a grave suspicion, on the face of available evidence, that the point to which the effluent pipe was to go had very little tidal movement around it and this caused many people on the land and, of course, the fishing industry in Tasmania to get so concerned and aggravated the last time. So on the basis of all those criteria not being met, it is hard to see how Wesley Vale could possibly have met these criteria the last time. The proponents chose not to proceed last time, and I am heartened to believe that this time they might.

As far as flexible technologies are concerned, I think North Broken Hill has shown a commendable attitude on this. It has since last March stressed to the Government that it is prepared to look at changing its technology if and when the technology for a different kind of process arrives or, indeed, if the market need changes. The Government has agreed with North Broken Hill to have a look at the changing technologies and also at the Bureau of Industry Economics which is looking at possible markets for unbleached paper over time. So I do not think we have got too much of a problem with North Broken Hill on that and I am delighted that it is still able to proceed with the proposal, albeit on very much tougher guidelines.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is also addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, follows the question asked a moment ago by the Leader of the Opposition. In his response to Senator Chaney, I noted that the Minister indicated that there was no truth in the story that the Prime Minister has rebuked Mr Kerin for his earlier remarks.
—You like to believe fantasy?

—No, I have said that I note the Minister's assurance to the Senate that the Prime Minister has not rebuked Mr Kerin. I therefore refer to the remarks made by Mr Kerin on these environmental matters the day before yesterday, which were reported in quotation marks in the press-not merely in the Australian-yesterday, not today, to the effect:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . Mr Kerin, yesterday criticised ``trendy environmentalists'', saying Australia would lose valuable income.

``Eventually there will be a backlash against the greens when they realise mining companies aren't exploring any more and most of the manufacturing and value adding companies are going off-shore,'' he said.
``Australia has a lot of high aspirations about the environment but I-
am still tossing up in my mind whether we can afford them.''

Do I understand from the Minister that the Prime Minister, by failing to rebuke Mr Kerin for those remarks, is agreeing with them? Do I understand the Minister, in his remarks to Senator Chaney a moment ago, also implicitly agrees with them? If the answer to those two questions is in the affirmative, would he kindly explain the views on this matter stated by his colleague, Senator Richardson?

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that the Prime Minister failed to rebuke Mr Kerin and that I said in answer to Senator Chaney that the allegation in the Australian was nonsense-I repeat that it was nonsense-does not mean that it can be said of the Prime Minister that he is agreeing with Mr Kerin. The Prime Minister does not agree with everybody in this Government and he does not spend his time rushing around rebuking people. It would not be a very healthy sort of government if he did. It does happen to be a government in which there are differences of views and emphasis, and that is a very healthy thing. Sometimes we find them on the Opposition benches. When we flush them out a bit people start to take points of order because they get worried about having these differences of view exposed from time to time. Honourable senators should not worry about it too much; I certainly do not worry about it too much. I have not seen a written text of what Mr Kerin said but I--
—Then how do you know that the Australian article is wrong?

—I have not seen a text of any speech. I do not believe it was a speech; they were remarks made off the cuff. I am sure there are plenty of trendy environmentalists around and there are plenty of people who see it as important to add value to Australia's resources. Some people object to that, including some people sitting to the left of Senator Stone. There are differences of view about these matters, and there always will be. I do not think it matters very much.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it that I am to understand from the Minister's reply that the Prime Minister may have disagreed with Mr Kerin's remarks but that he has not rebuked him for them. I repeat Senator Chaney's earlier question: What does the Minister understand by the principle of Cabinet solidarity? As an example of that principle in operation I remind him of the resignation of Minister West over the uranium issue in 1983. Does the Hawke interpretation of the principle prevent outright opposition-perhaps one might call it failure to rebuke-such as that by Minister West, but allow more subtle defiance such as that indulged in by Mr Kerin?

—I am at risk in saying this, but I do not know precisely what is in the Prime Minister's head at every hour of the day. One is at risk in saying this because the Opposition perhaps gets a little bit of excitement out of a remark such as that. I have a lot better knowledge of what is in Andrew Peacock's head-nothing, at every hour of the day. I am unable to say whether the Prime Minister agreed with Mr Kerin. As to the question of Cabinet solidarity, if the Cabinet had made a decision last week that there were many trendy green environmentalists running around the country who ought all to be shot, Mr Kerin's statement would be in conflict with it. But we did not make any decision about that. We did not make any decision about whether we wanted to add value to particular raw materials; about what we thought about various sections of the green movement and so on. So there is no breach of Cabinet solidarity. If Opposition senators want to know, Mr Kerin got closest to it when he criticised the Kakadu decision a few months ago. At the time those opposite did not make very much of that; it went through to the keeper.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. The introduction of the family allowance supplement (FAS) two years ago yesterday is now recognised as an historic step in the Government's attack on child poverty. In recent weeks there have been calls for a national summit on child poverty. What is the Government's response to these calls?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been calls from some quarters for a national summit on child poverty. Contrary once again to some reports, the Government does not support the concept of a national summit. Yesterday, the Prime Minister did announce a further and important initiative in the attack on child poverty. He announced that he is seeking the cooperation and commitment of all Australian Premiers--

ANSWER.PARA: Senator MacGibbon interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Has Senator MacGibbon finished? The Prime Minister announced that he is seeking the cooperation and commitment of all Australian Premiers to the improvement of a range of services available to children and families with children. As the first step towards that, he proposed that the States join with the Commonwealth in the establishment of a ministerial committee on services for children. The job of that committee will be to examine the range of services provided by Commonwealth, State and Territory governments, with particular focus on family support services-health services, education services and community legal services. One of the major roles of the committee will be to identify current weaknesses in the provision of these important services, particularly in respect to the geographical coverage of those services. It will also examine and define ways of better coordinating these services. The committee will make an initial report to the next Premiers Conference in mid-1990.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Zakharov mentioned the family allowance supplement. That is the important first step on which this committee will build on the Government's record in this area. Income support is obviously a primary factor in the attack on family poverty. On the second anniversary of FAS, it should be noted that the family allowance supplement or its equivalent is now paid to over 560,000 families with 1.2 million children, including 190,000 low income working families. We should also remember that family allowance is paid to two million families with 3.7 million children. As we have said before, other factors are involved, including the provision of services. These factors are absolutely crucial to any attack on child poverty. It should be recognised that the Government's record on these services is already impressive. We need to think only of Medicare, increasing retention rates in schools, child-care and a whole list of other programs that Senator Button mentioned here yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —`No children in poverty in 1990'. Tell us about that.

—I will tell Senator MacGibbon who has credibility in this area, and I will tell him why. Income support and the provision of services are pivotal. Those opposite ought to take into account three reasons why we are recognised as being sensitive and responding to the area: one, the people can remember the performance of those opposite. They can remember the seven years between 1975 and 1983 when those opposite increased child payments only once-in 1982. Secondly, they also remember that those opposite increased the number of children living in low income families by 50,000 each year, apart from the Opposition's special last year in office when it bumped it up by 150,000. They can remember the degree of disrespect for the issue. They also recognise that the Opposition's family action plan-the `short shelf life plan'-of a couple of months ago does not respond to their needs. Thirdly, and more importantly, people have no confidence in the Opposition's ability to deliver; they have no confidence in the Opposition's core Ministers; and they have no confidence in the Leader of the Opposition. In fact, to sum it up, they think that Andrew Peacock is to politics what Aero is to chocolate-sweet nothing!

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite sure that the Minister for Consumer Affairs has been dreaming up an occasion to use that one; I would hate to take away from his fun too soon. My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and is a `trendy environmental' question that probably will not please Mr Kerin at all. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of this statement by the Prime Minister earlier this week while opening the headquarters of the Australian Conservation Foundation:

QUESTION.PARA: Through efficiency improvements and the identification of alternative forest areas outside the National Estate (in south-west New South Wales) I hope we can get to a position where the industry will not have to return to logging the existing National Estate forests in the South East . . .

He is further alleged to have said that his Government is `prepared to bring down the full weight of its constitutional powers to achieve a solution'. Is the Minister also aware that the Victorian Government is reportedly about to allow immediate logging of National Estate forests just across the border in East Gippsland despite the fact that recommended studies of Aboriginal heritage and water and soil protection have not been done and that the Government has acknowledged that it can find alternative logging areas outside the National Estate areas but is apparently not prepared to use them? Will the Minister therefore contact the Victorian Government to ensure that logging of National Estate areas is not commenced in the following months? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope I got down all the parts of Senator Haines's question. The first part concerns the south-east forests of New South Wales and the Prime Minister's statement that, through efficiency improvements and the identification of alternatives, he was hopeful that the New South Wales Government would not have to go back into the National Estate forests. I think Senator Haines and all other senators are aware that my colleague Senator Cook negotiated an agreement with his New South Wales counterpart which sought to protect 91 per cent of those forests while some flora and fauna studies were conducted.

ANSWER.PARA: It certainly is the intention of the Commonwealth to assist in identifying alternatives so that logging will not have to continue in that 91 per cent of the forests. I do not believe that we have ever made a commitment that we would be protecting the 9 per cent as well. I think any remarks the Prime Minister may have made-I have not seen a text of them-would be referring to the agreement and the 91 per cent. As far as the corporations power is concerned, what we have said is that if alternatives are identified and the New South Wales Government refuses to accept the identification of those alternatives and goes back into the National estate forests, then we will use the corporations powers. That remains our commitment.

As far as the decision in Victoria is concerned, I did become aware of it in the last couple of days. I have asked for a report from the Victorian Minister for Conservation, Forests and Lands, Kay Setches, on what is planned and whether alternatives have been identified. Unlike the situation in New South Wales and the south-eastern forests, with those areas of Gippsland the Victorian Government has in the past couple of years identified some very large areas which have been reserved in national park and, therefore, thought the rest could be available for logging. Because it is on the National Estate and the Commonwealth has a duty to look at prudent and feasible alternatives where possible, I have asked Kay Setches to let me know whether there was any attempt to identify those alternatives and whether any were identified. I assume that the answer will come back that there were none possible, but I do not yet have an answer. I am promised to have the answer by tomorrow afternoon, so I can have a look at it then. I will undertake to inform Senator Haines on Monday of what Kay Setches has had to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the risk of appearing obsessional, I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to episode two of the comic opera farce known as the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Assembly. The Minister for Urban Services and Finance, Craig Duby, who was known in his previous incarnation as a No Self-Government candidate, says that it is desirable that the benighted burghers of Canberra should be saddled with two extra ministers. Other reformed No Self-Government candidates are now calling for a new parliament house to contain the inmates. For example, the Speaker of the Assembly, Mr Prowse, is quoted as saying that the Federal Government should pay for a new Parliament for the Australian Capital Territory. When asked what would happen if the Federal Government refused to pay, he said, `We will call them a few names, just like we have done before'. Will the Minister indicate his views about these sophisticated requests for extra funds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Australian Capital Territory Administration has shown its priorities very well in this area. Its priorities are more Ministers and a new home. I understand that, as Senator Aulich has said in his question, one No Self-Government candidate is now a Minister and one of the other No Self-Government candidates wants to become a Minister as well. I am not sure who the funding for the second suggested new ministerial position is intended for. As far as I am concerned they can whistle for it, and ditto for their new Parliament House.

ANSWER.PARA: On the more general financial background to the ACT, the process of aligning the ACT Budget with the States began three years ago. In that year the Commonwealth Grants Commission conducted an inquiry and concluded that a relative factor with the States for the Australian Capital Territory was 1.57, which implied overfunding relative to the States at that time of some $84m. The Grants Commission has not done another inquiry but it is the belief of the Department of Finance that, based on that same factor, the level of overfunding has now reached about $100m. Part of the reason for that widening, of course, was that the Australian Capital Territory was given a guarantee of maintenance of funding in real terms for the three years ending 1990-91. It may be questionable whether they should be given such a guarantee, but they were, and it still has 18 months to run. In the same period, the States had no such guarantee and there were significant reductions in Commonwealth funding to the States, as there should have been, given the economic circumstances.

The reason for that generosity-some might suggest excess generosity-was to give the Australian Capital Territory three years in which to get its financial house in order. There is little indication that that is happening, although there was some indication a while ago that it was. All minority governments, or all governments who have a minority in either House of a parliament, have trouble implementing a responsible fiscal policy, and the previous Australian Capital Territory Administration had some of those troubles. There is no indication whatsoever, that I am aware of, that the new Australian Capital Territory Administration will take advantage of that three years to get its fiscal house in order. Indeed, all the indications are that it will be doing the opposite.

The last point I make is that the Grants Commission is about to receive a reference on the Australian Capital Territory which will be the basis of determining a two-year transitional arrangement after the three-year funding guarantee expires in 18 months time. I do not expect that that review will suggest that the Commonwealth should fund the self-aggrandisement with which the present Australian Capital Territory Administration is so obsessed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. With the production of the guidelines for pulp mills now completed, can the Minister give the forest and forest products industries of Australia, and potential customers from around the world, an undertaking that the Government will abide by these guidelines, that companies complying with them can be assured of freedom from interference from both government and non-government sources and that agreements, once made, will be honoured?
—The answer to most of that question is yes, subject to the fact that the guidelines provide that there will be monitoring of the operations of pulp mills.

—I refer the Minister for Justice to recent media reports suggesting that an application will be made for the repatriation of James Savage to serve a sentence in Australia for the murder committed in the United States. I ask: Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government proposes to accede to such an application?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say categorically that I have ruled out any question of repatriation of James Savage to serve any sentence of imprisonment that might be imposed on him by the court in Florida. This man has been convicted of murder in the first degree, robbery with a deadly weapon, and sexual battery with great force and with a deadly weapon. He has been convicted of very serious crimes and if, indeed, he is spared the death sentence-and I know that all honourable senators would wish that that sentence not be imposed-then he will serve his term of imprisonment in Florida rather than in Australia. There is no capacity within the Australian legal system for the detention within Australia of a person convicted of a crime overseas. There is no customary international law and, indeed, no treaty, such as I believe the United States has entered into with some other countries, to enable this to occur.

ANSWER.PARA: Though slightly at a tangent, it needs to be said that, as far as Australians travelling abroad are concerned, it is the policy of this Government to try to make them as aware as possible of the fact that if they commit a serious crime, for example in South East Asia to do with drug trafficking, then they face very severe consequences in terms of the penal laws of those jurisdictions, perhaps facing the death sentence or certainly long terms of imprisonment, sometimes in very primitive conditions. A warning appears on the plastic cover of passports issued to Australians travelling abroad and I believe that it ought to be heeded and taken very seriously: there will be no occasion when an Australian is brought back to this country to serve time imposed in a jurisdiction abroad.

In relation to the Savage case, which has, of course, excited great emotions, it is quite well-known that the Australian Government decided to help provide witnesses at the sentencing stage of the trial in order to try to mitigate the sentence that might be imposed-namely, the death sentence. As recently as last week in the hall just outside this chamber the leaders of all the major political parties in Australia, the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Australian Democrats-indicated that their parties abhorred the death sentence and made representations to try to avert that penalty in appropriate cases when imposed abroad. To try to avert that sentence I provided funds to enable some persons to travel to Florida to be available to the defence counsel to help bring about a situation where a life sentence of imprisonment is imposed rather than the death sentence. For that reason it was very aggravating to me to see in an Australian Associated Press report a day ago the remarks made, when Mr Justice Hall Wootten was stopped from giving evidence in the case, by a Mr Chris Loorham, apparently a lawyer with the Aboriginal Legal Service in Victoria, who is in Florida. The report stated:
`The judge ruled that because Justice Wootten did not personally know Russell (Savage) his evidence should not go to the jury,' Mr Loorham said.
`The reason he had not met Russell was that he arrived here exhausted, suffering jet lag a couple of days ago and hasn't had a chance to meet him which he would have had to do at night at the jail'.
Mr Loorham said the Federal Government, especially Justice Minister Michael Tate, had been tardy in the matter, and had responded only at the last minute.

The application for funding for these witnesses was received on 23 November 1989. The application was approved on 24 November 1989-in other words, within the day. The United States attorneys were advised orally that day and a letter confirming the grant of funds was sent the next day. Far from being jet lagged, Mr Justice Wootten took two days to get from Australia to Florida, having two overnight stops along the way, and arrived in Florida six days before the hearing, so he was available for such consultations as might have been required. I totally reject the allegation made against me and refuse to be set up by Chris Loorham in order to be some sort of scapegoat in the event of a particular penalty being imposed on Mr Savage.

No Australian wants to see the death sentence imposed. On the other hand, this man has been convicted in a fair trial of most heinous crimes against a woman and I believe that in this situation whatever sentence is imposed by the court ought to be accepted and served in the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health seen the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1989 No. 330? Have these regulations been tabled? If not, is it the Government's intention that they should not be tabled until the last day of sitting, thus bringing about a situation in which, if the Senate wished to disallow them, it would be unable to do so until at least 20 February, presuming Parliament is recalled on that date? This would ensure that these regulations, which require the provision of information to the Department of Community Services and Health about the age and sex of various applicants and limit the dispensing of repeat prescriptions, will have been in effect for at least six weeks before they come to the Senate to determine their fate.

—I cannot confirm whether I have actually seen those regulations. I have seen some pharmaceutical regulations but I cannot recall whether they had the same number the honourable senator has indicated in her question.
—You probably can't remember whether they were on recycled paper.

—They were not on recycled paper, as I recall; they were on ordinary paper. I propose to take Senator Patterson's question on notice and inquire of the Minister for Community Services and Health about the detail. I will provide her with an answer early next week.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Why was it necessary for me to go to the Australian Government Publishing Service today to purchase this document for 50c rather than having it available to me in the Parliament? I seek leave to table the document.

—To answer Senator Patterson's question, it is probably because she is a foolish person and wanted to spend her money to make a political point rather than wait for the Government to table the document.

—Has the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories seen the article in the Australian last Monday, 11 December, by Jeff Wells disparaging the good work being done for women in sport? Will the Minister comment on the level of sporting journalism as featured by Jeff Wells? What has this Government done to show that it is more serious about women's sport than Jeff Wells obviously is?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read the article on the back page of the Australian on Monday. I think it was an attempt by a sporting journalist to inject humour into the debate. The difficulty with that kind of macho humour that denigrates women is that it is not all that clever and, in my mind, is not all that funny. I should tell honourable senators fortunate enough to have missed the article that Mr Wells made the following statements:

ANSWER.PARA: And vigoro? Well, the name says everything-I mean if you were a good Catholic would you let your daughter get involved in something called vigoro?
I think there are plenty of good Catholics who have. He also said:

And heaven knows what goes on in synchronised swimming. You see these females disappear to the bottom of the pool together and there is all manner of thrashing about and then they pop out of the water with some very strange looks on their faces.

I could refer Mr Wells and his colleagues to an establishment a few yards away from the News Ltd offices. It is a pub called the Evening Star. I have seen quite a number of Mr Wells's colleagues go in there, disappear for a number of hours, go under and come out with very strange looks on their faces indeed. On the basis of what Mr Wells has had to say I wonder whether an effort to disguise the word `lesbianism', while printing the word `shirtlifter' in full, can be applied to the activities that go on in the Evening Star.

Mr Wells's suggestion that men face the same problems as women in regard to lack of participation in sport is nonsense. It is well documented that Australia has a major and growing problem with adolescent girls dropping out of sport from the age of 13 on. As a Government and as a nation we must address that. To that end we began the women's sport promotion unit. We have enormously increased that body's funds. A few months ago I announced the next step for Australian sport, which included a massive increase in funds for the Aussie sports program, which allows adolescent girls the opportunity to play sports they could not have played under the old regime. As an adjunct to that there is a youth sports program which particularly targets young girls from 13 up. Mr Wells aside, I think most Australians accept the fact that there is a need to do more in that area, and we are doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to the Auditor-General's report on the administration of Austudy which reveals significant levels of fraud, overpayment and inadequate administration, problems which the Opposition has been drawing attention to for some time. Does the Minister acknowledge that between 12 and 27 per cent of assisted students were overpaid in 1988, on average by of the order of $1,100, and that, in the Auditor-General's words, in tertiary allowances alone, potential overpayments of at least $4m per annum are indicated? What specific steps is the Government now taking to reform the administration of Austudy by the Department of Employment, Education and Training? Will there be any reallocation of resources within the Department to facilitate such changes? Will the Department of Finance have any supervisory role over this process? Finally, will the Government now adopt the whole of the 5-point plan to reform Austudy which the Opposition published earlier in the year and reiterated in the Economic Action Plan in October and which is estimated to save the Commonwealth $30m?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that the Opposition put forward five proposals to minimise or eliminate overpayments and fraud in this area. All of those proposals are in operation already, including the production of the audit report itself. The Government has placed a high priority on the elimination-reduction, I suppose, is a more realistic objective-of fraud and overpayment, not only in Austudy payments but in benefits generally. Substantial improvements in recovery action within Austudy are expected this financial year, with the developments which are currently under way to improve systems and procedures. It is probably true-indeed, I would say almost certainly true-that all sorts of administrative actions in the Department of Education have been hampered by union obstructionism over at least the last two years. I understand that something has been done about that.

ANSWER.PARA: The five proposals that have been put up by the Opposition, as I have said, are already in operation. I am pleased to see that the Opposition is taking an interest in this area, but every time the Government proposes a more effective mechanism for the detection and reduction of fraud and overpayment in general, the Opposition knocks the measure over. It opposed the tax file number. Opposition members all hold up their hands and cry `Shock! Horror! There is fraud and overpayment', and then oppose every measure that will be a cost-effective way of dealing with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw to the Minister's attention-this is quite contrary to his final remark, which was self-serving at the least-that this week the Opposition supported the amendments to the Austudy legislation in order to deliberately extend fraud and overpayment regulations to the unlegislated schemes. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of that and of the fact that the Government, by adopting the measures the Opposition has been putting forward for some months now, is beginning to catch up with the Opposition in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already said that I am very pleased that the Opposition is taking some interest in this matter. Let me tell Senator Teague that in 1981, as an economy measure, the last coalition Government abolished the requirement for people to report fortnightly in person to Social Security officers before they could collect unemployment benefits.
—Who was the Minister?

—It was Senator Chaney, if I remember correctly. Steadily, over a period of years, the ratio of people in receipt of unemployment benefits to people shown by the Australian Bureau of Statistics surveys as looking for full time employment blew out from 98 : 100 to 125 : 100. The cost of that was in the order of $600m to $700m, at present levels of unemployment. This Government took action against that and reversed the stupid decision made, on false economy grounds, by the coalition Government in 1981. We put a number of other measures in place and the ratio has come back to where it was before then.

ANSWER.PARA: So Senator Teague should not try to lecture me or this Government about taking effective action-or as effective as we are able to take, given the constraints that are imposed on fiscal responsibility by the Senate. He should not lecture me about the Government being in any way tardy in this respect. But I am pleased to see that he and the Liberal Party have finally taken an interest in this matter. I assume that they would not do again anything as stupid-if they ever got back into government-as they did in 1981 and, perhaps, it is a more forlorn hope, that some time they might start to change some of their antediluvian ideas and think about some really effective means of eliminating fraud and overpayment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I refer to the Minister's attendance at the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council meeting. I ask the Minister whether he can advise the Senate on what the industry's performance is in relation to exports, productivity and industrial relations. Further, has the company Robe River Iron Associates been a participant in the Consultative Council process? If not, is it considered by the industry to be a member of the Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the question is about the performance of the iron ore industry. The performance of the iron ore industry has been outstanding. For the first time ever, the Pilbara will export in excess of 100 million tonnes of iron ore. That is a record. It is up from 96 million tonnes last year, with a total value of in excess of $1.8 billion to the Australian economy. For the first time as well, for the first half of this Japanese financial year the Pilbara will claim 50 per cent of the Japanese market. That is a record and one hopes that it can be maintained. As well as that significant penetration with our major customer, the iron ore industry now has other customer countries, which constitute 53 per cent of its trade. Therefore, the emphasis on the Japanese market has been decreased. We have spread our trade across the north Pacific and Europe and have a much more balanced trading environment because of that.

ANSWER.PARA: Productivity per head has increased from 1984 by 32 per cent until today's date over the whole of the industry, representing a 23 per cent per hour increase per employee in tonnes shipped over that same period. So there has been a dramatic increase in productivity. The number of industrial disputes has decreased dramatically. We are now looking at concluding this calendar year with a record low in terms of industrial disputation in the Pilbara.

There is something about the Australian culture which focuses, in industrial relations, on the dispute index when often the most time lost on major projects is due to accidents. If we look at the accident and safety index we find that there has been, from the first days in which the Consultative Council was constituted until now, a steep ramping down of work days lost due to industrial accidents. Indeed, this year to the end of November there has been, compared to the end of November last year, a 32 per cent reduction in time lost through industrial accidents. The industrial accidents index is down right across all the indicators: the number of accidents, the time lost in all occupational groups and all types of injury. We had a 15 per cent price increase last year, with the bigger volumes, and this year we are expecting a price increase of very significant proportions, too. So, according to all the indicators, the industry has been performing extremely well.

Senator McKiernan asked me about Robe River Iron Associates. Robe River has chosen voluntarily not to attend, as a company, the Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council in the last three years and be part of this general consultative approach to obtain greater efficiencies. Therefore, the Consultative Council does not consider Robe River as a member of the Consultative Council, active or passive. I am absolutely disgusted by that company's nineteenth century view of industrial relations, which is legend in the Pilbara. It took the form, just in the last week, of trying to deny unions, which under their own independent banner are signatories of the Consultative Council's charter, from having representatives attend the Consultative Council. Robe River informed the unions that representatives could go to the Consultative Council meeting if they sought leave. The shop stewards applied for leave and were told that it would not be granted unless they took their annual leave. When they applied for annual leave to attend the Consultative Council meeting they were told that it would not be granted unless they took it in five-day blocks. When they applied for a five-day block of annual leave to attend the Consultative Council meeting, they were told that it would not be granted because they had not given a month's notice. In the first instance, all they sought was leave without pay in order to be part of this consultative process that has obtained these types of results.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. I refer to press statements in respect of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill-the CELA Bill-which took effect on 1 July and which imposes heavy penalties for errors in documentation of customs clearances. Those releases indicate that only 219 penalty notices have been issued against a total of 604,000 entries lodged. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that these 219 notices are the result of a random audit of some of the 604,000 entries lodged and not an audit of every entry? Is it a fact that no field audits have been performed despite assurances, when this legislation was introduced, that the new system would free Customs officers for field audits?
—I do not have an answer to that question at the moment. I will obtain one for Senator MacGibbon.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If there is an absence of field audits, what tolerance will the Government show to Customs agents or importers who keep repeating an innocent mistake and thereby multiplying their liability under the Act?
—Senator Button, do you have any further answer?
—I have nothing further to add.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Has the Minister decided not to consider any further requests by the HMAS Sydney and Vietnam Logistical Support Veterans Association for recognition of service in the Vietnam war by awarding its members the Australian Vietnam Medal; if so, why? Has the Minister decided no longer to consider similar claims from the British Commonwealth Occupation Forces Association for recognition of service of its members in Japan and of the Wartime Merchant Seamen's claims for recognition of those merchant seamen who manned the Australian National Line ships Boonaroo and Jeparit on voyages to Vietnam; if so, why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall endeavour to find out the answer to those questions as soon as I can and let Senator McLean know.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the article written by Dr Herb Feith in the Age on Thursday, 7 December, entitled `Time is right for peace in East Timor'? Does the Minister agree with the author's suggestion that there are signs that the war in East Timor could be wound down in a relatively short period if more outside states and international organisations were willing to play more constructive roles? What does the Minister feel about the proposal for creating a kind of special territory or autonomous region status for East Timor? Does the Minister agree that this proposal constitutes a possible way out of what hitherto seemed an impasse? Finally, would the Australian Government be prepared to play the kind of role suggested by Dr Feith at the end of his article and would the Minister be prepared to instruct Australian officials to refrain from describing East Timor's situation in ways that deny the central reality that there is a war going on there?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read the article but fortunately the person who has written the answer has. My colleague Senator Gareth Evans was informed of the article by Herb Feith concerning East Timor prior to its publication in the Age on 7 December. In correspondence with Dr Feith, the Minister indicated that he shared a strong concern about the manner of annexation of East Timor by Indonesia. The Government recognises Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor. This was enunciated clearly by the Prime Minister in his statement to Parliament on 24 August 1985. Such recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor means that the Government would only support the proposal for creating a kind of special territory or autonomous region status for East Timor if it were accepted by the Indonesian Government. The Prime Minister made it clear at that time that recognition of Indonesian sovereignty had permitted us to pursue human right and aid issues in that province.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government gives its full support to international efforts, particularly those of the United Nations Secretary-General, to assist Portugal and Indonesia to achieve agreement on East Timor, taking into account the interests of all parties involved. Australia is not a party to those negotiations. We would, of course, be prepared to assist in any way that we can, provided we are invited to do so by both major parties. Whether other outside states and international organisations may contribute to the winding down of the war is a matter for them.

The Australian Government has consistently supported the efforts of international organisations such as the International Committee of the Red Cross and the United Nations Children's Fund, to assist and improve the welfare of the people of East Timor. The Government would not dispute that deaths and casualties still occur as a result of conflict in the province nor that there are human rights violations there. It remains the Government's firm view that the only practical way to assist the people of East Timor, including on human rights issues, is by working through the Indonesian authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to remarks that he made on a recent Canberra radio program when he said that the Government could have been more astute in its handling of the pilots dispute and that the Government's tactics could have been better planned. Does the Minister support the stand taken by the Prime Minister and his involvement in the dispute, or is the Minister suggesting that compensation for the airlines was ill-considered and hasty, as was the use of the military? What other actions does the Minister believe the Government could have taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not within my portfolio to answer questions in the Senate on the pilots dispute. I do not propose to answer them now.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I take that answer from the Minister to mean that he believes that the tourist industry has not suffered at all from the pilots dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a separate question. Quite obviously, the tourist industry has suffered. That is why the Government, in conjunction with the tourist industry in Australia, has announced the very large package to try to recover the lost ground that we have suffered. That lost ground over the course of this year is not due entirely to the pilots strike. Prior to the strike there had been a dropping off in tourist numbers which had been apparent for some months. Coming off the high of an Expo 88 year and a bicentennial year, some drop-off was to be expected. But it is a worry that the numbers have gone down as far as they have. That is why there is a package in excess of $30m to sort it out.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he saw an article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald entitled `Savings plans: the hidden costs'. Is the Minister concerned that excessive front-end fees on savings plans and personal superannuation plans of the type discussed in the article are acting as a deterrent to the increased saving which Australia needs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article that was published on page 29 of yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald. It cites two cases. Firstly, a Ms Jacona, who signed up for a savings plan through the Women's Investment network, saved $4,000 over four years and at the end of the four years had $2,600 to show for it. In other words, a dissaving of $1,400, even without taking into account the time value of the money. The second one was a Ms Stokes who signed up for a personal superannuation plan with Friends' Provident into which she paid $125 a month for two years, which totals about $3,000. She has $106.50 to show for it-a dissaving of nearly $3,400 in that case.
—Is that the same as a loss?

—Yes, perhaps I should have just said a loss. One does get a bit hooked on the jargon sometimes. In each case the basic problems were those of high commissions being paid to the savings plans sales people and high upfront fees. The article goes on to argue that high front-end fees were charged in such a way as to be effectively disguised. I make no comment on whether they were effectively disguised-I just do not know. There can be no doubt that when this sort of thing happens-whether or not the up-front fees are effectively disguised-once people find out about it it will be a deterrent, not an incentive, to saving.

ANSWER.PARA: It is worth quoting the opening paragraph of the article. The article was written by Anne Lampe, and I suggest to any people who are listening to the Senate broadcast that they read it. It is in the Sydney Morning Herald, dated 13 December 1989, at page 29, and states:
Savings plans sold by life insurance companies and their agents without adequate disclosure of all the fees and charges usually come back to haunt the company which backs the plan.
It is perhaps worth quoting the final paragraph of the article as well. It states:
Companies which don't charge excessive front-end fees on savings plans include the GIO of NSW, Westpac Life, ANZ Life and Oceanic Life.

That is probably not an exhaustive list, but just an example. I am not suggesting that every company not named on it is guilty of-shall we say-shady practices. I will refer the article to the Treasurer and see whether he can do anything about it. The final point I want to make as far as national savings are concerned is that there is no doubt these were losses to the individuals concerned, and might well have been losses to national savings as well if the people who received the front-end fees and the high commissions blew them all on an overseas trip and another Porsche.

During the debate on the matter of public interest I mentioned some aspects of the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation, particularly the failure of that report to indicate, among its priorities, any emphasis on trying to provide refunds within a reasonable time. I now want to draw the attention of the Senate to that section of the annual report which deals with the role of the Commissioner of Taxation.

As the Senate will be aware, the Opposition has been concerned at times about the role of the Commissioner, particularly his intervention in what the Opposition sees to be political debates on policy areas of taxation, not on the administration of the Australian Taxation Office. In particular, the Opposition is concerned about the appearance of advertisements in newspapers, which clearly seem to be of a political nature, over the names of the Commissioner or the Taxation Office. This is an unfortunate trend which has prompted responses of a political nature from the Opposition which the Commissioner may well feel are inappropriate. There is no doubt in the minds of members of the Opposition that the inappropriate nature of the activities emerges from the Commissioner's involvement in creating and debating policy matters-and controversial policy matters, I might say-when he should be at arm's length and dealing with the administration of the Taxation Office. It is interesting to note in the annual report the Commissioner's own explanation of his role. It states:

While the Treasurer is answerable in Parliament for the Tax laws, the clear intent of the general administration and secrecy powers is that the day-to-day running of the Tax Office, and decisions about tax liability, are for the statutory office-holder and not the political head, or anyone else for that matter. In other words, the Tax Commissioner is given independence (subject always to the law and the courts) and he is in a different and stronger position than the Secretary of a Department of State. He has a clear custodial role in relation to the tax system established by the laws he administers.
The report continues:

The duty of the Tax Office, which the Commissioner of Taxation heads, is to administer those laws, the aim being to collect the correct amount of tax that is payable under the law, no more and no less.

I want to stress the words `no more', because that is the very concern of the Opposition-it appears, from the Commissioner's intervention in policy areas, that he is going beyond the bounds of the constraints he sets upon himself in this annual report. The matters the Opposition is concerned about of a policy nature-defending the Government's policy decisions, outlining the `benefits' to the public of the Commissioner doing various things-appear to go far beyond this `no more and no less' proposition which the Commissioner has stated in this annual report. It is only right that the Opposition points out when these interventions take place.

I want to stress that no vestige of criticism can be made by the Opposition about the proposition that the administration of the tax laws is entirely up to the Commissioner. Whether he makes misjudgments in that administration is, of course, a matter which is properly capable of being discussed. Many people take the view that the highly publicised raids that the Commissioner has introduced in some areas are open to debate. One wonders whether some of those raids are for the purpose of putting other taxpayers in terrorem, fear, rather than getting a good result from that particular raid. There are those people who think that the end justifies the means, and whacko if a dilatory taxpayer is terrorised into coming clean-fair enough. I have some real problems with the manner in which some of these matters have been handled by the Commissioner.

Given that the Senate will be debating the Australian Heritage Commission Amendment Bill 1989 during this session of parliament, I think it is timely that the annual report precedes that debate. Let me preface my comments by stating that I concur with the Australian Heritage Commission's raison d'etre. The concept of the National Estate is a valid one. Just as I accept that the National Estate should be conserved, it is also acceptable to me that conservation is essentially about better management. It is the matter of conservation of the National Estate which I wish to address. The Chairman, Mr P. J. Galvin, in the opening pages of the report, said:
The year . . . has been, in many respects, one of taking stock and preparation for the future.

Although some of this self-examination began early in 1988, it gained momentum following the Government's decision to strengthen the role of the Commonwealth in the conservation of the National Estate.

Under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, the Commission's aims are, first, the preparation and maintenance of the Register of National Estate places; secondly, the provision of advice to the relevant Minister and to other Ministers and government authorities on government proposals which may affect the national Estate and on other matters relating to the National Estate; and, thirdly, the development of policies and programs for research, professional training and public information and education.

Without wishing to pre-empt the forthcoming Australian Heritage Commission Amendment Bill, I believe that the above aims will remain unchanged-I hope they will-as a result of the amendments. Given the above aims, as I interpret them-and as I take it they are meant to be interpreted-it was interesting to read the Chairman's interpretation. I quote:
Legislation sets out the Commission's principal tasks of maintaining and developing the Register of the National Estate and advising the Government on the-
this is the interesting word-
protection of our national heritage.

It is the regular use of the word `protection' nowadays, rather than reference to the `conservation' or `maintenance' of National Estate values, which I find particularly disturbing. I believe it is not in keeping with the legislated purpose of the Australian Heritage Commission. The protection-preservation attitude to the National Estate comes through particularly in Chapter 3.2 of the report entitled `The present condition of the National Estate'. It states:
Mining, manufacturing, agriculture, forestry, tourism and massive redevelopment in central business districts continue to place under threat parts of Australia's natural heritage.

Under the heading `Forestry issues' in this chapter the comments on clearfelling and pulp mill developments read like something from a Wilderness Society brochure. The Heritage Commission knows that no logging takes place in areas listed on the National Estate Register or interim list without its having input in the form of advice to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin).

The Commission should also be aware that there are many areas where logging is conducive and essential to maintaining the National Estate values for which an area has been listed. In support of my statement, I instance the Ben Nevis Foothills listing for which the statement of significance says that the area supports one of the best remaining populations of the rare endemic plant acacia pataczeckii. Under the heading `Condition' we are told, `Good, this has been selectively logged in the past'. Thus selective logging is conducive to the good condition of an endemic species, possibly preventing it from extinction.

Rather than adhere to a protection-preservation attitude, the Australian Heritage Commission should practise the view expressed recently in a letter to the editor by Gerard Early, the Acting Director of the Australian Heritage Commission. In that letter, he said:
Listing of a place-
on the National Estate register-

does . . . alert the Federal Government to the special values of that area, when Federal Government ministers and authorities are making decisions which may affect it. In this way heritage values can be considered alongside other values-land use, economic, employment and so on.
I think it is important that we get our terminology right and that we understand what we are doing under the heading of preservation of the National Estate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
