It is regrettable that there is such a short time to address these agreements because one of them at least finally lays bare the absurd situation that this Government's misplaced enthusiasm for a military alliance with the United States of America has got us into. The agreement on communications, which is treaty No. 16, is essentially a machinery measure designed to update and upgrade Australia's military linkages to the United States (US) and to keep information from the public. It is no new departure.

Treaty No. 17 concerns the defence communications service and there is an agreement between the United States and Australian governments; yet in Article 1, section 3a it refers to the involvement of the New Zealand Ministry of Defence, which is pending. It is concerned with the United States-New Zealand responsibilities for the Simpson system and obviously requires bilateral talks between those two governments. I mention it to highlight the fact that post-ANZUS not a lot has changed for the New Zealanders. They are officially left out of the annual talks as a face-saver to the United States to prove that their relationship is now that of friend rather than ally. Yet when it comes down to the nitty-gritty-that is, the exchange of so-called military intelligence, which has often been called a contradiction in terms-the United States still extracts its pound of flesh and the New Zealand Government still acquiesces. It is business as usual. It is a continuation of the mostly one-way flow of information from both Australia and New Zealand to assist the United States military strategists.

The Simpson system involves the New Zealand defence communications network which is linked to allied military communications networks through Australia and the United States of America. This system provides secure telegraph and data communication channels for the exchange of narrative record traffic. In concert with a planned upgrade of the Simpson communications system and a US legislative requirement for formalised agreements, a draft United States-New Zealand agreement is currently under review by the United States Department of Defense. This agreement is similar to the Australian-United States agreement which I understand was signed in November 1989. It is anticipated that the New Zealand-United States agreement will be signed early in 1990.

The agreement on logistic support is another matter. I need to remind the Senate of the words of the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, in March 1987-words which were also in the speech of the present Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) when he tabled the Defence White Paper in the Senate. Mr Beazley said:

A particular aspect of our relationship with the United States that assures our capacity for self-defence is our guaranteed access to ready resupply of essential warstocks. Emergency warstocks of equipment and munitions would be prohibitively expensive to maintain ourselves. However our needs could be relatively easily met from US stocks.

So the Government in 1987 came into the Parliament and spoke about our guaranteed access to supplies of American war material should this be required. But what do we find with respect to the agreement before us today? I refer honourable senators to the explanatory press release issued by the Minister for Defence on 4 November which says with uncharacteristic honesty:

The Agreement provides that neither Australia nor the US would necessarily be committed to militarily supporting one another's forces in contingency situations, should it be against their respective national interests.

What has happened to the `guaranteed access to ready resupply' that Minister Beazley spoke of in 1987? Critics of the American alliance have never believed in it anyway. Now we find that the Government has finally had to admit that its critics were right.

This agreement is a sham. It is a farce. It is an example of the politics of the warm inner glow. It must make the Government, its conservative friends in the Opposition and the Americans feel good to sign an agreement like this, but nobody can stand up in this place today and truthfully say that we have any guarantee of resupply by the United States. It will supply us if-and only if-it suits it. This is why the Government and its fellow conservatives in the Opposition strive to outdo each other in protestations of loyalty and support for the alliance. That great greenie and environmentalist, Senator Richardson, says in the Senate that he welcomes United States nuclear warship visits and can hardly wait to get aboard. We have to grovel-he has to grovel-to keep the Americans on side.

We should, however, welcome the tabling of this agreement because it reveals the complete bankruptcy of the promilitary alliance policies of the conservative Government and the conservative Opposition. As cold war alliance edifices crumble all over the world, we find Australia locking itself ever more closely into an obsolete alliance. But as this agreement shows clearly, the alliance, even in its own terms, is not worth the paper on which it is printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 December, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Department of Primary Industries and Energy on its annual report and on its endeavours to encourage the growth of an adaptable and efficient primary industries and energy sector. I note that on page 1 of the report that the Department, which was established in 1987, states:

SPEECH.PARA: These industries, which represents about 80 per cent of Australia's merchandise exports, have a significant role to play in meeting two important national challenges. These are the Current Account deficit (and related foreign debt level) and the management of our natural resources to provide for ecologically sustainable long-term development.

As honourable senators would know, I represent a State which is very proud of its place in helping Australia to meet its economic challenges. Queensland is a very decentralised State. It is at least 1,500 miles in length and 1,000 miles in breadth. Over the years I have made many trips throughout the State and I realise the value of primary industries and the tremendous contribution they make to the economy. However, it saddens me that too often people, especially many in government, fail to realise the tremendous cost for rural industries in trying to meet the challenge of giving Australia a buoyant economy.

This Government chooses to penalise those who work in our primary industries and, sometimes I think deliberately, fails to recognise not only the physical hardship of working in that environment but also the tremendous financial burden being placed on the shoulders of the man on the land. It is all very well to have the land and the seed to grow the crops or to allow the livestock to graze, but often it is forgotten that to get the end product, to make ends meet, the man on the land has to rely on things over which he has no control. First he hopes for rain to allow the crops to grow. He hopes that there will be good markets and prices for his goods, that interest rates will not cripple him, that fuel prices will not be prohibitive, and that the roads on which he has to transport those goods will be passable. After farmers plant the seed and wait for rain, they have to clean up the crop for weeds and spray for bugs. Finally, if they get a crop to harvest, they either look at using large machinery, which costs an enormous amount of money to buy, or at employing workers to come in and help with the harvesting. This is where many expenses are incurred on the land.

It is often when assessing the rural industries that we talk only in terms of how much they have contributed to Australia's export growth and not in terms of the effort made to achieve those exports. I note on page 21 of the report that one of the objectives of the Livestock and Pastoral Division is:

To foster the development of efficient, low cost, internationally competitive, innovative and adaptable livestock and pastoral industries and so further enhance their contribution to the Australian economy.

Some of the industries which the livestock and pastoral section deals with include wool and goat fibres, beef and veal, sheep meat, pig meat, chicken meat, livestock exports, dairy products, honey and eggs. These industries had a gross value of production in 1988-89 of about $13 billion and earned $9 billion in export revenue. But it is here I would like to point out that in the goal to achieve these low cost internationally competitive industries the Government has to be aware that it could be killing the goose that laid the golden egg. I am referring not only to some of the major public controversies that the Department was involved in last year but also to many of the minor actions that the Department and the Government have taken which have had adverse effects on the man on the land. Some of these controversies include the divisive stance taken on wheat marketing reform, the removal of the sugar import embargo, the reform of wool research and development arrangements, the implementation of quotas to conserve gemfish resources and the delineation of boundaries for world heritage nominations. If in the process of achieving cost efficient industries we push the small family farmer off the land, in the long run we are serving no really good purpose for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also congratulate the Department of Primary Industries and Energy on its annual report. The report refers to the new Wheat Marketing Act, and there are concerns about how it will work out in the short term. My concern-and this was never expressed by the proponents of the change to the wheat marketing system when the matter was being discussed six months ago-is that although we have always been told that the Australian Wheat Board will continue to pool the wheat instead of the wheat being sold to private buyers, nothing has been mentioned about how the pooling system will operate. We were not told that the pool would not necessarily last for 12 months. Previously, we had one pool for one year running from 1 November to 31 October the following year. Everyone in that pool got the benefits or disbenefits, if I could use that term, of what might have happened during the year. Even though we were told that the Wheat Board would remain working as it has been working, I have been told in the last few weeks that under this system the pool could last a very short time.

SPEECH.PARA: This could be rather discriminatory around Australia. A pool may start when Queensland starts its wheat harvest. Then harvesting moves to northern New South Wales and then goes to mid-New South Wales. Then the harvest starts in the north of Western Australia, with the eastern parts of Western Australia next and the more northern parts of South Australia. That is when the best world wheat prices are available-when the northern hemisphere harvest starts to be exhausted. At that point the new northern hemisphere crop is growing and we get a better idea of what is there. Generally, come the end of December and early January, the world wheat price is slightly depressed. That would quite legally let the Australian Wheat Board cut the pool off at that point and create a second pool which would not be able to get the advantages of the earlier prices. Mr Kerin certainly did not tell us that that would happen when he successfully sold the new wheat marketing system.

In the brief time I have left, I want to mention another fear-it is not mentioned in the report-that has come out in the last few days. Senator Richardson, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, has mentioned once again what he wants to do with marginal land. Some of the marginal wheat lands around Australia are the most important producers of wheat exports. This would be the third time--

TALK.START.PARA: —Marginal because of that crank Charlie Court.

—We are in a marginal area and we have made a great success of it, even though I say so myself. The point is that it is highly productive country which has now been placed slightly in jeopardy by what this Minister keeps saying. I wish that he would tell us what his exact agenda is. At that point, I seek leave to continue my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for consideration of Government papers has expired.

—by leave-I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) whether we can feel confident that tomorrow the list of papers to come up for discussion will bear some relationship to the order in which they are to be presented to the chamber.
—There is one problem with that question, Senator Baume: tomorrow is Friday and we are not sitting.
—The next day of sitting.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will look into that and try to facilitate an answer which will be pleasing to the honourable senator.
—I seek leave of the Senate to address No. 83 on the papers list, to speak to it for five minutes, and to seek leave on behalf of Senator Vallentine and Senator McLean to also address this matter.
—The time for consideration of Government papers has expired. You are seeking leave to speak to a paper in extra time? Is leave granted?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to my contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Dunn moving a motion relating to the conduct of business of the Senate, namely, a motion to provide for the consideration of General Business order of the day No. 83 relating to Government papers, being the Government response to the Foreign Affairs Committee report on visits by nuclear powered vessels.

As I understand it, when the Government responds to a committee report it is not usually buried in the papers of the day and there is some obligation on the Government to table its reports. This has clearly not been done in the present instance. Clearly, it is a matter of some concern to the Australian population. This is a report which was prepared over a period of nearly three years. It has cost the Australian taxpayer thousands and thousands of dollars. Over 102 submissions were received by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Quite clearly, it is a matter of some concern to the Australian public, particularly because it concerns their safety.

It seems to me that it is urgent that this motion come on because both the Committee and the Government have stressed the importance of informing the Australian public about the safety arrangements, particularly about the importance of making safety plans public. This forms a considerable part of the Government response to the Committee's report. Indeed, it is a major part of the Committee's report. That is why I think we cannot afford to let this be buried right at the end of the papers, at No. 83, where it apparently does not belong in any case. It should have been tabled separately, and I am sure that my fellow committee members, including you, Mr Deputy President, would have wanted an opportunity to comment on the Government's response. There are other senators, of course, in this place who would have liked an opportunity to comment on it. Given that we rise next week for the session, I do not think we can afford to put off the results of this major report any longer, considering the amount of time, effort and money that was put into the Committee's deliberations, in which you, Mr Deputy President, took such a major part.

It is urgent that the motion come on also because the Government cannot be taken seriously when it buries its response to the Committee's report right at the bottom of the papers list. I feel sure that this was probably deliberate. The Government is fully aware of the controversial nature of this report. It generated much debate at the time. There have been many media responses to the report. Indeed, all the public opinion polls show that there is a great interest in the community about the subject of the report, which I am not going to mention here today. However, the title of the report, which shows that it is a report by the Committee into contingency planning for the visits of nuclear armed and nuclear powered war ships to Australian ports, indicate something fundamental, not only about the safety of the Australian population and the degree of preparedness--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Dunn has been speaking for five minutes uninterrupted as to why Standing Orders should be suspended. She is now debating the issue. She should not be allowed to do that. We have been through this stunt with Senator Dunn several times recently, and it is a stunt again. We will see that we stick to the Standing Orders.

—Order! It is always a very narrow line for a senator to draw when giving reasons why the Standing Orders should be suspended without trespassing on debating the issue. So far, I think, Senator Dunn is doing it fairly skilfully, but she is very close to the line. I will draw it to her attention if she goes over it at all.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. To talk about quite a different subject, I remind the Senate of the disgraceful episode of the Nurrungar debate where a very similar--
—Order! That is out of order, Senator Dunn. You must stick to the reasons why Standing Orders should be suspended for the particular purpose you wish them to be suspended.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I believe that it is urgent that this motion come on because we do not want this same stunt by the Government and the Opposition pulled again. These matters must be debated fully and openly in this country. The last time this sort of episode occurred in the Senate, it was a disgraceful episode.
—Order! Senator Dunn, you are now, again, trespassing. You must stick to the particular reasons why the Standing Orders should be suspended for this purpose.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I shall do so. It is urgent that this motion come on because the Senate Committee has endeavoured consciously to prepare its report, and I believe that the Senate is being treated shabbily by the Government in its attempt to bury the report as No. 83 out of a total of 88 papers that have been presented. It is not the right place for this report and the Government's response to the report to appear. It is clear that the Government is trying to avoid a debate on it and I can only wonder why that might be the case. Maybe it has something to do with the contents of the Government's response.
—Order! Senator Dunn is again getting wide of the point. She should stick to why Standing Orders should be suspended now.
—Giggle on, Senator Dunn! It's good fun at the expense of the taxpayer. There is some decent legislation to be got on with, for once.

—Perhaps the Government ought not to have buried the report and given us an opportunity to debate this response by the Government. I stress that the other members of the Committee, which was a bipartisan committee, had a great deal of interest in the matter. It was one of the most hardworking committees of the Senate during the year. We met to receive many submissions. The report is very long, about 500 pages in all. One hundred and two submissions were received from the Australian community.
—Order! That is not relevant to why Standing Orders should be suspended now. Senator Dunn is discussing the nature of the report.

—I would like to stress that the other members of the Committee who are obviously also members of the Senate should be entitled, as members of the Senate and the Committee, to have a say on the subject of the report. After all, their work was essential--

—I have a point of order, Mr Deputy President. This is no more than a stunt or a device to jump the queue. The processes of the Standing Orders with respect to papers are set out quite clearly. We are proceeding fairly quickly. There will be an opportunity for the honourable senator and others to speak next week. Honourable senators on both sides of the chamber wish to make an important contribution. A number are not here today and it would be most unfortunate if the honourable senator were allowed to proceed.

—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Dunn has a contingent notice which she is entitled to move. But, as I have said several times, she must stick to the reasons why Standing Orders should be suspended.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I point out that because the paper is No. 83 on the list, it is highly unlikely that we will get to it before the end of this session. I stress that this is a very convenient way for the Government to avoid debate on this critical subject-much more so than many other papers on the list. We know that the Australian population is very interested in this subject and that the Government has avoided its responsibilities by burying this paper in this list. That is why I thought it important to move my motion to suspend Standing Orders in order to get at least some debate on the matter by those senators who are deeply concerned about the report. Senator Vallentine and Senator McLean also have electoral responsibilities. They have a responsibility to represent the views of those Australians who are, at the very least, concerned about the subject of the report and who have been following it very closely. There is also a responsibility to the media. We have the responsibility of ensuring that the debate gets out to the media, that there is a full debate--
—That's it! That's what it is all about, isn't it, Senator?
—It is. That is part of our parliamentary democratic system.
—Stunting!
—Order! Senator Dunn has the call.
—We don't control the order the papers come in and you know it!
—It shouldn't even be in the papers.
—Order! There are too many interjections and too much cross-talk. Senator Dunn has the call.

—I point out to Senator Ray, through you, Mr Deputy President, that had this paper not appeared in this list and had there been an opportunity for us to debate it, the matter would not have arisen now. Senator Button says that this is a stunt. It seems to me that it is a stunt by the Government to avoid discussion on it.
—I sat on the Committee.
—I am sure Senator Schacht would like an opportunity to address the subject of the report.
—Order! Senator Dunn should not reply to the interjections. She should just get on with the reasons why Standing Orders should be suspended.

—My worry is that if this debate is put off until next year, we may never get to it. As I understand it, papers that are not dealt with go to the bottom of the list for the next sitting week. So we could see an increasing number of papers overtake paper No. 83; there may be no debate about it in this chamber at all. This would not be the first time it has happened. Those of us who have responsibilities to people in the community who are concerned must bring these matters on for discussion. If that interferes with the legislation, which is not our intention, so be it. These are also legitimate matters for Independent senators and the Australian Democrats, who are concerned about them, to raise and make sure they get debated. We are fulfilling our electorate responsibilities, just as much as Senator Button or Senator Schacht. I am quite happy to leave the matter there and to pass the debate on to my fellow senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been many occasions on which people have been dissatisfied with the order in which papers are listed. Let me say this: the papers are listed in the order in which they come in and the Government does not interfere in their listing. The charge made by Senator Dunn thereof is totally false. Does Senator Dunn know what the decent senators do? They come to me and ask whether a particular paper can be moved up the list because they have a special interest in it. By leave, we do that. The stunters do not ask. Those who want to come in here and abuse the processes of the Senate cannot even pick up the phone or come to see me at Question Time or when I am available in this chamber and say, `Senator Ray, this is a critical issue. With the concurrence and leave of the Senate, can we please move it up the list?'. That is the first point I want to make in terms of whether this is urgent.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I want to make is that I moved a motion in this chamber that debarred debate on papers and private business for the last two weeks of this session. Senator Dunn voted for that, or at least she did not oppose it. However, when a lot of papers arrived at the last minute, I added, without hesitation, 4 1/2 hours to the time allotted for debate on papers in this chamber. Yesterday we moved a critical paper up the list and allotted one hour for discussion on it; Senator Dunn was given 10 minutes in which to speak. I am sick of hearing the whingeing about the rights of the two Independent senators and the others. We have rights too-the 32 senators on the Government side and the 34 senators on the Opposition side have some rights. We have the responsibility, however, to pass legislation in an orderly manner. Senator Dunn does not have that responsibility. She flips; she flops; off she goes. It might surprise Senator Dunn to know that one of the reasons this chamber exists is to pass legislation. We are not here only to listen to all sorts of comments. It is not as though she does not have her right of say. She speaks on the adjournment every night, boring everyone absolutely witless with her views. But we tolerate that; that is her safety valve. The adjournment provides an opportunity for the crackpots of the Parliament to come in and say what they like. I do not want to take this much further. We are already up to paper No. 49.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I have a point of order. I ask the Minister to withdraw the reference to crackpots. I note that he said `crackpots'; I do not know how widely he is applying that term. But this also reflects on those who vote for the so-called crackpots and I ask you to ask him to withdraw.
—Order! There is no point of order. The remark was made generally, not personally.
—Fortunately in this case, it refers to only one per cent of the New South Wales population.
—Order! The Minister has made his comment personal, in which case he will have to withdraw.

—Having made that point, I unreservedly withdraw the comment. We are already up to paper No. 49 out of 83, and 2 1/2 hours is to be set aside next week for papers to be discussed. If Senator Dunn cannot make her point succinctly then, or politely come up to Senator Lewis and me and suggest that paper No. 83 be put up the list, she should not be here because she is not practising the profession she was elected to serve, albeit in a substitute manner. This is just grandstanding and stunting and there are serious matters before the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sanders interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to Senator Sanders that we go through all these matters in the first few weeks, but it is time we passed some legislation. Barely 30 per cent of the time in the first few weeks of the sitting was spent on Government Business. Normally, 60 per cent of the time is spent on Government Business in the last couple of weeks. Senator Dunn has the option open to her not to use a contingent motion to suspend Standing Orders on this occasion. She could have resolved this in another way. There are only two alternatives: either Senator Dunn did this out of naivety, in which case her action is forgivable; or she is grandstanding and stunting. If that is the case, her action is not forgivable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be relatively brief in speaking to the contingency motion to suspend Standing Orders. The Australian Democrats support the motion because they object to the manner in which a government response to a major report was brought before the Senate. It is an acknowledged practice in this place that a government response to a report is given the same standing as the report itself. Therefore, it should have been tabled by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), thereby giving honourable senators the opportunity to speak for 30 minutes to the Government's response. I spoke very strongly and very aggressively about this significant report when it was tabled. Frankly, I resent not being given the opportunity by the Government-as responsible as it is supposed to be, as claimed by Senator Ray this afternoon-to speak--
—You'll get it next week.

—We will not get to it. We will get to it here, where I will be given five minutes, if I am lucky, to speak to a response which the Government is trying to bury. I object to this technique. Senator Ray and Senator Button have claimed that this is an abuse of procedure. I say that the placement of a response to a report amongst Government papers is an abuse of procedure. That is why we believe that it should now be debated. We object to the abuse of procedure by the Government. This is our first objection. It is not a paper; it is a response to a report and therefore has a different status.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing we object to is the allegation that this is a stunt. The placement of this response, hidden in this list of documents, is a stunt supreme. The stunt making has come from the Government and we are simply responding to it. As for the point that we are wasting the taxpayers' money this afternoon by taking 20 minutes of the Senate's time, I remind Senator Ray that this 500-page report about an absolutely critical aspect of Australian safety is also taxpayers' money. It is a major report. It was tabled in this Parliament and addressed as a major report. The Government has now responded to it and we cannot address its response in a serious way. The way that the Government has treated it is the waste of taxpayers' money. It is an offence to the people who took part in the process of formulating this report and the thousands of hours that went into its production that it is, by means of a stunt, being buried among these papers today.

The Government is calling upon us to cooperate with it in its processes. Seven Democrats cooperate with the Government day after day, week after week, month after month. We find it offensive that we are being accused this afternoon of being uncooperative because we are speaking in defence of the normal, legitimate and established procedures of the Senate. I speak very strongly in support of this contingency motion because this response should have the standing of a report and honourable senators should each have 30 minutes to address it, because it concerns the safety of Australians. We have argued that it is a flawed report in the first place, and we argue that the Government's response to it is equally flawed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support the contingency motion put forward by Senator Dunn. It is an affront to the Australian people, who are greatly concerned about this subject, to relegate this report to No. 83 in a list of 87, and, if it did come up before the end of the session, to allow honourable senators only five minutes each in which to address it. It is a very complex report of 500 pages with a substantial dissenting report. It deserves better attention than that. The people of Australia are very concerned about it.
—It is the Government's response.
—That is right, and I am very concerned about the Government's response as well, because it has been extremely confusing, to the extent--
—Order! Senator Vallentine, you must not discuss the Government's response. You are only debating a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. You must stick to the reasons why it is urgent.

—One of the reasons is that the leading article in this morning's West Australian was totally misleading. A reporter misunderstood the Government's response because it had not been adequately aired. That should not have happened. The Government's response to the report is very confusing indeed. It deserves a full and adequate explanation in this place and it deserves a full debate, in which honourable senators who are interested can each discuss it for half an hour.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very misleading document in the way it has been presented-even before it gets onto the agenda of the Senate. But it is very important to discuss it because of the misunderstanding and confusion that this report has caused in the community since it was tabled yesterday. It is very important that it be fully debated in this place before the Senate rises next week, otherwise it may never see the light of day next year. I think Senator Dunn is quite right when she says that it is so embarrassing for the Government that it does not want it fully debated. That does not give enough credibility to the people who worked on the report initially, to the many people who made submissions or to the many Australians who oppose the visits of the warships. They are waiting to see the Government's response and they want it to be adequately debated.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it has been tabled.

—It was tabled, but it has not been debated. It needs to be explained in this place. The House of Representatives is not sitting, so no Minister is able to explain it in that chamber. Therefore, we need to be able to explain it here. We need Government senators to explain this document. As I say, it has been severely misinterpreted. It needs a full explanation from the Government and it needs to be fully countered in this place.

—I will be very brief-and I am sure honourable senators will be grateful for that. I think the seriousness of this matter is manifest. The Government has tried to bury this paper. It should surface and it should be discussed. I think it is reprehensible that the Government does not wish to discuss it. I think that Senator Ray would agree that it would probably have been better to discuss it anyway rather than go through this acrimonious argument. I hope that the Government acts with more responsibility in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be supporting the motion to suspend Standing Orders. There is not the slightest doubt that the Government's response to this report should have been brought into the Senate as a ministerial statement to enable the Senate to debate it in that fashion. That has not been the case, but we have a series of arrangements concerning the conduct of business for these last sitting weeks of the parliamentary session which looks like having the Senate sitting later than ever before to get through government business. Those arrangements were agreed to some weeks ago and, as the Manager of Government Business, Senator Ray, has said, no opposition was raised to the conduct of business at that time. No provision was made or raised by anybody to allow for these sorts of contingencies.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not the first paper of this kind to come up. The pulp mills response was brought into the Senate yesterday. We regarded that as important and something that ought to be dealt with and not merely left amongst the papers of the day for each senator to discuss for five minutes if it were reached. We approached the Government and came to an amicable arrangement with the Manager of Government Business to enable that paper to be discussed. I suggest that those who think that this, or any other of the papers, is sufficiently important, should approach it on the same basis and reach an agreement that shares the time available to all senators. I do not agree that the Independent and Democrat senators do not receive a fair share of the time available in the Senate. I would say that the back bench senators of the Government, in particular, and of the Opposition receive far less time and far fewer opportunities to air their views because they work as a team and try to cooperate to see that the democratic process proceeds. We will not support the motion.
Question put.
That the motion (Senator Dunn's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, I present the Committee's annual report for 1987-88.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report deals with the operations of the Committee in 1987-88. Included in the report are statistical data and analytical discussion of the scrutiny it has undertaken during that period. This report, together with the regular reports and Alert Digests issued by the Committee, describe the parameters within which the Committee operates. A perusal of the three annual reports of the Committee, the paper entitled The Operation of the Australian Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills 1981-85, printed as Parliamentary Paper No. 317 of 1985, together with the regular reports and Alert Digests, will inform senators, Ministers and their advisers of how the Committee has applied the principles set out in its terms of reference.

SPEECH.PARA: I place on record my thanks to the senators who served on the Committee in 1987-88 for their high service. A legislative scrutiny committee depends to a large extent on the input of its legal adviser. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has been fortunate to have the services of Professor J. L. R. Davis of the Law Faculty of the Australian National University and on behalf of the Committee I wish to record my thanks to Professor Davis.

The report deals with the work of the Committee from July 1987 to June 1988. The report includes statistics relevant to the work of the Committee over the year as well as the manner in which the Committee has applied the principles set out within its terms of reference. A matter of particular significance to the operation of the Committee is the number of amendments made by the Parliament as a result of the Committee's comments. These are incorporated in Appendix II of the report.

Ministerial responses have become better both in terms of content and expedition. Ministers' responses which treat the comments of the Committee as constructive, positive efforts to improve the quality of the information available to the Senate greatly assist both the Committee and the Senate. Given the time strictures within which the Committee operates, the Committee cannot and does not hold its reports and digests out as exhaustive critiques of all provisions of all Bills that come within the terms of reference of the Committee. What the Committee does is to examine every Bill that is introduced into the Parliament in a technical, non-partisan fashion. The product of this examination by the Committee is that any measures in a Bill that may breach the principles of the Committee are placed in an Alert Digest. The Alert Digest makes the Committee's comments on Bills introduced into the Parliament available to the Senate in the week in which the Bill is introduced.

The role of the Committee has developed to the point where it is now an expeditious, non-partisan and effective instrument of the Senate to help it review legislation. The Committee acts as a guardian of personal rights and liberties, examines administrative procedures falling within its terms of reference, and acts as a watchdog against the erosion of the prerogatives of Parliament. The Committee remains concerned at the continuing practice of legislation by press release. This arises when a change to legislation is announced, usually by a Minister, at times months before the draft legislation is available to the Parliament. The practice causes people to reorder their affairs to accord with the policies announced in the press release. This means that Parliament comes to look at legislation after people have acted in reliance of the press release. If the legislation is changed people have acted on a basis which turns out to be incorrect.

The Committee was concerned in 1987-88 with the number of provisions in Bills allowing for delegated legislation. The Committee will examine closely all clauses in Bills providing for delegated legislation. It considers that all delegated legislation should be numbered, consolidated from time to time and published to the same general standards as instruments in the Statutory Rules series. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee is effective only when it receives support from both Ministers and senators. It is when the reports and Alert Digests issued by the Committee are acted upon by senators and Ministers that it has maximum impact in improving the quality of debate in respect of legislation passed by the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Refurbishment of Reserve Bank of Australia, Melbourne, Victoria

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present the report relating to the refurbishment of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Melbourne, Victoria. I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the report I have just tabled the Committee has recommended the refurbishment of the Reserve Bank of Australia, 60 Collins Street, Melbourne at an estimated cost of $25m at June 1989 prices. In recommending that the work proceed, the Committee has drawn attention to a number of matters. The Committee is concerned that staff will be occupying floors while asbestos is actually being removed from those floors. The Committee has recommended that the Reserve Bank examine the need for this and also that strict safety measures be adhered to during asbestos removal.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has questioned the need for modifications to the ground floor facade at an estimated cost of $800,000 and has recommended that the Reserve Bank re-examine the need for this expenditure. Finally, the Committee has recommended that the Reserve Bank give consideration to the provision of additional toilets for the disabled. The Committee does not believe that the provision of only one toilet for the disabled in a building of 17 storeys is adequate.

The year 1989 has been an extremely busy one for the Public Works Committee. It has tabled 26 reports and held public hearings and inspections in all capital cities except Adelaide and also in many regional centres. The Committee held 66 meetings during the year, made up of public hearings, inspections and private meetings. In total during 1989 the Committee recommended the expenditure of $1,100m on public works proposals. In fact, apart from 1972 when 35 reports were presented, including projects in Papua New Guinea and local Northern Territory projects, this is the highest number of reports the Committee has presented on purely domestic projects. I commend the report to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY (PHOTOGRAPHIC FILM) BILL 1989CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING) BILL 1989CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1989CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
BOUNTY (PHOTOGRAPHIC FILM) BILL 1989
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Button for being in the chamber for the debate on the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989. Senator Button will appreciate that this is of considerable importance to the people of Australia because it dips into the pockets of Australian taxpayers for about $36m to finance a subsidy to an Australian subsidiary of a multinational company in order to enable the Australian subsidiary to send that $36m off to the multinational in the United States. A couple of matters are raised in the second reading speech but we have some difficulty in finding them in the Bill. We seek an explanation from the Minister as to how these arrangements are supported. For example, the Minister, in the second paragraph of his second reading speech, says:

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation will remain in force for a further period of two years to 31 December 1994 for the purpose of securing the performance of undertakings under this legislation.

The first question is: what undertakings? Would the Minister be prepared to tell us what undertakings have been provided to, I presume, the Government? As the Australian taxpayers are footing this bill, they are entitled to know what those undertakings are. The second question is: Who has given the undertakings? Is it Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd or is it Eastman-Kodak, the United States parent company? The third question is: If those undertakings have been given only by the Australian subsidiary, how will they be fulfilled if the parent company takes some action either to liquidate or change the structure of the Australian subsidiary so that it is no longer in the form of the company which has apparently entered into the undertakings?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to ask a couple of questions about the second reading speech. A claim is made on page three of the second reading speech that one of the prerequisites by Eastman-Kodak for Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd to continue operations in Australia was that it would deliver $20m per annum in productivity improvements in addition, of course, to seeking the Federal and State Government subsidies and whatever the Victorian Government provided by way of bounties and assistance. Did the Government assure itself of this $20m per annum improvement in productivity? If that is the case, how were these improvements to be achieved? The Minister in his second reading speech stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian operation is recognised . . . as an efficient and world competitive operation.

At no stage is the company mentioned as being economically viable. Last year's annual report of Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd showed that the return on shareholders' funds for what was a very good year, considering the Bicentennial, the operating profit-in other words, before tax-was about 13.5 per cent.

Senator Bolkus who came in here at the end of the second reading debate, rather than Senator Button, said that the net benefit of tax-I think he said over the next five years-would be $120m. Did he really mean net benefit? Did he mean company taxable income or was that supposed to be the net benefit less the bounty and the assistance provided by the Victorian Government? I have some other questions but I think they are sufficient for the Minister to go on with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of questions were asked and a number of statements made in the course of the remarks by Senator Lewis and Senator Parer. Senator Lewis said that $36m of taxpayers' money will be sent off to the United States to satisfy that fat multinational to which he has obviously taken a dislike. Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd has not paid a dividend to its parent company since 1983. The proceeds of the business have been reinvested in the company and the proceeds of the bounty will go to further investment in Kodak (Australasia). Senator Lewis asked a question about securing performance as it was referred to in the second reading speech. The methods of securing performance will be contained in the regulations made under this Bill, which will be tabled in the Parliament and subject to the normal scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator asked who had given the undertakings-Eastman-Kodak in the United States or Kodak (Australasia). The answer is that both have given the undertakings. He then asked: How can the undertakings be fulfilled if they were given only by the Australian subsidiary? That question becomes irrelevant in the light of the answer I have just given. Senator Parer asked about productivity improvement. Kodak (Australasia) has given certain undertakings to its parent company about productivity improvement. That includes rearrangements in the work force, award restructuring, some changes to management, management practices, some increased volume as a result of investment-a variety of things which go to the question of improved productivity.

Senator Parer referred to the fact that Kodak (Australasia) was described as efficient and world competitive and asked whether it was economic in the sense that it was providing only a 13.5 per cent return on shareholders' funds. The answer to that question is yes, it is regarded as economic by the company. Certainly it is regarded by the Government as a viable economic unit. With regard to the question of tax liability, if the plant closed its operation here during the period 1990 to 1994 it would be $80m and with the bounty it would be $200m in corporate tax, with a net benefit of $120m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to argue with the Minister about what will happen to the proceeds of the bounty, but it is clear that the whole purpose of this arrangement on the part of Kodak (Australasia) and Eastman-Kodak is for Kodak (Australasia) to start paying a dividend to its parent company. While it might use the proceeds of the bounty in investment in plant or equipment or some other form of investment, the ultimate result of this procedure will be that a dividend will be paid to the parent company. So that, in effect, is taking money out of one pocket and putting it in to another, using different proceeds and funds to pay dividend. I say to the Minister that the whole truth of the matter is that this bounty is being paid to enable the subsidiary company to pay a dividend to the parent company. As to the regulations, I presume those undertakings have been already made, and I ask the Minister to confirm that the undertakings have been made. Is he in a position at this stage to provide us with a copy of the proposed regulations so that the Parliament can have some knowledge of what the undertakings are about before we pass this Bill?

—I ask a question of Senator Button relating to the points Senator Lewis and Senator Parer were making. Has any undertaking been given by Kodak (Australasia) to meet the so-called commitments outlined in the second reading speech before it pays any dividend to Eastman Kodak out of the proceeds of the bounty? Also, I think I am right in saying that the Minister has emphasised on numerous occasions that this arrangement should not be seen by other companies as setting any sort of a precedent. I noticed that in the second reading speech the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) made the point that Eastman Kodak is unwilling to close down its less efficient operations-that is, operations less efficient than those in Australia-in other parts of the world for strategic reasons. I would think there are probably a lot of international companies with subsidiaries in Australia, like Eastman-Kodak, which take investment decisions globally on strategic as well as purely economic bases. Without naming specific industries, we could all think of some. Why should none of those companies regard this decision in relation to Kodak (Australasia) as in any way constituting a form of precedent for them as well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are four points in what has been put by Senator Lewis and Senator Short. Before we get too excited about this legislation and go off down a dangerous track, I must say that it is implicit in some of the suggestions from the Opposition that there is something unique about a bounty being paid to a multinational company operating in Australia. There is not.
—That is not the point at all. You ought to know but you do not know.

—I beg your pardon, but it is. If the honourable senator does not mind, I will deal with the speeches that have been made on the Opposition side. He can have a yarn in the pub about it later on. Senator Short's follow-up question goes to the point of whether we have an undertaking that there will be no dividend paid to Eastman Kodak by this company until these obligations have been discharged? That point followed from Senator Lewis's point, which suggested that this money was being paid irresponsibly by the Government, sloshed into the coffers of Kodak (Australasia), whence it would be sloshed into the coffers of the big multinational monster Eastman-Kodak. I do not think honourable senators opposite ought to get too excited about that point. For years industry assistance has been administered in this country and it has been paid to companies irrespective of where their corporate headquarters happen to be-whether it be in Australia or somewhere else. Strange as it may seem, IBM receives a small bounty under legislation which honourable senators opposite voted for. A number of foreign-owned textile companies receive bounties under legislation for which honourable senators opposite voted. Honourable senators opposite did not get too fussed about that.
—Wasn't there an IAC report on it?

—That does not make any difference to the principle. This coming in here and bleating in an Orwellian manner-four legs good, two legs bad sort of stuff-is really getting a bit silly. We have to deal with the argument, not bleat away like Senator Short does, and did a minute ago. I am just uttering a bit of warning about getting too fussed about that sort of stuff.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis asked me whether the undertakings had already been received. The answer is yes. He asked could he look at the draft regulations as soon as possible. The answer is yes, probably today. They will come before Parliament in the usual course. Regulations are not always available--

TALK.START.PARA: —That only allows us to disallow them. That would be a stupid thing to do.

—Yes, of course it would, but that does not mean that those opposite will not do it. That is the normal procedure. We will make them available as quickly as we can. Senator Short asked had there been any undertaking by Kodak (Australasia) not to pay a dividend to Eastman-Kodak until the undertakings it had made under this legislation had been discharged. The answer is no, there has been no such undertaking. On present form there will be no dividend either because it is committed to using the bounty for investment purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally Senator Lewis took up the point of whether there was any precedent in this. There is no precedent. Senator Lewis referred to the words `Eastman-Kodak, for strategic reasons, has decided to keep plants in some other countries' in the second reading speech. That is true, but that is not why we are paying Kodak (Australasia) a bounty. It has nothing to do with the payment of a bounty. The company has strategic reasons for keeping a plant in Europe. The division of the Eastman-Kodak empire is quite simple. United States operations are serviced by United States plants and South American operations are serviced by a South American plant-protected by a 60 per cent tariff, as I recall, against Japanese competition, which is why the company wants to keep that operation. There is a European operation. Having regard to the post-1992 integration of Europe the company wants to keep the plant there. They are strategic reasons. From Australia's point of view the important thing about the Eastman-Kodak empire is that Australia has the plant which provides the exports to the Asia-Pacific region. That is where the proceeds of the Kodak (Australasia) plant go. That is strategic for Eastman-Kodak and it is also, in my view, strategic for us.

TALK.START.PARA: —On page 4 of the second reading speech there is a list of some commitments which Eastman-Kodak and Kodak (Australasia) Ltd apparently have given. The fifth is in relation to Kodak (Australasia) maintaining its mandate for the Asia-Pacific region over the next five years. Is the Minister aware of a recent opportunity for the sale of over $1m worth of Kodak products into mainland China where the executive of Kodak (Australasia) simply refused to enter into the contract on the basis that the deal would have to go through a Hong Kong agent, notwithstanding the fact that an Australian agent who was in mainland China had been offered the contract? Firstly, is the Minister aware of that? Secondly, can the Minister explain to the Senate what is meant by Kodak (Australasia) maintaining its mandate for the Asia-Pacific region? If the Hong Kong agent were another subsidiary of Eastman-Kodak, which I think it is, Eastman-Kodak would in effect be interfering with the so-called mandate for the Asia-Pacific region. So, although the product may be supplied from the Australian plant, the price and other factors are determined by Eastman-Kodak and not necessarily by the Australian subsidiary. Can the Minister give us some explanation about this so-called mandate for the Asia-Pacific region?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The mandate for the Asia-Pacific region is agreed between Eastman-Kodak and Kodak (Australasia) Ltd. It has existed ever since the company started making photographic film in Australia. It will continue, and I do not think there is much concern about that. If it does not continue the plant will close and the bounty money will come back to the government of the day. It is agreed between Eastman-Kodak and Kodak (Australasia) that the mandate will be maintained, and extended to embrace one other country. Senator Lewis also asked whether I had noted a report that somebody had been to Eastman-Kodak wanting to sell $1.2m worth of film in Hong Kong or South East Asia or somewhere.
—Mainland China.

—Mainland China. Senator Lewis said the person had been told that he could not do so. I noticed that report, which was by Peter Bowers in the Sydney Morning Herald. At the time he was actually engrossed in the Queensland election and did this one-off piece as a result of somebody talking to him in a pub or something.
—That is hardly fair. Mr Bowers is a good, reputable journalist.

—I would like that recorded in Hansard. Senator MacGibbon says that Mr Bowers is a good, reputable journalist. I would not want to say what Peter Bowers thinks about Senator MacGibbon; I am sure he thinks Senator MacGibbon is a good, reputable senator, too. It must have been a bit of an aberrant day because a couple of days later the article was corrected by the Sydney Morning Herald journalist who writes about these matters. All the excitement need not have happened. I suppose one day in the life of a journalist is something we have all got to put up with.

SPEECH.PARA: Kodak receives on a regular basis two or three calls a week from people purporting to have export orders or who are working on export orders and who say, `We will buy this much film and sell it in China'-or Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, the United Kingdom or wherever. As a matter of policy, Kodak does not follow up those sorts of contracts unless the firm is known to be a very reliable one and unless substantial information is provided on the possible opportunity. In the specific instance to which Senator Lewis refers, the firm was not known to Kodak. The approach was made to a relatively junior officer who is not involved in export matters, and substantial follow-up information was not provided.

Another important point is that photographic film is a perishable item. In the past Kodak has had experience of exporters, or potential exporters of the kind referred to, buying their film and selling it some time later in another country when the quality has deteriorated. Kodak provides, as it were, a daily service by air into its market in Asia and is properly concerned that the quality of its film is maintained and that the appropriate shelf life is preserved. If distribution is allowed to fall into the hands of a wide variety of people who may not ensure quality control one runs a risk of damaging the reputation of the product. Kodak has had that experience in the past, which makes it very cautious about some of these sorts of suggestions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that Mr Peter Bowers will thank Senator Button for his backhander.
—Tell him I called him Daffy. That will make him happier. Go up and tell him, `Senator Button called you Daffy'.

—I will note that for the record; I do not think I will tell him that, though. I do not think that the company that was endeavouring to enter into this arrangement with Kodak-as I say, it was a very substantial contract-will thank Senator Button either for the implication that it is not a reliable or substantial company. However, I shall move on. The next matter I want to refer to in the second reading speech occurs on page 5. I might say that my colleagues are enabling me to go through my questions first for a personal reason, for which I thank them.
—I've got personal reasons, too, Senator.
—Yes, I understand. On page 5 the Minister states:

SPEECH.PARA: Any changes in government policy that would provide a comparative financial advantage to Kodak Australasia (e.g. reduction of corporate tax rates or of tariffs on input costs) will be taken into account and any assistance provided reduced accordingly.

How does the Minister intend to measure that? In what way would those measurements be taken into account? Would it be guesswork? On the last page of the Minister's speech he says that the Government is satisfied that the commitments entered into between Eastman-Kodak, Kodak (Australasia) and the Government, and this legislation will be, in effect, satisfactory. I ask the Minister: Will there be any arrangements which will not be clear from the regulations which ultimately we might see? No doubt the Minister will provide them to us after this Bill has been passed. I also ask: Will there be any arrangements, as there are in the partnership for development program, which are not made public so that the people of Australia are not fully aware of them? Or will all of the arrangements be set out in the regulations so that it is clear what the full details of the arrangements are?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The arrangements with Kodak which are to be made public will appear in the regulations. I have forgotten the first part of Senator Lewis's question.
—How will the Minister measure the comparative financial advantages of reduction in corporate tax rates or tariffs on input costs?

—I do not think there is any particular art in that. It can be very quickly estimated what the reduction in input cost to a company will be as a result of a tariff reduction. If the input cost was $2m a year, the reduction in input cost would come off the bounty for that year.

—I turn to another matter. In relation to current competition in Australia with Kodak, the Minister will recall his assuring the Senate that there was no-one in Australia who competed with Kodak. But I think the Minister was not aware at that stage that Kodak operates a subsidiary which is involved in film processing. So a large number of small businesses in Australia compete with Kodak. I think the Kodak subsidiary is called the Rabbit processing company. So a large number of Australian film processors are in competition with the subsidiary of a multinational which is receiving this very substantial bounty payment. As the Minister was apparently unaware of that competition, I ask him whether that affected his judgment in any way. What sort of undertaking did he get from Kodak in relation to the fact that the Government is subsidising Kodak? A large number of these Australian business people allege that Kodak is undercutting them in a film processing price war and that it has been enabled to do this by the bounty being paid to it by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of companies might be alleging that, but a discerning, astute chap like Senator Lewis will quickly realise that that is not a likely course of events. When I said that there was no competition for Kodak in Australia, that is true. The legislation which we have before us and which we are debating is called the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill. If Senator Lewis looks at the definitions in the Bill, he will see that it is about paying bounty in respect of the sensitising and finishing of film, a production activity in relation to new film. On page 2 of the Bill, `relevant activity' is defined as relating to the production of photographic film, meaning any activity that is part of the sensitising operation, which is a production activity-making films, as distinct from processing them-or the finishing operations undertaken in the course of producing film.
—Do you think that the profits are not counted from all sources?

—Senator Lewis now comes at it from a different direction and gets back to the sort of minestrone sloshpot in the Kodak corporate office into which money goes and, irrespective of where it comes from, it is all mixed up together and somehow it all finds its way back to Eastman Kodak at some time in the future. None of those things are right.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Parer interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I said a minute ago that the bounty would be attributed to investment in Kodak (Australasia). I said a minute ago that since 1983 no dividend has been paid to Eastman-Kodak. Eastman-Kodak is, perhaps, building up an asset in Australia. I agree with that. But in terms of a direct contribution to Eastman-Kodak, none will arise from this legislation. So, when I said that there was no competition with Kodak in Australia, I meant it. There was no mistake about that. The subsidiary of Kodak which processes film certainly competes with other processors of film, but it is a different operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to a question, Senator Button threw away a figure when he said that over the next five years, with the bounty, the taxation revenue payable by Kodak (Australasia) would be $200m. That is $40m on average over the next five years. I would like to know the basis of that throwaway figure of $200m. The reason I ask is that, in the financial year ended December 1988, the income tax attributable to profit was $13.4m. With a pretty high operating profit-largely, I believe, because of the effects of the bicentennial year-on a calculation that I did on the basis of the annual report and adding in the bounty effect and the Victorian Government assistance effect of $2m, this would lift the operating profit or taxable income of Kodak (Australasia), assuming that last year's figures are indicative of the future, to about $49m. On the basis of 39 per cent tax, it would provide a taxation revenue to the Government of $19m, which includes the bounty, the Victorian Government assistance and the tax thereon.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has said that, with this bounty and the Victorian Government assistance package, suddenly the tax will rise to $40m a year. In other words, the operating profit of Kodak for the next five years on average will go from $35m, as at December 1988, to $100m a year. I would like to know the basis of that figure of $200m which the Minister threw away.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the 1988 year Kodak will pay $13.9m in tax; for the 1989 year Kodak expects to pay about $14m; Kodak's forecast for 1990 is that it will pay about $37m.
—$37m tax?

—That is right. That is because it is a high growth business. There is a lot of improvement in the markets in Asia at which Kodak is looking. But suppose the figure is only $10m a year; suppose it is only $5m-it is not really material to the argument.
—Well, it is because you gave it as a justification for the bounty, so it is material.

—No, the simple justification in terms of tax in respect of the bounty is that, if Kodak disappears, if it leaves Australia, if the business is closed, it will pay no tax at all. If it is here, Kodak will pay tax well in excess of the bounty. That is satisfactory as far as I am concerned.
—That can be said of anyone.
—Well, it could, but I am saying it of Kodak.

—I know that Senator Button is having great difficulty selling this proposal. He obviously did not enjoy it in the first place. Senator Button's comment is a ludicrous statement-I am just picking Senator Button up on this point-because, if the manufacturing part of Kodak, which is the part that the Government is protecting, disappeared, it would mean a couple of things: either the Japanese groups-the Fujis and the others-would take Kodak's place or film would be introduced from Kodak plants in the Philippines or in Brazil. Presumably film would still be marketed in Australia under the Kodak brand name, Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, and Kodak would come out with a profit on which tax would be paid. Senator Button is saying that the manufacturing set-up-I want to come to that in a minute-of the sensitising or finishing, or whatever the two processes are called, would somehow disappear altogether if the bounty were not provided. That patently is just not true because Kodak would still have, in one way or another, its marketing outlet, irrespective of where the goods were produced.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not disagree with that-not at all.
—You said it would disappear.
—I am sorry; I meant if the manufacturing operation disappears.
—You said the profit would disappear.
—Look at it this way: Kodak exports about $160m worth of film a year from Australia. The market for films sold in Australia is about $40m or more each year.
—Total sales of $472m, of which $164m is for exports, so you are looking for $308m.
—I am just trying to make a point by--
—Well, you are miles out-by a factor of eight or 10.

—The point that I am simply trying to make is about the effects on the current account. If Kodak's manufacturing operation closes, a very substantial volume, by value, of film will be imported to this country which is not coming in at the present time and there will be a reduction to zero in export of films, which currently totals about $160m per annum. That is a very substantial shift. Nobody else will come here to manufacture film. Plenty of people will be prepared to import film, including Eastman Kodak. We are talking about a manufacturing operation. That is a consequence of its closure or survival.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to ask the Minister a couple of short questions. How can the Government or the Minister deny that there is favouritism shown to certain manufacturers in Australia when it comes to creating bounties in various areas. For example, I refer to the April statement when the bounty on farm machinery and farm harvesting equipment manufactured in Australia was removed, saving about $29.5m. In that case a sunset clause was applicable under which the bounty was due to run out at June 1990-I am pretty sure that that is the date.
—1989, Senator.

—The removal of the bounty, which was announced in the April statement-although I do not think that the bounty was actually removed until June or July-provided a saving of $29.5m. The company that was mainly affected was John Shearer Ltd in Adelaide-the leading manufacturer of Australia's tillage machinery. That company was on the brink of disaster for a few reasons. That company was denied the bounty even though, legally, the bounty should have continued for a further 12 months. Now, in this case, six months later, more than $29.5m is paid to a single firm with its manufacturing operations in Melbourne. I cannot see why there should be a difference: either both companies or neither company should have been helped if we want to have a level playing field. John Shearer Ltd is strictly an Australian company, manufacturing in Australia, although I believe that it has an assembly factory in South Africa. The company has been thinking of shifting its manufacturing operation to South Africa because it cannot carry on in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The other question I want to ask the Minister is: is it correct that in return for the payment over three years of $36m, Kodak has undertaken to stay in Australia only for the period of the bounty? In other words, in three years time will Kodak have satisfied its obligations for receipt of the bounty?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of the question is that Kodak has undertaken to maintain the sensitising and finishing operation in Australia for five years.
—Three for sensitising; five for finishing.

—Yes. In the earlier part of the question Senator Panizza referred to the bounties paid for different manufacturing industries. By the way, I think Senator Panizza made a slip when he said that the agricultural equipment bounty was $29.5m. That is right, but that is per year. The Kodak bounty is $36m payable over three years-$12 million per year. That is the comparative figure that Senator Panizza has to refer to. Bounties over the years have been altered, reduced or abolished depending on fiscal circumstances of Budgets. That is what happened to the farm machinery bounty. The farm machinery industry was advised at the time that after many years of encouragement from government and assistance by way of bounty, it had done nothing in terms of export performance, nothing in terms of mergers of companies that should have been merged. There was very little, if any, export activity from that industry. There was no point in sustaining the industry by a bounty in the circumstances in which it existed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Panizza mentioned John Shearer Ltd, which is a firm with which I am quite familiar. When the bounty was removed there was a bit of a noise from John Shearer's, but that company had more and bigger problems to make a noise about, as Senator Panizza well knows, which have now been resolved and Shearer's is continuing in business. Senator Panizza mentioned that John Shearer Ltd is an Australian company. I am afraid that makes no difference from the point of view of the argument. What he said was nice and warm emotionally. I share the honourable senator's view that it would be nice to give bounties only to Australian companies and not to other companies which operate here, but that cannot be done under the Constitution. If a company is registered in Australia it is eligible for the benefits and detriments associated with the law of this country. One cannot discriminate on that basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to return to a couple of points made by the Minister, partly in response to questions from this side of the chamber. The Minister said that no precedent for other companies is involved in this decision. In that sense he also mentioned the situation of IBM Australia Ltd. My understanding is that IBM receives a bounty-as does any other bounty recipient in Australia, with the exception of Kodak now-as a result of the operation of proper, normal, due process which includes, in particular, reference to report by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). I would like confirmation from the Minister on that point. I would also like to know how many other companies have been awarded bounties in Australia without having gone through the IAC reference and report process. To some extent, this is a sideline to the precedent issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the main point of my earlier question, in which I pointed out that the Minister had said in the second reading speech that there were strategic reasons for the decision by Kodak (Australasia) Ltd to look at the question of moving from here. The Minister said, quite rightly, that Kodak has a strategic global plan. But so do a large number of other American, British and Japanese international companies. I would like to press the Minister further on this because I do not understand what makes the situation of Kodak unique to such an extent that the Government believes it creates no precedent at all for any other situation.

I would also like to pursue a little further the response of the Minister to Senator Lewis's question about the measurement aspect. Senator Lewis referred to a statement in the second reading speech as follows:

Any changes in Government policy that would provide a comparative financial advantage to Kodak Australasia-for example, reduction of corporate tax rates or of tariffs on input costs-will be taken into account and any assistance provided reduced accordingly.

I ask the Minister: What is meant precisely by the word `comparative'? Comparative with what? Does it mean other producers in Australia or other companies in Australia producing any other product, or is Kodak being compared with producers of this product in other countries? That part of the second reading speech seems very vague.

Reference was made in the speech to the reduction of tariffs on input costs. Even if there were no change in stated tariff rates, the amount of duty paid on input costs would vary with variations in the exchange rate. Obviously, the Minister is referring to input costs relating to imports. I would like to understand better just how these changes will be measured, because it is not immediately apparent. What is apparent is that it would be an extraordinarily complex issue, and the method of valuation would be very important in that context.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it would be very important. We are talking about a relatively small sum of money and relatively small variations to that sum. I do not think it would be terribly important, unless one is feeling a bit obsessive about all this. Any company operating in a floating exchange rate environment has to take the swings and roundabouts of the movements in the exchange rate. Clearly, what is meant is an alteration to the rate of the tariff, because that would be consequent upon Government action. That is what I meant when I referred to the tariff. I think it is pretty clear what a change in corporate tax would mean. Senator Short asked whether there were any comparative changes-
—What does `comparative' mean in your statement?
