—It means that at the date of this legislation a certain regime applies, a static model, as compared with now when, if the taxation rate moves-the corporate tax rate or the tariff rate-that is be taken into account. That is the comparative charge referred to. I would have thought that would be clear to almost anybody.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short asked about the strategic considerations of other companies, other multinationals and so on. Sure, they all have different policies which are adopted by their corporate headquarters. Some of them may have a strategy rather like Kodak's, of dividing up the world and so on. Senator Short could take this debate a lot further if he could point to one of them operating in Australia which has been here for a long time and has exported $160m worth of goods manufactured in Australia to Asia-sophisticated manufactured goods. If Senator Short could point to one company that was doing that and was in trouble through no fault of its own, he would be pretty close to his precedent, but he cannot.

TALK.START.PARA: —On that latter point, my understanding is that the profit of Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd last year, to quote the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), was $35m to $40m. Can the Minister explain to me how an Australian company, Kodak (Australasia), is in serious trouble when it is earning a pre-tax profit of $40m? In relation to the measurement factor that we were talking about before that would determine whether assistance provided would be reduced, will the method of calculation of the changes that may occasion those reductions be spelt out in the regulations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow up the question Senator Short raised in relation to profit, because I raised it earlier. The profit last year was $35m with a return on shareholders' funds of 13.5 per cent, which Senator Button said he thought was pretty reasonable. Subsequently, in response to a question I asked in regard to the anticipated future profit, Senator Button indicated that Kodak (Australasia) had advised him that for 1990 it anticipated that the actual tax bill would be of the order of $35m. A quick calculation backwards on that, which includes the bounty and the Victorian Government assistance, would indicate that the operating profit, without the bounty and assistance, then goes to $76m, which shows a return on shareholders' funds of the order of 28 per cent. The reason we are questioning this is that Senator Button has intimated, according to newspaper reports, that he felt he was blackmailed even though he did not like it. I am wondering whether he was not conned as well. If the figure he gave me earlier is correct, we now have a company that says that next year, excluding the bounty and the $2m, it will have an operating profit before tax of $76m, of a 28 per cent return on total shareholders' funds, including the funds that have been reinvested since 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: The question I am asking, in addition to those asked by Senator Short, is: How can the Minister justify the payment of the bounty under those conditions at a rate of return which most companies would give their eye teeth for? Why would a company with that sort of potential require Government assistance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to repeat myself ad infinitum, but the fact of the matter is that Eastman-Kodak made a decision which involved cutting back production capacity throughout its empire-if I can call it that-around the world. It decided to cut back production capacity in Australia unless the performance of the company improved. That was the reference I made to being in trouble-it was not because of the existing performance of the company in Australia, but because of the requirement of Eastman-Kodak that that performance improve or the production capacity cutback would occur here. That is the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short has said that there has been no reference to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) in this matter. I have answered that question in public on numerous occasions. We had to move quickly. There was no time for a reference to the IAC. This has happened before. This Parliament overrides the IAC legislation and that is why we are here debating it today.

TALK.START.PARA: —When has it happened before?

—I will give the honourable senator some examples. I know that it has happened before, but not in my time. Perhaps the honourable senator would not want me to go into them all. It was in the previous Government's time. The fact of the matter is that this Parliament overrides the IAC legislation, and that is why the legislation is here and why we are debating it. In so far as the regulations are concerned, and they have relevance to the calculation of all these matters that Senator Short has fussed about, that matter has to be handled prior to the annual appropriation, and that is provided for in the regulations. The methodology is not provided for. It is commonsense, I think.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have now determined, after some discussion, that the reasons for the bounty are not economic. We have to find out just what the reason for the bounty is. No one could claim that a company which forecasts that next year, pre-bounty, it will make a 27 to 28 per cent return on its shareholders' funds has economic problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now move to the manufacturing side, which is made up of two parts-the sensitising operation and, I think it is called, the finishing operation. With the provision of taxpayers' money through a bounty, why was it possible to get only an assurance-assuming from Kodak (Australasia) and Eastman-Kodak-for sensitising operations for three years? That is the tricky part; the high technology part. Senator Button, in his second reading speech, makes great play of the fact that we will be exporting ETMs, elaborately transformed manufactures, through Kodak because it happens to be the second largest exporter of these items in Australia-which is a pretty sad indictment of this country, though I am not holding the Minister responsible. But that is for three years only. I would like a response from the Minister as to why that is the case.

Having committed taxpayers' money to this extent, we have to be suspicious that at the end of three years we will end up importing sensitised film-whether it be from Brazil, the Philippines, or somewhere else-and we will be left with what is called the finishing operation, which is cutting and packaging. That only needs to go on for two years. How confident is the Minister that this injection-if we can call it that-of taxpayers' money will benefit this plant for the long term and not just the short term? Are we not running a risk of just postponing the inevitable?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course we are running a risk. We run a risk every time we pay bounties to any firm. I do not think there is any greater risk being run here than there is under any other bounty legislation. At least we know where the money is going here. We do not know with many of the other bounties which have been paid for donkey's years and which have gradually been reduced or abolished by this Government.

—I just want to come back to the precedent point. I realise that there is a limit to how much we should push this. I will ask one other question on it. Let us take, as an example, a company such as Ford. It has plants around the world in the same way as Eastman-Kodak and has them there for strategic reasons and all the similar sorts of reasons. The Ford Motor Co. of Australia exports. Hopefully it will increase its exports significantly over the next few years because it is doing a good job and it is confident that it will continue to do so. Let us say that the parent company in the United States proposed to take a similar decision in relation to Ford Australia that Eastman-Kodak put to the Minister in relation to Kodak (Australasia). Will the Minister confirm that under no circumstances would he treat Ford in the same way he is treating Kodak (Australasia)? If not, why not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator can think up all sorts of hypothetical examples of what one might do in a particular situation. I do not think he has chosen a particularly good one, if I might say so.
—I think it is a quite analogous situation.

—Let me start off by saying, so that the honourable senator can relax, that I will give him that undertaking. So long as I am here that will not happen. Ford Australia is a beneficiary of a number of other things under the car plan, for example, just as computer companies are beneficiaries not of financial assistance but of other assistance in terms of their operations in Australia, many of them under the partnership for development program. I think that the circumstances are quite different. It is quite possible that in a few years time Ford, or one of the other manufacturers, might come and say, `No go down there, fellows; we are going home'. That might happen. They will go home. I have been telling them for five years that if they do not like it here they ought to go home. That is why we have been reducing the numbers of manufacturers in Australia.
—But you wouldn't tell Kodak?

—No, I would not tell Kodak that for the reasons I have identified ad nauseam in the course of this debate and publicly. Kodak has asked for short term assistance of a relatively modest kind because of a particular set of circumstances. Kodak got that assistance because it happens to be a very large exporter of elaborately transformed products to the Asia-Pacific region. That is it in a nutshell. If Senator Short gets a lot of macho comfort in criticising that decision, he can go his hardest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a final wrap-up question to ask of the Minister.
—As long as you are not going to wrap me up.

—It would not be a big package. What is the real reason for handing out this money? From what I have been able to glean this afternoon, it is not economic. We already have the Minister's assurance that next year the company will not be paid any bounty and that it will have a rate of return on total shareholders' funds of 27 to 28 per cent. The Minister also says that there is a risk involved. In other words, there is no guarantee whatsoever that after three years we will be producing sensitised film in Australia-and I suppose the chances are that we will not-and that at the end of five years we will be cutting and packaging film. So I am not too sure-and I am not sure whether the Minister himself can justify it, although I know he will do his best-that this support can be justified.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not seen any supportive comments in the media over the period of this little episode-not that the media is always correct in these things-as to how we can justify this expense to the Australian public. We will have paid out $36m. The Victorian Government will have paid out $6m. It is not that the company was not profitable and efficient, or did not have the potential to become more profitable. We have not been given long term guarantees that the company will continue with this high technology and the export of elaborately transformed manufactured goods, because that is assured for only three years. What is the real reason? I certainly cannot pick it up from the second reading speech or from any of the statements the Minister has made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said on numerous occasions in this debate, governments pay bounties for a variety of reasons and we now pay about one-third the amount of bounties that were paid when we came into government. This is the only bounty which I think has ever existed in which very onerous requirements have been placed on the company in terms of accountability for that bounty.
—It is what you call an aberration.

—Senator Parer can call it that if he likes. He said earlier that I said that I had been blackmailed. I did not say that I have been blackmailed. I am not a person who is easily blackmailed because of the essential purity of my character. People know I smoke, and I suppose somebody will blackmail me about that one day. The bounty is payable at the end of the five-year period on condition that the company meets all those requirements.
—Not at the end of the five years.

—At the end of the five years. That is technically correct. Advances can be paid as against the bounty but it is not payable, technically, until the end of the five years. It is put in those circumstances so that conditions which have been placed on it will be met along the way. Senator Parer still keeps asking why the bounty is payable at all. I have told him that it has nothing to do with any suggestions that might be exciting his mind at any particular time.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the projections on sales, some of which I have referred to already-and I do not regard this as a significant and material point in terms of the tax take-so long as the tax returns exceed substantially the level of the bounty which, itself, is taxable, that is not a problem that concerns me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to buy into this debate, but I cannot help but comment on the furious objection from the Government and the Opposition in respect of debate on the far more serious matter of nuclear armed and powered ships to Australian ports. This afternoon, the Bounty (Photographic) Film Bill 1989 has occasioned well over an hour's debate. I will seek a little more information from the Minister. No doubt he has been negotiating with Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd over this matter. I ask him a question in relation to something I raised during the second reading stage of the debate. There is no indication that Kodak in Australia will be proceeding with the development of any of the newer technology such as the digital recording of images. That is a matter which concerns us in that we would like to see some encouragement of that development. This bounty is only in relation to an established technology-possibly a technology which will pass out of use over the next 10 to 15 years. Did the Minister, in his negotiations, develop any notion that Kodak (Australasia) will be or is likely to be developing these newer technologies in Australia as an Australian technology?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been such discussions with Kodak and it is keen to use the technology to which Senator Coulter refers. I was not present at the detailed discussions, but I was present at the discussions at which the remote sensing industry and imaging, and so on, were referred to as an interest of Kodak in Australia. In a sense, it is remote from this Bill, as the honourable senator would appreciate. People in my Department have had discussions with Kodak about that and they are continuing.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the second reading speech on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) referred to the fact that schedule 6 operates on and from 1 August 1989 and provides quota free and duty free access for certain ski boots and cross-country ski footwear. I do not have any particular objection to that exercise. I am raising not the $6m a year that we have been discussing for Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd-it is not even $600,000; it is not even $60,000-but an amount of $6,000. We are quite happy to allow ski boots and cross-country skiwear to be dealt with in this way yet, seemingly, we are buried in an almost miasma of confusion with regard to boots for spina bifida children.

SPEECH.PARA: We have engaged quite properly-and I am not objecting to this; in fact I supported at the time the harmonisation of the tariffs-in changing the definition with regard to orthopaedic appliances. We have adopted the harmonised definition-and I am not objecting to that either-which says that orthopaedic appliances mean footwear made to measure for a specific disorder. The difficulty is that the interpretation that the Australian Customs Service has put on `made to measure' is, I feel, such a pedantic one as to really be very difficult to swallow. We are looking at boots for spina bifida children, which have to be placed on the child's feet at a pretty early stage so that weak feet, paralysed feet or feet not treated very rapidly do not end up severely deformed.

It so happens that the boots that are provided in Australia are all imported. They come from France. We import about 250 pairs a year. The strange thing about the way that they are made is this: a spina bifida child has a mould made of its feet. That mould is then used to select, from a range of shoes which are pre-made, the shoe that fits that particular child. To do anything else, quite frankly, would be pretty stupid because that is the best way of dealing with the issue. One has to cycle through a number of these boots. They are quite expensive. The basic cost is about $60 each, and we are putting a 45 per cent import duty on them. I say it is 45 per cent, but the Minister might be able to find out something else. I have ploughed through hundreds of pages dealing with footwear and it seems that, if there is a stitch at the top rather than at the bottom, the amount is changed. I originally thought the import duty was 50 per cent. I am lead to believe that it is actually 45 per cent.

The differences between these boots and ordinary footwear are quite extensive in terms of the height; the ankle support for rigidity; the reinforcement to prevent sideways movement; the arch support, dealing with the junction of the back foot and front foot movement; the front part, which has to be additionally wide to allow free movement of toes; the heel, which has a one centimetre maximum to allow the back foot-forward foot movement; the sole, which has to be made of leather as an anti-skid arrangement; and the cushions, which are very important for children who do not have much feeling in their feet because they could be knocked, have serious bruising and not know it. That could rub, and there could be additional problems there. That means you have to have a very supple leather with a lack of stitching so that any risk of irritation is avoided.

All of that, quite frankly, constitutes a highly specialised boot. But the interpretation of `made to measure' has been done in what I consider to be a most extraordinarily pedantic and bureaucratic way. These boots are made to measure. In fact, if the people in the Australian Customs Service knew anything about the way that made to measure boots are made, they would know that most of them are made in an identical fashion. The feet are measured up, and then the customer goes into a room and selects from ones already there. Those boots cost about $300. I happen to know that, if Senator Button is interested, because my son has to have them and I have seen them made. That is perfectly all right. But I ask: how precisely are imported boots going to be made to measure in any form under the interpretation given by the Australian Customs Service? Presumably, one would go overseas and have them measured up. Alternatively, one would have to have them measured up here and send measurements overseas. They would be made up, sent back for fitting, and then sent overseas again. We are dealing with a most extraordinary proposition.

The total cost to revenue would be about $6,000. I hope that the Minister is listening because this is an important issue. It is only about 250 pairs of boots for children suffering from spina bifida. I am sorry it is not about Kodak! In fact, this absurd exercise has been going on now for months. People have been flying around the country. I think we have spent more than $6,000 already. Today I ask, `When are we going to get a decision on this?'. The Minister has somebody in his Department-in fact, two people-dealing with this issue now, and we are told that there will be no decision until the middle of January. Quite frankly, it is not good enough. This is the type of thing that could and should have been solved within a day, and that should have been done months ago. It is not a difficult problem. If, in fact, the interpretation is such as to make it absolutely impossible to solve this problem, the Minister has the discretion under the Act to be able to deal with it. Do not tell me that we are going to find ourselves in a General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade debate over 250 pairs of boots in the harmonising exercise. I do not want to involve myself in the harmonising exercise-as I have already said, we support it totally-but that is the excuse I keep getting in the myriad of letters that are churned out on this issue.

I am appealing to the Minister for a little commonsense in what has become a bureaucratic maze. It is no fault of the Minister. I am not castigating him on it. It is probably the first he has heard about it. It is just one of these absurd situations where everybody feels they have to run along with words which could not possibly have the meaning being put on them. This situation could easily be solved by the operation of the Minister's discretion, which hopefully could be done within the next 24 hours.

That is all I really want to say on the matter. I want the situation to be cleaned up, as I am quite sure the Minister does, so that these people who have these children and who are dealing with this matter are not put to the type of expense that is now suggested, that is, that they are going to have boots made at $300 a pair. If children cycle through these boots at a fairly rapid rate, it is already an extremely large cost to add to families that are already bearing quite significant add-on costs as a result of having a child with spina bifida.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industries Assistance Commission is currently conducting an inquiry into aids for the handicapped, and that inquiry closes, in so far as submissions are concerned, on 15 December. That encompasses a range of issues, apart from the one which Senator Macklin has spoken on. I have heard his speech; I was listening. I will see what else can be done in terms of looking at an appropriate by-law or something to deal with this problem. I will let Senator Macklin know as soon as I can about that.

-I thank the Minister. I am sure that he will do that. This is not a matter which comes under the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). It is a matter which has arisen out of the interpretation of a harmonising definition. We cannot change that, but certainly the interpretation can be changed. In any event, the Minister has a discretion with regard to these types of matters. It just seems to me that this matter is something that the IAC probably will never even discuss in that the amounts and numbers involved are infinitesimal. Quite frankly, I do not think there should be any more letters written on this matter, anybody else jetting around the country, or somebody highly paid sitting in one of the Government's departments until the middle of January working out whether we should or should not. Knowing the Minister's decisive manner of dealing with these things, I am sure that he could fix up the situation in a couple of minutes after he gets out of the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt that the Industries Assistance Commission would consider the matter if Senator Macklin made the speech he has made to it next week. As he has made it to me, I will see what can be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
CUSTOMS EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989
Clauses 1 to 17-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 18 to 21-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That clauses 18 to 21, inclusive, be deleted.
I would like to get some information as to what was behind the Government's move to legislate in the way it did.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that Senator MacGibbon has a number of amendments going to a number of clauses, but substantially dealing with the same sort of process of change between the existing Act and how he would like to see the Act, as amended through this legislation. I wonder whether he would be prepared to argue the generality of his case rather than take his clauses one by one. I would be keen to hear the counter arguments of the Government in relation to the generality of these clauses because I think I am right in saying that they all attempt to achieve the same end purpose. I wonder whether we might deal with the amendments together.

—I just put my first amendment on the table to use that device to question the Government as to why it is doing things and to cover the generality of the whole procedure of moving to guidelines, getting away from the specifics. I used the formal device of moving that clauses 18 to 21 inclusive be opposed to give the Committee the opportunity to question the Government as to why on broad grounds it is moving away from specific and legislated definitions or set of definitions into a series of guidelines and from particular goods to a class of goods. I ask the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who is at the table, why the Government is doing what it has done in this proposed legislation. I read the second reading speech with interest. I make the comment in relation to section XVa that the theme of the speech is that there are some minor administrative problems that need to be corrected. It said that there is a need for some slight finetuning to the administration. In the second reading speech, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) said:

SPEECH.PARA: Experience with the system has pointed to several changes which could-
I note use of the word `could', not `would'-

be made to improve operational efficiency. In the May 1988 Economic Statement the Government announced that it would modify the system to more closely align its operation with the Government's industry and technology policy objectives.
Subsequent to that Economic Statement, decisions by the Federal Court have highlighted restrictive and narrow interpretations to various definitions contained in the legislation.

To restore the Australian Customs Service's ability to administer the legislation in accordance with the Government's intentions, it is necessary to make appropriate changes to the legislation and fine tune operational aspects of the system. The amendments proposed in this Bill seek to achieve this.

I argue that the theme of the speech is for some administrative finetuning, yet we have a major rewrite of the Bill; there is not only a rewrite of the provisions, but also a change in the whole format. Whereas before we had very precise definitions that had to be met in order to qualify for the importation of goods which were not manufactured in Australia and for which there was no readily available Australian substitute, very precise conditions defined in law, they have now all be thrown out and we are given some guidelines which will be written by the Australian Customs Service and proclaimed by the Minister. They will be disallowable instruments laid before the Senate, but we will move from the precise to the imprecise. We will move from the known to the unknown and the unknowable in so far as they can be changed quite readily. I wonder whether the Minister for Resources can offer some explanation as to why this is being done.

By way of explanation, I diverge a little into the history of the matter. The Industries Assistance Commission report of 2 July 1982 recommended some changes to improve predictability and certainty and to reduce the scope for dispute. Both of those faults were undeniably present in the guidelines that existed prior to the 1983 changes to the Act which created the present section XVa. When Senator Button introduced the scheme in 1983, in his second reading speech he also said that he wanted to reduce disagreement and legal disputation and to achieve the result of predictable administration. The legislation was incorporated in the parent Customs Act and it has been in place now for about six years.

If we look at what has happened in those six years, we see that the Australian Customs Service has struggled since 1 July 1983 to retain its earlier by-law control. It has challenged the legislation by whatever opportunities open to it in an attempt to get back to the old system, which was clearly unsatisfactory. It has tried to limit the width of making particular concessions where there was any hint of questioning by local industry and it was at variance with the expressed law. Looking at the history of the six years of the current legislation, we see that the Australian Customs Service has nearly always made concessions when the local industry agreed. It has never stood on its own feet and made decisions on their merits. That can be seen from the statements the Service has made to people who have applied. It has tended to avoid the second stage of the requirement of section XVa that it has to consider the relevance of cross-elasticity in demand.

As a consequence of this, we have seen the Federal Court actions of Davies Craig Pty Ltd, Amcor Ltd and Corinthian Industries (Sydney) Pty Ltd where the judgments have all gone against the Customs Service and it has been advised to reconsider its decisions on the correct basis. In my judgment, we have not seen a cooperative move by the Australian Customs Service to administer the legislation as it is on the books. When the matter has been raised in the courts, it has been found repeatedly that the Customs Service has not interpreted the law. I want to know why the law is not being interpreted and has therefore not really had a fair trial. In the light of the IAC report which set up the legislation in 1983, the Minister's second reading statements when the amendments were put in the Act in 1983 and the Minister's second reading statements today in which he said that he wants administrative finetuning, I want to know why we do not fix the present law instead of throwing it out entirely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —The chamber has before it an amendment to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) which has been moved by Senator MacGibbon on behalf of the Opposition. Having a few minutes ago answered some very detailed questions by Senator MacGibbon, I am coming quickly to a basis of knowledge from which I can supply authoritative answers. I cannot be 100 per cent sure that I can answer all his questions in the way he posed them, but I will take a run at it by going back to what was said in the second reading debate and, hopefully, picking up the answers to his questions by a full explanation of the points that the honourable senator's amendment implies. With your leave, Mr Temporary Chairman, I will consult my notes fairly extensively in this process.

SPEECH.PARA: The rationale for the Government's proposed amendments of the commercial tariff concession system (CTCS) in clauses 18 to 28 of the Bill was well set out, as the Senate should be aware, in Senator Coulter's second reading debate comments. It is not, as Senator MacGibbon has said, or would wish us to believe, an attempt to pre-empt the announced review of the system by the new Industry Commission. While review by the Industry Commission of the CTCS is in fact programmed, the review is not expected to commence until late next year, and it is anticipated that it will be of about 12 months duration. In the meantime, with concession applications being received at the rate of about 150 per month, the Government believes that immediate action is necessary to enable the system to operate as it was originally proposed.

The amendments are intended to restore the pre-Corinthian case status quo which Senator Coulter addressed and to which I will refer shortly. The amendments are not intended to pre-empt any review of the overall objectives and the operation of the system, which is quite properly the province of the independent Industry Commission. In accepting the 1982 Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report on a modified commercial by-law system, both the previous Government and this Government intended the new CTCS system to be broad in application and predictable in outcome. The concepts conveyed by the terms in part XVa of the Customs Act were intended to be broad rather than narrow in interpretation so that, where appropriate, concessions would be available to all importers of like goods. The system was not designed or intended to enable importers to use the CTCS mechanism in narrow terms exclusively to suit their own commercial interests.

In practice, it has been concluded by the IAC that the definitions contained in the legislation have tended to confuse, rather than offer precision, and have obscured, rather than clarified, the system's objectives. I should say that Senator Coulter quoted from the IAC report No. 416 of 1 February this year concerning two CTCS references during his second reading debate comments. Similarly, recent Federal court cases have led to a narrower and more restrictive application of the terms of part XVa than was envisaged. Until recent Federal Court judgments, for instance, it was believed that the Comptroller could write a concession for a class of goods having regard to the goods described in the particular commercial tariff concession orders application and the goods produced, or capable of being produced, in Australia with which they would compete. However, in the Corinthian Industries (Sydney) Pty Ltd versus Customs case of 7 April 1989, the Federal Court clearly stated that the provisions of section XVa limited the scope of a concession order to the `particular goods' that are the subject of an application. I will give an example. The legislation only permits concession orders to be written in accordance with the description of the goods set out in the application. Where an application seeks concessional entry for blue felt pens and there is no legal manufacture of blue felt pens, a concession can only be issued for blue felt pens rather than all felt pens. I hope that is an illuminating example. This could lead to separate concessions for blue pens, black pens, turquoise pens or pens of any other description.

Frequently in the course of their discussions, importers negotiate with local manufacturers to determine the scope of a concession which could be made. The power to narrow concessions, for instance, to cover fewer goods than were originally applied for, is important for applicants as inquiries with local manufacturers might establish that the concession, as originally applied for, cannot be issued within the scope of the original wording. However, without the power to vary this wording, no concession can be issued requiring a new application with a new operative date which, in many instances, might be later than when the goods were actually imported, thus resulting in no concession for those goods.

Additionally, not being able to change the description of the goods applied for has the potential for applicants manipulating the system to specifically exclude competitive imported goods-this point is acknowledged by the IAC in its report No. 416, previously referred to and quoted by Senator Coulter in his remarks during the second reading debate-or increasing the number of concession orders thereby raising costs for both the Australian Customs Service and users, or loss of operative date of concessions and thus the inability on the part of importers to obtain refunds of duty.

The amendments proposed in the Bill seek to restore the Australian Customs Service's ability to effectively administer the CTCS, in accordance with the original objectives of the system, pending the review and report on the system by the Industry Commission in late 1991. I hope that Senator MacGibbon has found that a more illuminating explanation for the first 13 of the Opposition's amendments. I think amendment No. 14 requires a different and fuller explanation which I will give in a minute. But I hope that that answers the question that Senator MacGibbon raised with respect to this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not answer my question. It raises a whole heap of questions. The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) did not tackle the fundamental point as to why it was necessary. I will touch upon one of the Minister's latter points before I come back to some earlier ones. The point that the Minister raised about an entry or application being made for an order and it not being accepted or accepted in the form that it is required is perfectly valid. But had the Customs officers worked through the amendments that were proposed by the Opposition and taken the trouble to sit down and go through them and compare them with the changes to the legislation that the Government is proposing, they would have found that that point is covered more than adequately, because we pick up the precise terms that the Government proposes in its legislation to allow the earlier starting date. So that is a non sequitur and irrelevant to the discussion at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Does the Government agree with the argument that Senator Coulter put forward before lunch? I find that his argument is quite at variance with the argument that the Minister made in his second reading speech, where he argued for administrative changes. Yet Senator Coulter was arguing from the basis of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) inquiry.

During the lunch hour I reread the Industries Assistance Commission report on Commercial Tariff Concessions (PVC Foam Blocks and DC Electric Motors). I did not use it in my speech because, quite frankly, it is utterly irrelevant to this Bill. It deals with two specific cases where two companies had applications for tariff concessions refused and the IAC supported the refusal. There are a couple of points that I want to make about this. I do not know whether Senator Coulter read the report. I have read it a couple of times, and I reread it again at lunchtime. It does not provide any comfort at all for the Government with respect to the amendments in this Bill.

One of the points made in the opening part of the report is that although an IAC report was held on these two refusals, as is allowed under existing section XVA of the Act where a tariff concession order has been refused, the IAC report on those has no bearing on the Minister at all. The Minister does not have to accept the recommendations in any way at all. There is nothing binding on him. The most important thing about this report-I presume Senator Coulter derived all of his information from pages 26 and 27 under a two-page section entitled `General Issues Arising In The Inquiry'-is the issues and the views expressed by the IAC with respect to the legislation. They foreshadowed what has subsequently occurred-namely, a full inquiry by the IAC, or by its successor, the Industry Commission which, as the Minister said, will report in the immediate future.

I am interested to know whether the Government is changing its ground and is going on to pick up the argument which was advanced, I think, with respect, quite erroneously by Senator Coulter, because the IAC simply had nothing to do with this legislation. Senator Coulter said that there was a need for an overhaul of the system. The Opposition and, quite clearly, the Government believe that there is a need for an overhaul of the whole system, or a review of it, and that is why we have all supported the Industry Commission report in the future. We also support the Law Reform Commission's inquiry. But the IAC said in this report, No. 416, that it cannot be done in this particular legislation, and it is not being done. The review of the TCOs that is required is not being done by this legislation at all. What Senator Coulter is saying is very relevant to next year when the reviews are being done, and I find that at great variance with the Minister's theme that what is needed is to finetune the operational aspects of the system. That is certainly not a complete review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am bound to reply to the questions raised by Senator MacGibbon.
—You are not bound to; you are entitled to.

—No, in an effort to shed some illumination on this point and hopefully, therefore, obtain passage of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) more quickly, I think I should answer the question raised by Senator MacGibbon about the point of view exercised by Senator Coulter, and do so based on my very rapid accumulation of information on this point. The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report that is the basis of what the Government is proposing to address is entitled Commercial Tariff Concessions (PVC Foam Blocks and DC Electric Motors), 1 February 1989, Report No. 416. If that is not confusing enough, the section that I will rely on in answering Senator MacGibbon's question is section 5, `General Issues Arising in the Inquiry', and in particular the references and observations made by the IAC on pages 26 and 27.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter in which the Government is proposing to insert into the Bill guidelines rather than living tightly drawn definitions, and the IAC made relevant observations about those definitions, making a nonsense of the Government's intent or the intent of those definitions if those definitions, drawn tightly and narrowly and, I would have to say, understandably but somewhat stupidly, were to be applied. The intention of the insertion of the guidelines is to arrive at what was intended by a sensible, straightforward means without having to get into the litigious possibilities offered by narrow and, perhaps on reflection, insensitively drawn definitions. It is because of that and the observations made in section 5 of the report that the Government proposes these amendments.

Senator MacGibbon asks whether the Government concurs with Senator Coulter's view. In all honesty, I have to say that I did not hear Senator Coulter's erudite words in the second reading debate, so I cannot be absolutely sure whether I agree with all of them, but I am advised that Senator Coulter, in his second reading contribution, substantially captured the essence of the Government's position and there appears to be no difference between us.

TALK.START.PARA: -It is not surprising that Senator Coulter agrees with the Government because the Australian Customs Service is perhaps the sole source of information for Senator Coulter. I have sympathy for the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) in that section 15a is a very complex piece of legislation and the amendments proposed to it by the Government really cannot be picked up on the run. They do take some hours to reflect upon, and for the peace of mind of the Senate let me just say that I differ with the Minister on the interpretation of what the Industries Assistance Commission report No. 416 says. Since we will not reach agreement on that, there is no point in proceeding with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that we were taking these matters all together, because the issue before us really bears on three of Senator MacGibbon's amendments wherein he is seeking to insert the word `particular'.

—Senator MacGibbon has not moved any amendments at the moment. He has given notice that the Opposition wishes to oppose clauses 18 to 21, and that is why those clauses are before the Chair at the moment.

—Mr Chairman, as I said in my opening remarks in the committee stage of the debate, the difficulty is that we are dealing with two alternative views of a particular procedure. Senator MacGibbon is attempting through a series of amendments to move to one particular position and the Government is attempting to move to another one. I just draw attention, in relation to what has just passed between Senator MacGibbon and the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), to page 8 of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report No. 416, where one finds that the Industries Assistance Commission is saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The term ``identical'' was (implicitly) interpreted to take its literal dictionary meaning so that it was hardly capable of practical use.

It seems to me that Senator MacGibbon is attempting to write back through a series of amendments a definition which implicitly-that is the word used by the IAC-assumes identicality between the goods for which a concession is sought and goods manufactured in Australia whereas the IAC is saying that it is hardly of any practical use.

I am not in any sense relying only on pages 26 and 27 of that IAC report, but it seems to me that the IAC report in general raises serious doubts about the ability of the tests which have to be applied to be interpreted clearly enough so that they can be properly applied-and that goes more to Senator MacGibbon's amendments, which are consequential upon the particular one that he is presumably about to move.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the Chair is that clauses 18 to 21 stand as printed, for which there are no foreshadowed amendments. In order to make this debate orderly, I remind the Committee that it has passed clauses 1 to 17 as printed. Clauses 18 to 21 are foreshadowed to be opposed by the Opposition and are, therefore, the matter before the Chair. After that, I am in the hands of the Committee. If the Committee wishes to take the remainder of the Bill as a whole and Senator MacGibbon move all his amendments together, that is up to the Committee, but at the moment the question is that clauses 18 to 21, for which no amendments have been foreshadowed, stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Coulter has raised a very good point there. He has quoted from the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report No. 416 about the difficulty that the Industries Assistance Commission had with the word `identical' and, quite clearly, the Australian Customs Service (ACS) has the same problem with it. As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, this matter is defined in the legislation and it is proper for the courts of Australia to determine what the legislation means. With the greatest of respect to the IAC and the ACS, it is not for them to interpret what the legislation means. They can have their views on, but the ultimate arbiter is the courts of Australia. It is very interesting to look at the Corinthian case which apparently provoked this whole exercise and at the judgment of the presiding judge of the Federal Court in that case. I will quote more from Corinthian Industries v. Comptroller-General of Customs later, which was decided as recently as April of this year, but one particular paragraph of the judgment is very relevant to what Senator Coulter has said. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not useful for the purposes of this case to attempt to expound on the circumstances required to make goods identical. It is sufficient for present purposes that the word `identical' is an ordinary word in the English language, as is the word `goods'. The provision will apply when goods satisfy the ordinary conception of identical goods and will not apply if the goods are not identical in that sense.

The court has made a judgment as to what the word `identical' means. I submit that Senator Coulter and the Government have to accept that the ruling of the courts, which is the proper place for meaning of the legislation to be tested overrides the views of the IAC and the Australian Customs Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I think your observation as to how we might proceed is eminently sensible, and I would like to follow your suggestion. As Senator MacGibbon has foreshadowed his opposition to these proposed sections, we might take them all together. If Senator MacGibbon so wishes he may then move his amendments. He can deal with it in that way. Otherwise, we will simply lap the course possibly twice or maybe more times with no real benefit, gain or utility to any of us. If we get to the point where we simply repeat our arguments by calling out the numbers by which the amendments are noted, it will also make a farce of this process.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I sit down I will make a quick comment on what Senator MacGibbon has just said. He has made the observation that it is appropriate for the courts of Australia to decide the meaning of `Acts of Parliament'. That of course is true. But if the courts of Australia decide that definitions or meanings are such that in the practical workaday world it becomes virtually impossible or indeed extremely awkward to function, then it is appropriate that the legislature should revisit that and solve the practical problem. On the advice and information before me, it seems that the Corinthian case clarified a legal view of the legislation. It imposed practical and realistic workaday world constraints. We are trying to return the Act to what was intended so that business and commerce can function smoothly within its original intent. We had set down the legal words to mean certain things but we have found them not to mean those things. I do not contend with Senator MacGibbon's initial view of what the court's role might be, but if a nonsense is thrown up in law it is entirely appropriate that the legislative wheels should turn and correct that. As I understand it, that is the basis of this exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I understand Senator MacGibbon correctly, he is saying that laws should always stand without amendment and that we should simply abide strictly by the interpretations which the courts place on those words. I do not think that is what he really means. I think he is saying that he would prefer to stick with the definition which the courts have put on this form of words, whereas I understand the Government to be saying that, in line with the judgment of the Industries Assistance Commission and others, the interpretation which the courts have given to these words is so fraught with difficulty that the words have very little meaning at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I have drawn attention to the words of the IAC in relation to `identical'. Pages 26 and 27 and the point in relation to cross-elasticity of demand have been picked up several times. On these pages the IAC says that it cannot be measured in a prospective market situation. Surely it is obvious that one cannot do that. Yet that is the sort of test that Customs is being asked to apply. Surely, under those circumstances-this is directed to Senator MacGibbon-it is appropriate for the Government to bring that law back into this place so that we can debate a better form of words. That is what we are about. We do not stick with the words as they are simply because the court has given one interpretation of those words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter has gone off on the wrong line. It is always possible for the courts to point to defects in the legislation and it is quite proper for the Parliament to amend those changes in the light of the experience of the courts. I do not wish to pursue that any further. As I said about 10 minutes ago, I see no point, as we will not reach agreement on the report No. 416. I am still seeking an explanation from the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) as to why the Government feels it important to make these changes. The Minister said that the terms were too narrow and that that led to confusion. I would have thought that a reasonable person would have made the assumption that the more precise the definition, the less the field for confusion.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the Minister back to the whole basis of issuing tariff concession orders: they are to allow goods to come in without detriment to Australian manufacturing industry where those goods are not produced in Australia. The whole purpose of a tariff concession is to protect Australian industry and to advance it so that manufacturers can pick up components, put them with other products, make bigger units and sell them in Australian and world markets. It is very much against the interests of Australian industry to have the gateway so wide that, instead of being precise as to what good or goods can come in, a whole class of goods are allowed to come in, as this legislation proposes. I simply cannot see the logic of the Government's argument that it needs to move from a precise definition of particular goods, which are very precisely defined in legislation, to a whole class of goods, which by its very definition encompasses a whole range of things which will compete with Australian manufacturing industry to the detriment of our production.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have now understood the difference between me and Senator MacGibbon. Senator MacGibbon is saying that the definition that is now in place and for which we now have a court interpretation should stand. I am saying that the terms which are used in that definition are unsatisfactory. That has been pointed to by a number of people. The question that really should be directed to the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, is: given that the actual criteria which are used are unsatisfactory-and everybody agrees they are unsatisfactory-can the Minister suggest other terms which might be put in the place of these terms found to be unsatisfactory without broadening the ambit, which seems to concern Senator MacGibbon and a number of other people? Are there not other criteria which could be set up and put into place far more simply than the large number of amendments sought through this legislation? Has consideration been given to other criteria that might not be open to woolly interpretation? They might have the same precision that Senator MacGibbon is seeking. They might not leave the discretion so widely with the Australian Customs Service, which also seems to upset Senator MacGibbon. Are there not other criteria which could be put in place which would precisely define and which could do this job far more simply?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit surprised at the turn of this debate. The intention of the Government is not to open floodgates or indeed to strangle off possibilities of trade but to effectively capture the original intention. Because of the Corinthian Industries Federal Court case, which effectively restricts the scope of the concession order to the particular goods subject to an application, we have moved to a position of inserting guidelines, which do not propose to broaden or to constrict but to capture our original intent. The amendments will just validate the status quo. The new facility can be used as much to narrow concessions, to cover fewer goods than originally applied for, as to broaden them.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 20 (2) is a savings provision intended to validate any existing tariff concession orders which may be in doubt as a result of the Federal Court decision in Corinthian Industries (Sydney) Pty Ltd v. Comptroller-General of Customs and Others, an example being that since September 1988 the concession order was written for something wider or narrower than that applied for. The subclause treats such orders as if they were made under subsection 369c (1) of the Customs Act 1901, as proposed to be amended by this Bill. I understand the point that is being made by Senator MacGibbon and the supplementary point being made by Senator Coulter, but to view this amendment as a widening is to characterise it incorrectly. Its purpose is to meet the original intention of the Government so that the definition as interpreted, now we know what the words mean as a consequence of the Corinthian case, can be installed. That is the significance. Of course, a number of other orders are affected by the Corinthian decision and uncertainly about their fate needs to be removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -Now that the Minister has brought up the Corinthian decision and subclause 20 (2) I want to deal with those two matters. First of all, in the Corinthian judgment, which Senator Cook has said can be wider or narrower as the situation demands, the judge discussed the relationship of particular goods. The argument can be advanced that that is precisely capable in the present definition because the judge says:

SPEECH.PARA: The definition of `particular goods' in s.269b (1) makes it clear that the application need not refer to specific goods but may refer to goods included in a particular class or kind of goods.

At the end of the judgment the judge found in effect that the legislation was perfectly adequate for the intention of the Government. I will not take the time of the Committee by reading it out, but the judge in no way found that the existing legislation was deficient.

I now want to turn to clause 20 (2), since the Minister raised it and it is within the group of clauses 18 to 21 that we are discussing. What does the Minister understand that proposed amendment to mean? I take it that it means that, unless a tariff concession order is permanently revoked before the day that the Act is proclaimed, all existing tariff concession orders will stand. In what the Minister has said we have heard a little inference that the Australian Customs Service is under a lot of pressure because there are something like 150 applications a month for tariff concession orders. In correspondence with me the Customs Service has said that something like 9,000 tariff concession orders currently operate in Australia. If the Service receives 150 applications per month and 9,000 are in operation, there is no way on earth one can claim that the present scheme is unworkable.

I return to subclause 20 (2). I have asked whether that means that tariff concession orders that are in place are validated, but I think there are some other implications, as I read that subclause. I take it to mean that concession orders that have been granted thereby comply with the new legislation. I wonder why that qualification was put in the subclause because, as I understand it, the Bill does not say only that they stand there but that, by virtue of their standing there, they satisfy the requirements of the proposed changes to the Act. Is that true or false?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —We seem to be making heavy weather of this. I find the observation of Senator MacGibbon extraordinary. It is not at all unusual that a practice is engaged in in the full belief that that is the intention of the law and that it is engaged in comprehensively across the board by many people. If one individual or company then decides to read a different definition into it and takes a case to court, a court may then determine that that individual was right. We as a government need then to pay attention to whether, given that precedent that has been established, all of the existing custom and practice remains true.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case it is obvious to me that we need to amend the Customs Act in order to validate what has happened and to protect previous orders; otherwise we will be in clear breach of the precedent that has been set. If the interpretation is that the Corinthian case may only narrowly be concerned with Corinthian and no-one else and that the lessons and dicta laid down in that case do not apply more comprehensively, our view is that we would be failing in our duty if we did not pay attention to those dicta as they would apply across the board and take steps immediately to remedy the situation thrown up by the interpretation of the law. That is the intention here. It seems to me that that is good, prudent and sensible administration by a government and would be the case irrespective of what government was in power.

TALK.START.PARA: -I do not think the Minister quite understands what I am saying here. First, if his amendments are not passed, there is no threat to tariff concession orders that are already granted because that provision stays. The legislative base has not changed. I am not concerned at all, if the legislation passes, that tariff concession orders that have already been granted are to remain valid. It is commonsense that they should. I have no argument with that at all. My question is a legal one. My understanding of subclause 20 (2) is that it goes beyond saying that tariff concession orders are valid, that it goes to the point of saying that they satisfy and shall be taken to satisfy the new proposed legislation. That is the point on which I wish to have a yes or no answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is genuinely a disagreement here. It may be that that disagreement will remain in open contention in spite of my answer. If that is the case it is unfortunate, but I guess that is how life is sometimes. My advice is very strongly and very determinedly on the point that we need to make this amendment in order that the other existing orders are not open to challenge in the same way that Corinthian was. That is why subclause 20 (2) is a necessary amendment. If subclause 20 (2) were carried we would feel comfortable that the existing orders could not be challenged in the same way. As I said a moment ago, that is a necessary comfort to give to people whose future and livelihood depend on these orders operating for the smooth and ready transfer of commerce. I do not think it is right to contend, as Senator MacGibbon did in his intervention a moment ago, that those orders somehow have a life irrespective of the Corinthian decision and cannot be called into question because of that decision. Clearly, given the dicta laid down in the Corinthian decision, if those precedents were used in an application under another law, we may well have the same outcome.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner we were talking about clause 20 (2). I had made the point that I really was not concerned about the provision that is in that to validate the tariff concession orders that have already been granted and to carry them forward in the future. That was not the point. The point that I was seeking an explanation of is that part of the subclause (2) which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that order is taken to be, and always to have been, as effective as if the amendments made by this Act had been in force at the time it was made or purportedly made.

My reading of that is that, in effect, it is saying that the tariff concession orders which are in place and which are carried forward to the future are held to satisfy the conditions of the proposed legislation which will become the Act. My reason for asking that is that, while the great majority of existing tariff concession orders are defined with precision, if one looks at the schedule of concessional instruments from tariff concession orders-I was looking at some during dinner-one finds that the goods are described in three columns. There is a tariff reference on the left, a description of goods in the centre and then a prescribed item and validity date, which does not concern us, on the right.

Am I right in the interpretation that those concessions that are carried forward are taken to satisfy the Act and, if that is so, what is the legal part of the existing tariff concession orders? Are the tariff reference column and the description of goods linked to form a legal unit or, under the new legislation, will it only be the descriptions of goods, or the tariff reference, that is carried forward?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

Review of decisions

One of the deficiencies in part XVA is that there are no appeal provisions other than under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. Those appeals can be based only on the grounds of a narrow interpretation of law. It is possible to make an appeal to the Industries Assistance Commission, as has been instanced in the early part of the debate. TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendment. We ask the Committee to note that there are three avenues of review available in the particular circumstances we are talking about. Firstly, we have the normal internal Customs review. Secondly, we have the capacity for a reference by the Minister to the Industry Commission, as it now is known, for review of the question of whether an order should have been made or revoked. Thirdly, and most importantly, we have the capacity for judicial review in the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The process of administrative review of decisions taken under the proposed legislation, before the amendments, basically is the same as presently exists in respect of decisions under the current scheme. I refer here to part XVA of the Customs Act. Basically we are saying, firstly, that there are three avenues of review. Secondly, if we are looking at decisions such as this, we really should be looking at maintaining consistency with the rest of the Customs Act.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the argument which has been put to us, essentially we are talking about making available for merit review decisions under the commercial tariff concession scheme (CTCS) by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal process. We maintain quite strongly-and previous governments have also taken this view-that where we are talking about decisions such as merit review of industry policy decisions, it is quite appropriate for the independent review to be done by a recommendatory body rather than by what has been proposed by Senator MacGibbon.

It should be noted that since the introduction in 1983 of the CTCS there have been just under 10,000 concession orders in existence and only two have been referred to the IAC for merit review. I ask the Committee to note, again, that not only has this been the policy of this Government, but it also has been the policy of previous governments. It is a policy that has been well grounded. In July 1982 the report of the IAC that we have a recommendatory system in this area was supported by the Liberal Government of the day. Not only that, the Administrative Review Council in its recommendations made very much the same sort of point, that we should stick to a recommendatory review process.

In essence, we are saying, firstly, that there are three systems of review available already. Secondly, the decisions that are being canvassed in this area are more appropriate. Given the fact that they go to merit review of government policy making and industry policy decisions, it is more appropriate for a recommendatory body to make an assessment of them. In that respect, it is most appropriate that we maintain the current system of review.

I repeat the point that not only has this process been embodied in the Act, but also it has been embodied on advice from, amongst other quarters, the IAC and the Administrative Review Council. I also ask the Committee to note that it is not just this Government that is doing it; it is a policy that has been consistently held by this and previous governments. I refer once again to the July 1982 decision of the previous government. The Government does not support the amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1989OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 November 1989 and 14 December 1989, on motions by Senators Walsh and Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three Bills are to be debated together in the Senate this evening. The first is the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1989, the second the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, and the third Bill, which was introduced in the chamber only this morning, is the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. I will refer to the least complicated Bill first, the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill. The Bill enacts some minor but necessary amendments required to be made to the Overseas Students Charge Act to make the Act consistent with the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989, which will be proclaimed next Tuesday, 19 December. Accordingly, the Bill is urgent. It is unexceptional. The Opposition supports it. The Bill is in a separate form because the Overseas Students Charge Act is a tax Act and so its amendment must be subject to a separate Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill is of considerable substance and was considered in the other place in October. In the second reading speech, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding) summarised the measure in these words:
The primary purpose of this Bill is to amend various Commonwealth Acts as a consequence of provisions of the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989 . . . which amends the Migration Act 1958.

The Bill also makes a number of other minor amendments to the Amendment Act. The majority of the amendments, update terminology, make slight changes in wording or correct internal references within the Amendment Act. The Minister has said:

It is inevitable in the case of legislation as complex as the Amendment Act that some minor corrections will be necessary. Several amendments then are made because of the complexity of the original Act and various omissions and misstatements now require correction.

I am glad that the Minister has referred to the complexity of the Act. It is not only the legislation and the Act itself that is complex, because there have in fact been these four Bills before us over the past six months which have totally transformed Australian law with regard to immigration.

The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill was determined in May and June this year. The Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill was debated in the House of Representatives in October and is being debated here this evening, with the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989; and the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 was introduced in here this morning. All of these four bills will be brought together and there will be a great deal of renumbering involved in putting all of these amendments together into one coherent set of legislation next week. But, in addition, there are the regulations and, because of the way in which this legislation is composed, all of Australia's immigration policies and programs, indeed the whole operation of the Department and its procedures, are determined in the regulations.

Firstly, there are regulations in transition from the existing regulations under the Act. Secondly, there are new machinery regulations covering the operation of a completely restructured and enlarged Act. Thirdly, there are new compliance regulations covering illegal entrants and custody, apprehension, deportation and prosecution of offenders under the Act, and many of those procedures are quite new. Fourthly, there are new procedure regulations covering the concept of the status of the visa system and the entry permit system. A new distinction is being introduced by the regulations in the Act. Fifthly, there is a whole set of regulations-literally hundreds-that define the new immigration criteria. They cover all of the precise criteria that define scores of different types of visa and entry permit categories. Included in this is the new points system and the pooling selection system which will operate for the first time from next week. Also covered by these criteria are some forms of visas that must be very flexibly defined. They are important visas, nevertheless, in the form of humanitarian and refugee entry permits. Until recently it was not guaranteed that the way in which those regulations were expressed was not ultra vires the Bill that we adopted earlier this year.

Finally, there are completely new reviewed regulations which cover the new Immigration Review Tribunal, which again will be established next week. The procedures that that tribunal will follow will also be established. It is fair to summarise the situation by saying that if the Act is complex, the regulations are 10 times as substantial and complex. So we have before us tonight an enormous amount of new legislation. Next week we will see the Minister publish in the Commonwealth Gazette and no doubt table in this Parliament the regulations from all of the categories that I have outlined. However, up to this point none of the regulations have been made public. No-one who has a direct concern in an immigration application, let alone those groups of persons more habitually and professionally involved in giving immigration advice, has of right as a member of the public seen the regulations. They will not be released until next Tuesday. For completeness, as I understand it, all the regulations that will be published next Tuesday will be reissued two days later in a completely renumbered order so as to fit the variety of amending Bills that I described earlier and which are expected to be adopted by them. Next week, even for the experts, there will be an enormous array of Bills, regulations and renumberings, and perhaps by 1 January there will be one consolidated set of statutes and regulations. So the matter is highly complex, and the public has not seen the vital part-that is, the regulations.

I will come back to that important deficiency because even now, although Senator Jenkins, who follows me in this debate, and I have been appointed by the Senate to the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations, which has met perhaps 20 times in the last 30 days-and Senator McKiernan, who is sitting across the chamber, is also a member-we are unable to disclose the deliberations of that Committee. Two of our major reports have gone to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), and we are looking forward to his tabling those reports, together with his, I trust, positive responses, next week; and if not the full reports, then the responses to those specific and positive suggestions and recommendations that the Committee has made to him.

The Opposition has the gravest reservations about how this whole process has been managed. We are critical of the haste. If the Minister in his eventual response to this debate says that six months is not haste, I will still use the word `haste', because it has been very evident that the first draft of the regulations was available only at the beginning of November and we are seeing them promulgated only some six or seven weeks later, even if, with a number of contributions from parliamentarians and the Department itself, they have gone through second, third and fourth drafts in those six or seven weeks. There has been haste, and we in the Opposition are not confident that it will all come out in a sensible and integrated way. I know that the Minister must profess that he has confidence that it will, but I do not have that confidence, and neither does the Opposition.

We are likely to see unintended consequences. Again, the Minister will give a quick response that he will seek, as genuinely as possible no doubt, to remedy those unintended consequences by changes to the regulations as soon as they become clearly established, but even next week there may be some public alarm either at some particular elements of the regulations-at those few items of new policy that the Minister may make when releasing the regulations-or just in the first-look confusion at the complexity of events that will occur in the coming week.

These outcomes are the responsibility of the Minister and the Labor Government. The Opposition, for its part, has insisted that the Government agree to the establishment of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Migration Regulations. Honourable senators would know that to set up such a committee is rather an unusual step. It is certainly not a standing committee of the Parliament, but it is not one which we think is going to last only for these two months; it will have a continuing life well through the coming year. Even with a change of government next year, there will be a need for such a parliamentary committee to review regulations because of their immense effect upon Australia's immigration policy and programs.

Secondly, the Opposition expresses its lack of confidence that the whole scheme of the Act, the regulations and the manual for the Department's use will be ready to operate from next week. In the light of that, we strongly urged the Minister three weeks ago-on 24 November to be precise, when the House of Representatives was still here and could deal with an amending Bill-to bring in a separate Bill that would amend section 4 of the Act to give the necessary flexibility to delay the operation of the new law if it was necessary. My colleague Philip Ruddock, the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, wrote to the Minister in the following terms:

. . . I believe that for more abundant precaution it might be appropriate that you give consideration to an amendment to section 4 to enable the proclamation to be deferred for a further period by regulation.

In that way the matter would still be in your hands but it would mean that if for any reason the new administrative arrangements you contemplate are unable to be put in place you would then be in a position to ensure that existing administrative arrangements remain in place and our immigration program is not interrupted.
It seems to me that this decision should be made and a judgment formed at a point closer to a date for implementation of the new administrative arrangements.

These comments are not meant as any reflection on the competence of your professional officers who I believe have endeavoured to draft the regulations on very tight deadlines. However it is a pity that a good deal more work had not commenced on the regulations before the Migration Legislation Amendment Act came before the Parliament.
