My concern still remains that the range of possible defects in this new regulatory framework is such that a good deal more public exposure for comment would be a more desirable way to proceed.

That was the view of the Opposition; it is still the view of the Opposition. Whilst we were not, by agreeing to support such an amending Bill, insisting that the Minister defer the Bill, we wanted him to have the option, the power, so that any defects that remained on 19 December, or even a week or two or three weeks after that, could be remedied in time for the new integrated approach to migration law to start on a sound basis. We certainly wish the Act and regulations well. That is why we have all been working so positively to that end. I notice Senator Collins, another member of the parliamentary committee, has come into the chamber.

To summarise these points, I give the Opposition's assurance that we will continue to be vigilant next week and all the following weeks and to be responsive to sound representations from all around Australia. We will respond in three particular ways: first, through our active involvement in the parliamentary committee; secondly, through our policy initiatives which, if necessary, we will take to the coming federal election and implement in government; and, thirdly, more urgently than that, perhaps in the days when we return for the sitting of the Senate in February and March, by considering the use of the power in this Senate to disallow regulations on a sitting day if we regard those regulations as still defective and in need of remedy.

To complete my remarks on the Consequential Amendment Bill I will refer briefly to some particular provisions, all of which are improvements to the legislation and all of which the Opposition supports. The Bill provides that regulations may be made that will prescribe matters to be considered in the making of decisions concerning discretionary deportation orders. Also, these regulations affirm the essential feature of the Amendment Act, namely the separation of processes of selection, based on the criteria in the regulations, from the processes of expulsion, which matter is in the hands of the officers whose responsibility is compliance with decisions of the Minister. That is a proper separation which the Opposition supports.

There is also provision in the Bill to enable prompt and efficient granting of visas in respect of a select set of visas where the normal procedure would be administratively burdensome. There is also a provision in the Bill to make sure that the point system is sufficiently broad to permit its proper operation. There is also a provision to clarify the definition of custody in the meaning of the compliance aspects of the Act. There is also a provision that puts beyond doubt the consequences of escape from custody. There is a strengthening of the intention already in the Act to ensure that persons who hold valid entry visas are properly treated as holders of valid entry permits and are not, for technical reasons, deemed illegal entrants.

The Bill provides for the possibility for endorsements to be entered on visas and entry permits. It also provides for the making of regulations in regard to imposing fees for English language tests and for a better definition of certain proof provisions which will apply in criminal deportation proceedings. Another provision will amend a number of Commonwealth Acts, in addition to the Bill that was passed last June, that are consequential upon the passing of the amending Bills now before us. There are some other provisions of a technical nature to ensure that the legislation is complete.

Of all these provisions of the Bill, one of the significant matters concerns the power to make regulations for, and the prescription in the regulations of matters to be considered in, the deportation of illegal entrants. Since the original debate in May and June the Opposition has urged that these procedures be carefully and specifically defined to ensure natural justice, that the rights of applicants be preserved and that sound and accountable procedures be followed. The Opposition has been particularly concerned where circumstances of a compassionate or humanitarian kind are involved-for example, the circumstances of refugees. Accordingly, we welcome this provision in the amending Act to make regulations. However, the regulations themselves have yet to be announced and have not been seen by the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations. This whole provision depends upon these regulations. We are very conscious that the Minister has, nevertheless, understood our requests through all these months and we accept his assurance that the specific requirements that we have urged will be in these regulations next week. We will then examine them carefully. With these reservations about the subsequent and dependent regulations themselves, the Opposition supports the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1989.

I now turn more briefly to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, which was introduced this morning and which is much easier to deal with. The Opposition has called for and supports the measures which are provided in the Bill. In May, June, October, November and December-at all stages of this year's debates on immigration legislation-the Opposition has maintained some strong recurring themes. They are these: The elected government of the day, and not the department, should be actively responsible and accountable for all aspects of immigration policy and the operation and management of the immigration programs. There should not be a fudging of that responsibility to an anonymous departmental officer acting upon the, however tightly expressed, Act and regulations. Rather, the Minister should be actively responsible and accountable for everything that happens in the immigration program.

Another theme is that the Minister must retain responsible flexibility to make decisions in cases where compassion and fairness ought to require the Minister's intervention. A third theme that has been recurring in the Opposition's view is that the new legal framework to be determined by the principal amending Act and the new comprehensive regulations must preserve not only announced Government policy but also the longstanding practices of the Minister and the Department to deal with individual cases of merit, despite such cases not easily fitting the complex of definitions required by the criteria for granting visas and entry permits in the great majority of circumstances. In brief, the Opposition has all along insisted that the new migration law must retain ministerial responsibility and flexibility for the Minister to intervene favourably where compassionate and humane considerations require it.

Accordingly, for want of these features in the original Bill last May, the Opposition decided then to reject the Bill. The legislation was revived later that month when significant changes to meet the Opposition's views-these things that I have expressed-were introduced. For example, the word `Minister' was substituted for `Secretary' wherever it occurred in the original Bill. Particular attention was given to section 64u, which now provides for the Minister to intervene to favour an application and so reverse a decision of the Department and reverse a decision even of the Review Tribunal. Also, the Minister has now given an undertaking to monitor all the regulations continually, but especially in the first months and first year of operation, in order to add or amend regulations so that their effect is to gain the objectives intended and to ensure that justice and compassion are reflected in the operation of the regulations to the greatest extent practicable.

The Opposition welcomed this assurance of the Minister, but all of these changes still had not satisfied us. Thus we come to the Bill. Thus, to be more complete, we called for and now have before us the measures that are in this Bill. What does it provide? It provides, through new additions to section 61, that the Minister for immigration may exercise the power set out in section 64u to intervene in an applicant's favour at an earlier stage of the processing of an application. Whenever this early intervention is exercised, the Minister must meet two extra accountability requirements, that is, the Minister must report his intervening decision to Parliament and he must set out the reasons for his decision, attesting it to be in the public interest. These two requirements of section 61 are already established in the Act for the section 64 interventions, which can be made only after the Review Tribunal's consideration is determined. What we then have is a fast track version of section 64u. It provides a short cut for the Minister, but a short cut that is responsibly defined and requiring much greater accountability to Parliament, a short cut for the Minister to intervene favourably for an applicant and so have the capacity to act humanely, compassionately and justly where, in the Minister's discretion, the particular circumstances of the application warrant such a decision.

Had this amending Bill not been presented, then I and my Opposition colleagues predicted that there would be many instances arising where the Minister would be hog-tied by his own law. The Minister would have found himself genuinely sympathetic with an immigration application but would have been prevented by the Act and regulations from varying the normal logic of decision by his Department and the first tier of review within his Department. Moreover, had the Minister been confined to the 64u provision, he would have had to wait perhaps 12 months, until after the third stage of the Review Tribunal's determination, before being able to intervene. Many cases arise which are much more urgent than the section 64u provision would allow, hence the fast-track approach of proposed new section 61 in this Bill.

The Bill before us places two additional provisions in section 61 and in a new section 64u. These make explicit what the Act has until now put forward as implicit. Firstly, the Minister is not compelled to use the power of intervention. The Minister does not have a `duty', as the Act puts it, to intervene and this prevents appeals to the court which might have sought to use this as a ground to try to wrest the court's judgment in the place of the Minister's. The Opposition supports this protection for the Minister's decision. Secondly, the Minister is not able to intervene where to do so would be contrary to other provisions in the Act itself. That is explicitly set out in sections 61 and 64u as proposed in the Bill.

With regard to the Tribunal, the new procedure as set out in clause 3 (b) of the Bill makes clear that, where this fast-track intervention by the Minister leads to determination of an application, the applicant does not have the normal ability to appeal to the Review Tribunal. The Opposition notes the comments of the Minister in the second reading speech on this matter that he will be monitoring this to see whether there is not some need in certain circumstances for a review to be able to be made to the Tribunal. The Opposition supports those remarks and would want to see that monitoring enhanced and, where necessary, adjustments made.

I refer finally to the public interest definition that the Minister made in his second reading speech. This has been of concern to the Opposition because we would not want a narrow interpretation to be given to the term `public interest' so as to negate compassionate and human considerations of a particular individual or that person's family. But the Minister has rightly given a very broad meaning to the term `public interest', and that is certainly welcomed by the Opposition. In conclusion, I note that the Minister referred in part of his speech this morning to the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations but he has not yet referred-no doubt he will next Tuesday-to this whole Bill being suggested to him by that Committee. I believe that that acknowledgment is not only factually correct but is appropriate to be made in this debate because it has been one of the very positive outcomes of the all party deliberations of that Committee. In brief, the Opposition supports all of the Bills before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating three Bills, the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1989. Two of these Bills are consequential amendments to the Migration Legislation Amendment Act which was passed by this Senate in May of this year, while the third Bill is the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. I will address my first remarks to the two consequential amendment Bills. The Australian Democrats regard the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989, passed earlier this year, as a disastrous piece of legislation. In the committee stage I will be moving some amendments which, if passed, would remove some of the undes- irable features of that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the greatest of the many defects of that legislation was the attempt to codify-almost to automate-migration decisions as if to remove all discretion from those responsible for those decisions. Those who have framed the legislation-the Government, which introduced it, and the coalition Opposition, which ensured its passage-seem to have forgotten that we are dealing with human beings here; we are dealing with people's lives. Human beings and human circumstances exhibit an almost infinite range of variation. People simply do not fit neatly into a limited number of pigeonholes or categories. If we try to simplify and codify the process of making decisions about human beings beyond a certain point, we are led into creating a mass of rules and regulations which will inevitably confuse the issue, lead to gross injustices and bring about inefficiency instead of the very efficiency which was the aim of the exercise in the first place.

That is what I believe the Government has achieved with its migration legislation. The Migration Act 1958, as amended, was an already lengthy and complex document. It was widely regarded as out of date and difficult to use. The Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies recommended a complete rewrite of the Act, and that was that we all believed the Government would do. But the Government rejected this recommendation and, instead, the Migration Legislation Amendment Act added approaching 100 pages of amendments to the old Act. The legislation is to be further elaborated by way of regulations which are provided for in it.

When the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 came before the Senate these amendments were unavailable to the Senate for scrutiny and, six months later, the Senate still has not seen them, although the Department for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has been hard at work preparing its manuals. Indeed, as Senator Teague stated earlier, the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations has also been hard at work with its review of the regulations which were made available to it. The new regulations are due to take effect from 19 December, in just five days time. I gather, from the questions I have been asked by the media recently, and from a letter which was written by the Minister to the Chairman of the Committee on Migration Regulations, that it is the Minister's contention that the Australian Democrats are responsible for the rush to implement the Migration Legislation Amendment Act as from 19 December. However, the Government's own drafting instructions state that although it is the Government's preference for legislation to be proclaimed no later than six months after passing through the Parliament, nonetheless the Minister has the option of a later date provided there is a suitable reason. I would have thought that very complex legislation which depends on very complex and numerous regulations would provide such a reason. Paragraph 5.8a of the drafting instructions state:

As a general rule, the commencement clause for Acts which commence on proclamation should provide a specific date, or a specific period after royal assent (such as six months). Where preparatory work is required before an Act commences, a realistic assessment should be made of the time required to complete the preparations and a specific date or a specific period after royal assent for commencement included in the drafting instructions . . . an explanation for choosing that commencement must be included in the notes on clauses in the explanatory memorandum . . . Where an unusually long period of time for that commencement has been included (for example-longer than 6 months after royal assent), an explanation should be included of why this period has been chosen.

I believe that the Minister, and possibly the Department, did not realise at the time how complex the regulations would have to be in order to codify the whole of the immigration legislation in the way that it has been. I really believe that the complexity was not foreseen. However, having said that, I believe that once the complexity was realised, and the inevitable delay was realised in having draft regulations available, the Minister should have considered changing the date for implementation. It may well be that there is confusion concerning the motion moved by Senator Macklin on 29 November 1988, which stated:

That there be laid on the Table of the Senate, on or before 31 May and 30 November each year, details of all provisions of Acts which come into effect on proclamation and which have not been proclaimed, together with a statement of reasons for their non-proclamation and a timetable for their operation.

That motion resulted in a number of Acts coming before the Senate which had not been proclaimed. Therefore, it was decided that Acts preferably should be proclaimed within six months, if that were at all possible.

The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) amends section 26 of the principal Act with regard to the Minister's discretionary powers. Section 64u, as it stands, provides that the Minister can overturn the decision of the Immigration Review Tribunal in a way that is favourably disposed towards the applicant. The Australian Democrats applaud the definition that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has introduced as far as the term `public interests' is concerned. The Minister, in his second reading speech, stated:

The term `public interest' is not limited solely to public issues. Consideration of the public interest could involve consideration of the circumstances of the particular case having regard to an unusual, unforseen or other features that are deserving of a favourable response against the background of Australia being a compassionate and humane society.
I applaud the Minister for including in his second reading speech the definition of the term `public interest'. He also said:
Concern has been expressed at the time it will take for a case to proceed through each tier of review before the Minister can use the power contained in section 64u.

The amendments in this Bill will meet these concerns and enable such urgent cases to be decided by the Minister at an earlier stage of the process. When the Minister reviews these cases, and finds in favour, he must table in the Parliament the reasons for doing so. I am also encouraged by the Minister's statement that the Government will keep under review those cases where the Minister's decision was more favourable than the first tier review decision with a view to determining whether review by the Immigration Review Tribunal should be available in some circumstances. Although I have been extremely critical of the Bill as a whole, I commend the Minister and the Department for making some amendments at this late stage which will soften the impact of the legislation which has disturbed not only some of us here in the Senate but also people in the wider community.

What we have in this new Bill is a discretionary power of the Minister, which is what we asked for earlier and what I tried to have included in the legislation when it went through the Senate last May. That discretionary power is needed. There will be need at times for a fast-track urgent decision to be made for compassionate reasons. We have all heard of cases of a terminal illness and where a person literally has no time to wait for a decision to take a year or even two years. The Australian Democrats have some reservations with regard to review by the Immigration Review Tribunal not being available in these circumstances, but would not want to jeopardise in any way the facility for a genuine, urgent case to be fast tracked by means of ministerial discretion.

As with the discretionary power to overturn decisions of the Immigration Review Tribunal and substitute a decision, more favourable to the applicant, likewise when fast tracked and overturning a first tier review officer's decisions to a more favourable one to the applicant, the Minister must table his reasons in both Houses of Parliament-in this instance, twice a year. This has the advantage for the Parliament to see how many fast-track decisions have been made in favour of the applicant and whether there is a consistency in changes of decision. If that were the case, the determining factors, as legislated and regulated for, should be reviewed and possibly changed. I know that the Minister has this in mind because he has stated on more than one occasion that he will be keeping the process and procedures of the new immigration Act with its regulations under scrutiny. The Australian Democrats believe that to be consistent the Minister should also give the number of fast track appeals which he reviewed and did not decide favourably for the applicant, together with a statement giving a summary of the reasons for his decisions. In this way we will start to have some idea of how the whole thing is working.

I now turn my attention to the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill, which also refines the migration legislation of May earlier this year. This legislation is basically a tidying up Bill. It deals with refinements which the Government wishes to make to the major package of migration legislation. At this stage I thank the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs for providing a copy of the consolidated immigration Act. As I said before, the 1958 Act has been amended so many times, and we have also amended the amendments so many times that it makes it difficult to cope with. At last we have a consolidated Act of the old section which went from No. 1 to No. 67, including en route bizarre numbers such as 11za through to 11zl, and 64a through to 64zz. Blissfully, the new numbering simply goes from 1 to 181. It is a blessed relief to cope with.

Nonetheless, the consolidated migration legislation will undoubtedly stand as a monument to bureaucratic obfuscation. I suspect that Opposition members who were on the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations have begun to realise over the last few weeks what a monstrosity it helped the Government to create. If they find themselves in government after the coming election I predict that they will come to curse their decision to support the present Government's approach relatively uncritically-and certainly wholeheartedly if we turn back to read their speeches on the second reading.

There are some most unfortunate aspects in the legislation. One, I believe, is the provision for two types of deportation: mandatory deportation of illegal immigrants, and deportation of illegal immigrants. I asked a question in the Senate some days ago about a well-known presumed illegal immigrant who is on trial in Victoria. My understanding of the legislation is that, if that individual is found to be an illegal immigrant 28 days after the proclamation of the legislation and it is deemed that he should have a deportation order placed on him under section 17a, after this period of grace expires the Minister would have no option other than to deport him from Australia, which could save his facing many charges on counts covering many millions of dollars.

Perhaps the Minister in his response or during the committee stage will be able to explain to this chamber when a deportation order under section 17a will be applied, and when deportation under section 18 will be applied and what discretion, if any, there is in that. If there is discretion in that the Minister can decide whether to place on a person a mandatory non-revokable deportation order or a deportation order that is revokable, we need to know why and what the criteria will be. It is for that reason that my first amendment seeks to delete from the Act section 17a. As I said, the Minister can deport a person from Australia under section 18. There is nothing to prevent his deporting whomsoever he wants under that section. If the Minister put a 17a deportation order on a person and then found that circumstances had changed or that there was something about the circumstances he was not aware of, he would be faced with the difficult choice of deciding whether to deport the individual or break his own law by neglecting to make the decision to do so. As I stated earlier, this could cause all sorts of problems.

Whether or not such an application would succeed-that is, if a person preferred to have a 17a deportation order on him and put the Minister in a position where he would have to deport him and the Minister did not, and this was tested in the courts-I am certainly not in a position to speculate about. But I am not happy with the possibility of a government putting itself in a position where it could treat its own laws with complete contempt, applying the full rigour of them when it felt like doing so-this would be very dangerous in politically sensitive or embarrassing cases-or ignoring them when that course of action suited it.

The Department has a history of being a law unto itself. It has a poor reputation with some of its clients, a situation which has been around for some years. The Commonwealth Ombudsman commented in his annual report on the very high level of complaints he received against decisions of the Department of Immigration.

Senator Ray once thanked me for saying that the Immigration portfolio was a verit- able ministerial graveyard. Since I came to the Senate 2 1/2 years ago, I have been the Democrats spokesman for immigration and ethnic affairs and Senator Ray is the third Minister that I have shadowed in that short time. I believe that there is unfortunate resentment in the community as a result of the new immigration Bill, and I hope that the resentment which is out there will not build up in the way it seems to be doing at the moment. There is a fear that people affected will feel the force of cold and cruel legislation. This, I feel, is most unfortunate. But, of course, for the rich, under the new rules, all will be well. Those who have enough cash, however it has been accumulated, will continue to be able to buy Australian residence and, therefore, citizenship. Other wealthy individuals will be able to cope with some of the harsh requirements and weave their way through the complex system of permits and visas, paying the appropriate fees at each step of the way and able to return overseas while they await the outcome of change of status decisions.

I feel that someone who has been in Australia and has illegal status may or may not be aware of their status. We have examples of people who came into this country perhaps, under a fiance visa. It would have been stated on their visa that they would be able to stay provided they married the person named on that visa within three months. They may have done that. That may have been some years ago. They may have thought that, having done that, they had fulfilled all the obligations and were here perfectly legally. But once this legislation comes into force on 19 December, if they have not in the meantime reported to the Department then those persons, as I see it, will be illegal entrants and subject to deportation.

I believe that the Government plans to place advertisements in the newspapers after 19 December warning people that the legislation has changed and that they have limited time to report to the Department. I ask the Minister what will happen to people who either do not see those advertisements or are not aware that those advertisements refer to them. We had an example in the Senate of a senator who was not aware that he was not an Australian citizen. It is possible for people who have been in this country for years and who have families and businesses here not to be aware of that fact. I will be very interested in the Minister's response to that.

I will move a second reading amendment. I am doing this out of a feeling of frustration. If I were in a position to change the date of implementation of this legislation, I would certainly do so but as I see it I am not in that position. We put ourselves on this fast express train last May and there is no getting off at this stage. That is to be regretted because the legislation will come into force next Tuesday. We will see the regulations as they stand next Tuesday. Immigration officers will have to apply the legislation and those regulations as from next Tuesday, so there is no way out at present. It is for that reason that I move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1989:

At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for setting in motion the process of making complex and weighty Migration Amendment Legislation which depends heavily on Regulations, which are themselves equally complex and weighty, without first giving the Parliament a proper opportunity to scrutinise and approve those Regulations''.

It appears that the Senate has a new view as far as regulations are concerned. Just a couple of days ago the Senate when considering health legislation dealing with nursing homes determined that the legislation should not be proclaimed until the regulations on which it depends heavily have been passed by both Houses of Parliament. I have previously described the system of having legislation which depends heavily on regulations as being basically an undemocratic system. My experience with the current migration legislation does not make me move from the stance.

I refer briefly to the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2). This Bill amends the Overseas Students Charge Act as a consequence of the provisions of the Migration Legislation Amendment Act. The amendments in the Bill are of a purely technical nature. However, I will make a few remarks with regard to overseas students. In yesterday's Australian there was an article headed, `Overseas student intake at risk'. The writer of the article, Jane Worthington, described a lack of cohesion within various government departments as regards full fee paying overseas students and said that overseas student councils yesterday warned that capricious changes in government policy regarding overseas students could cause Australia to lose its market share to Canada and New Zealand.

With respect to our overseas students, Australia has a history of having set things up very hastily in the early 1980s and of not having learned from the early experience in the United Kingdom, where students went to schools which did not always operate in the best possible way. The industry there was poorly regulated and the result was that the market became flooded by all sorts of fly-by-night and exploitative entrepreneurs who ran courses in cheap and unsuitable premises, employed unqualified teachers, and did their utmost to rip as much money out of the foreign students as possible. The result was that the whole industry in Britain developed a very bad name and, as I understand it, for a time the bottom dropped out of the market. I would not like to see that happen in Australia, although I must say that the situation in recent months has not been a happy one. We have had the occurrence in Perth of a private college going broke and closing its doors, greatly inconveniencing students enrolled for both current and future courses, who have not been able to have their fees refunded. I make those remarks in the hope that the Minister will also respond to those, because I regard that as a serious situation.

When we have overseas students in this country it is important that we give them the correct education to which they are entitled, qualified staff and proper premises. Of course, one of the problems in the past has been that being an overseas student in this country has been a mode of illegal entry. Here again, I think that the Department has been at fault because check-ups have not been done on these people in the right way. I suppose there is a fine line between over-checking on people and that being regarded as the bureaucracy gone mad and people being able to come in, enrol in courses, not turn up to classes at all and disappear into the beyond, therefore becoming illegal entrants to Australia.

In conclusion, I believe that we are stuck with this legislation. I believe that it can be improved through the amendments that I will move in the committee stage and I hope to have Opposition support for my amendments. In the meantime, I think it is up to all of us who are involved in this process to try to improve the quality of the regulations as best we can, although I very much fear what will happen when those regulations see the light of day this coming Tuesday. Everything is rather back to front because the regulations will be made public on Tuesday and then there will be full public debate and scrutiny. So potentially we have a situation whereby we have legislation and its dependent regulations coming into being in a few days time with the possibility of them being disallowed at a later date. That is not a happy situation at all and I believe this gives unnecessary uncertainty to the whole immigration process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) concludes the debate, I would like to speak very briefly to the amendment that has been moved by the Australian Democrats. It is the Opposition's view that where regulations are so overwhelmingly significant to the operation of an Act, as is the case in this legislation, then those regulations should be tabled in draft form in Parliament to allow sufficient time for adequate public consultation, in the same way as the introduction of significant legislation itself should proceed after a period that allows for public consultation. Another current example of this type are the health regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: The operative part of the Democrats' second reading amendment is the final clause, which states:
. . . without first giving the Parliament a proper opportunity to scrutinise those regulations.
This clause affirms the principle to which I have referred. For this reason the Opposition condemns the Government's failure and supports the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that I get up in the Senate and admit that I am a fool, but I must be. Fancy being foolish enough to want to transpose migration policy and migration direction, over which this Parliament had no scrutiny whatsoever, into law. I must have been mad to take that desperate step to make it publicly accountable and clear to everyone, rather than the old Byzantine system of direction by the Minister, where the Minister is equivalent to Kublai Khan and can change policy at a moment's whim, can jump the points up by 10 or 20 points overnight and can close categories overnight without this Parliament being able to say boo to a goose. I must have been a mug to do that, because it was a long and complex task over which we knew we would cop punishment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that the greatest critics of this legislation in the human rights field and the law field have never once acknowledged this fact, even though they put this up as the number one priority in all their submissions to the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policy. But never once have they acknowledged since it has gone through that it was a good idea to make all migration decisions and criteria accountable in law. I will come back to Senator Jenkins's second reading amendment later.

I correct something that Senator Teague said because I think he assumed that I am going to make public the observations-not the report-of the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations. I make it quite clear that the agreed process was that that Committee was to give me its observations by 21 November. That did not prove possible. I did not kick up at all. I extended the deadline even though the Parliament had dictated otherwise, and waited. I got it in two volumes, and no doubt I will get another volume-and I have no hesitation in saying that I welcome that. My job then involves a three-stage process. Some of those observations have already been absorbed into the regulations. Some of the more complex ones will be absorbed into the regulations over the next few months. I will also tell the Committee quite clearly which ones I totally reject. So it will be that sort of a process. Five sitting days after the regulations are tabled here, it is then the Committee's duty to report to this Parliament on the progress up to that time, and it is at that point that the Committee's observations and report will become public. I think that is a sensible process.

Senator Jenkins apparently does not place as much weight on the Macklin motion for deadlines as I and my Department do, because if my Department had thought some time ago that it would have a longer period to draw up these regulations it would have done, but we observed what we thought was a direction of this Senate for a six-month deadline. I will come back to that point later. I make the point, because it has been too misinterpreted, that the regulations that will come into force at one minute past midnight on 19 December are not holy writ, nor should they be. They are so lengthy and complex that there will be flaws in them, and we acknowledge that. Especially once they are in working order and are able to be tested as a working system, we will remain totally flexible and open about changing them to make them work appropriately. I think that is best seen in practice.

Senator Teague in a clever way-and I do not blame him-said that this is all the responsibility of the Government. I take that responsibility. We are doers; we are not going to wimp out, we are not going to avoid doing anything because we are afraid of criticism. We have taken that responsibility. We will take some criticism over it, but I guarantee Senator Teague that at the end of the day it will be a better, fairer and more equitable process than has existed in the last 30 years. There is no question about that.

We were asked at one stage to defer the Bill. There was a practical problem with that. When I got that particular request we were tied up in the Appropriation Bill committee stage in this chamber and House of Representatives legislation was under guillotine. The only possible way to go was to amend one of these consequential Bills and, with the House of Representatives not coming back until 21 or 22 December, any amendment to the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendment) Bill other than on the second reading sinks the Bill because it must come into force prior to the regulations and the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) being proclaimed. So it would not have been possible to do it that particular way because if I had not promulgated the regulations by 19 December the Bill would have been proclaimed, and if the regulations did not come into force no one could be admitted to Australia. By the time the queue had got right round to the domestic terminal, I think the Opposition would have given in and said, `Yes, we can put a regulation through'.

TALK.START.PARA: —A fresh Bill in the House of Representatives on 28 November would have been all right.

—A fresh Bill on 28 November was a possibility, but all these things have to go through some sort of process, through party rooms, et cetera. It was hard enough getting this other Bill through that we all agree on universally, and we would not have agreed on that Bill universally.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague said that the Government should be accountable. I agree with that. But I also say that we should be accountable under the law. There is nothing wrong with the Government being accountable under the law. Honourable senators opposite continually talk about compassion and fairness, but never on one occasion when we have had this debate in the chamber has any honourable senator defined compassion or fairness, much less ranked it and said, `How are we going to have any sort of criteria on which to assess it?'. One person's view of compassion and fairness differs from another person's view. When I have hundreds of officers overseas, it is my duty to see that they apply consistent criteria. How can I rely on their compassion and fairness being doled out in equal doses? After all, Senator Jenkins talked about human nature. That is a major difficulty. That is why, as much as possible, one makes the primary selection criteria objective and measurable.

In one instance in our history 110,000 people were admitted to this country by application to a Minister's office. Most drug pushers got in in that one year than during the rest of the years put together. Such a deluge simply cannot be handled. We have had ministerial intervention without any accountability. I think everyone acknowledges that that major problem is rectified in both the legislation and the consequential legislation. A Minister will not be going out and spending $1.5m to deport a drug pusher and, after all that money has been spent, have his colleague come in the next day and write one word on the form-`admit' with a signature. We will do away with this business of marginal seat candidates trooping into a succession of Labor and Liberal Ministers and saying, `I must get this case up because it will help me save my seat'. All that rotten borough system had to be done away with. All that political sleaze had to be sunk, and the only way to sink it was to make migration policy into law and that is what we have sought to do.

Senator Teague said something very remarkable for which I congratulate him. He said that these regulations were supposed to bring in announced policy. I congratulate him for that. Everyone else thinks that the regulations were supposed to introduce existing policy, but all along it has been announced policy. Senator Teague has picked that up, and I thank him for it. It is announced policy; not existing policy. While I am on that subject, we have changed some policies since June. Therefore, in my view, the Migration Regulation Committee is entitled to examine not only whether that policy is being put into regulations but also the merits of that new policy. I have never disputed that. However, there has been some misunderstanding about it.

Senator Teague went on to say that there are many examples for fast tracking, but did not mention one. This is a difficulty. I do not think there will be that many cases for fast tracking; there will be some. Senator Jenkins alluded to health problems. A family arriving in Australia but having to leave a child behind because it has leukaemia is an obvious example where fast tracking will be of immense advantage. I can imagine other such cases. But I do not see this getting into tens of thousands. When this matter was first put to me by the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations, there was talk in terms of scores a year. I think that will be the case with those that need to be fast tracked. I thank the Committee for raising this problem of fast tracking. I wish the Committee would thank us for coming up with the ingenious solution but no doubt that will come in the report; so far it has not come to me in any other form.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Robert.
—Thank you, Senator Collins; I appreciate that. We want to be loved.
—It was a good dialogue.

—As Senator Teague says, it was a good dialogue. We looked at a whole range of solutions and I think we finally got the best one for that particular process. I am quite happy and at ease with it. Again, I stress, it does not matter what the regulations say. I can intervene in the public interest, but I must report to this chamber as to why I have intervened. That is our critical achievement in this progress through the migration law. Let us make sure that those reports are scrutinised by every honourable senator. If that happens we can guarantee that fairness and equity can flow in immigration like it never has before. I thank Senator Teague for his contribution. I disagreed in part with a few comments he made but agreed with much of what he said.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jenkins ran the old argument of `not enough notice'. I will quote three paragraphs from the Hansard of 5 April 1989. Never let it be said that I did not put everyone on notice. I said then:

Senators will be aware that given the scope, the complexity and the inter-relationships of immigration rules, translating them into regulation will be an extremely lengthy process: in part this will reflect the fact that the approach is a completely novel one, and will involve the development of new skills and processes. Accordingly it will take up to 18 months to complete regulations for all classes of decisions.

I decided therefore that in order to accelerate the process, I would put the Bill forward at this stage to obtain legislative backing to what is a fundamental re-thinking of the administration of the Migration Act. My intention is, given that legislative backing, to draw up regulations for the major classes of decision as a matter of urgency, so that these can be implemented and have the force of law as soon as possible, rather than wait for every minor issue to be resolved.

Accordingly when the Bill is proclaimed, there will still be some gaps in the policy criteria as set out in the regulations. These areas will continue to be discretionary until policy criteria for these areas can be incorporated into regulation.

We put a lot of that on notice. But the most objectionable part of Senator Jenkins's views was when she described the Bill and the whole system as monstrous. She has never put forward what the alternative should be. I would love to hear her selection criteria and how they would be determined. I only get glimpses. From other statements she has made I know there would be no business migrants or skilled migrants. Therefore it is narrowed down to two categories-humanitarian, which I think she would take from 12,500 to 20,000-and family reunion, of which there are at least 71,000. But how would she choose the people? She has never stood up and said how. Does she want to have a lotto? Is that the fairest way of doing it? She makes offhand comments about people buying their way into the country-without ever nominating them or properly understanding the criteria that we place on the business migrants. It is not a question of having $500,000; they must have a sound track record of entrepreneurship. It is not a case of winning the lottery and buying one's way in. At least in a broad sense-I do not expect her to have the accurate details-it is incumbent upon Senator Jenkins to say what her selection criteria would be. I would love to know. If they are better than mine I might adopt them. I have never heard from Senator Jenkins on that matter; I have just heard general carping criticism.

I acknowledge and thank Senator Jenkins for her comments on the public interest. I put the remarks about that matter in the second reading speech not as an afterthought but as an extension of what our thinking always has been on this issue. We never envisaged a narrow definition of public interest. Other people have interpreted it that way. That is why we put it in the second reading speech-to make sure that, if it ever gets into the courts, the courts would understand the definition that Senator Jenkins and I have both endorsed tonight.

Complaints are made that the whole area is complex. I do not know how to simplify it. It is a complex area. Fairness and simplicity are not handmaidens. Sometimes knocking out loopholes and dotting every `i' and crossing every `t' is the way to equity and fairness. There is no simple way, and I do not think there was much choice but to take the route that we have taken.

Senator Jenkins has again repeated her remarks on illegals. The question about the distinction between discretionary and mandatory deportation was well answered and is contained in a confidential committee report. I will not refer honourable senators to the page number but it is clearly laid out. Senator Jenkins and I simply have a different approach to illegals. Senator Jenkins takes a very humanitarian and sympathetic approach to illegals. My view as the Minister for Immigration is that all my sympathy goes to the legal people who are lined up in queues overseas waiting to get here. My sympathy does not go to those who get on a plane and queue-jump. We will never agree on that so I am not going to take that matter any further.

Senator Jenkins then went on to say how unfortunate it is that I am in the graveyard. If I have to listen to a few more woolly-minded ideas from her I will go into the study and do the right thing, I promise. It can be a graveyard; I agree with that. We are dealing with new and complex issues every day where human emotions are involved. That could include the future of Australian circuses one day, defecting diplomats another day, deaf and dumb defecting Polish athletes another-the whole gamut and range comes across my desk day in and day out. What makes it hard is that all the time one is measuring consistency throughout the lot-trying to make it consistent, not favouring one over another. That is why it can become a graveyard for anyone.

One of the final points made by Senator Jenkins concerned the illegals who do not see the advertisements. Stiff cheese; that is all I say. But there have been plenty of advertisements in the last few weeks. We have taken more money from application forms today than in the history of migration. Even though one might have read an advertisement in the West Australian saying that the migration office there will be closed tomorrow, I have made sure that it will stay open so that people can exercise their rights of application right up to the nineteenth. There is still a fair degree in the regulations that will give them rights after that. But I do not have a duty to spend millions of dollars telling people who are staying in this country illegally of their rights. I simply do not have to do that. They are the ones who are breaking the law; they are the ones who are queue jumping; they are the ones who are abusing the hospitality of this country; and they are the ones who are going to have to find a way out of this, either by returning home or by applying for a change of status as allowed within the regulations.

The final point that Senator Jenkins made, the most valid and telling criticism, is that this Government, in its attitude to students, has had an unfortunate history. Obviously, I have to acknowledge that, because we have changed it dramatically in the last few months. One of the problems that we had was that, especially in short term, non-formal courses, the overstay rate was 25 per cent on average. For some countries it was as high as 40 per cent. This had to stop, and we have put a stop to it through a whole series of I think very fair changes in policy. So I can say that I agree with Senator Jenkins's criticism. It is well founded.

Let me move on to the last matter in the second reading amendment. I often think that there is not much justice in the world, but when this amendment passes the Senate I will have to say that I am a bit annoyed. But I will not divide on it. Heaven knows, for the first time in the history of the Senate we circulate regulations to members of the Senate as a select committee. The Opposition, in government, never did it once.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was good but not good enough.
—What rank hypocrites. Come on, Senator Teague, be fair. For the first time ever we circulate the regulations to a select committee to look into them. It in turn circulates them publicly--
—Not publicly.

—Not publicly? They went to only 20 or 30 different groups. They are only in the possession of about 50,000 Australians at the moment. I cannot find one person involved in immigration who does not have a copy of them. We have gone through all that process for the first time in history, and probably for the first time in history I get a motion canning me for doing it. What normally happens under Liberal or Labor governments is that one makes up the regulations in secret, drops them on the table and goes through a disallowance process. But what a mug I am. I say `No; we will bring you all into the process. We will set up a select committee; we will let you examine the regulations; we will go through a series of negotiations and all that'. So what do we end up with? We end up with a amendment condemning us for doing that.
—You're a mug.

—Senator Collins says that I am a mug. I would have to agree with him. That is twice tonight I have had to admit that. Maybe we should get back into hard ball, stand off politics, where we do the hard things and force the Opposition to disallow the regulations. I could have written up all the regulations as one regulation and had the Opposition try to disallow the lot and stop all migrants. I have avoided all those tactics and written the regulations in such a way that they could be individually disallowed. Opposition members have had several weeks to look at them and make their views known to me. They have not seen the end product yet. They have been promised that there will be a continuing process of review, but then they come in and condemn us for going through all these steps. So what? The second reading amendment is not even worth getting excited about other than because of the rank and staggering gall of the fact that the Opposition has come in here and moved it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have nothing more to say on these things except to thank Senator Jenkins and Senator Teague for their contributions. We will not divide over the second reading amendment if we are doomed on it. However, I just say that for once we believe that the Opposition and the Democrats are putting on record one of the grossest inaccuracies ever carried by this Senate.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1989
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, Schedule 1, proposed amendment to section 8, new subsection 17a (2) leave out the proposed amendment, insert the following amendment:
``Section 8, new section 17a:

I move this amendment because I believe that we do not need two sections on deportation in the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1989. If the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) can deport, then he can deport. There seems to be no need at all to place an obligation on him to deport. This is an obligation which in some circumstances could be highly inconvenient. In my previous speech I went into that in a little detail. I am especially afraid that two sections on deportation could provide the Minister with just what he does not want: the discretionary power to choose to move a deportation order either under section 17a-that is mandatory and non-revokable-or under section 18. The fear would be that this could be used for political reasons or for people who could provide an embarrassing situation for the Government. In Western Australia we are all very much aware of the situation of the Orionia community. I believe that it is wrong for the Senate to allow the passage of a measure which permits and indeed encourages discriminatory treatment against some individuals whom the government of the day might want to get rid of. I remind the Senate of the case of the Chilean activist Sergio Buschmann.

The provisions exist without having two sections. These sections could be used against people who represent viewpoints with which the government of the day does not have sympathy and not necessarily in any sense to protect the Australian community. It could possibly be used against people who have been in Australia for a very long time and who became illegal residents a long time ago without being fully aware of this fact. The Minister does not seem to appreciate that this is the case with a number of people. Once this legislation comes into being the Minister will be in for some surprises as far as this is concerned. I fully agree with the Minister that people who come here and who try to jump the queue, who come here specifically for that reason should not have sympathetic treatment. I agree with the Minister that the people who do the right thing and who apply overseas for entry should be the ones given the greater consideration. But I can assure the Minister that there are people here who are technically innocent illegals. This will be shown to be so during the course of next year.

There is also a problem with the sub-clause which makes deportation orders under section 17a non-revokable. Such an order, at some stage, could be made against an individual and, although the Minister has put forward procedural steps which would have to be taken before the deportation order could be enforced, there is still the possibility of an administrative error. If the order is non-revokable, it would have to be enforced and there would be no judicial power or ministerial discretion to overturn it once it had been made.

It is possible that such an order could be made against a person who might have escaped from custody and whose whereabouts was unknown. I suppose the order could remain in force for years. Perhaps the Minister can enlighten us on that aspect, too. The wrong person might be apprehended and, in that case, the wrong person might, or might not, be deported.

There could be a change of government in the country to which the person is to be deported, which would put that person at risk. I know of a case in Western Australia some years ago where five students from Afghanistan were on a course. I know of another case of students from Cambodia attending another course. In both cases the students were here at the time when right wing governments in their countries were replaced by governments of the opposite persuasion. Under this provision, if an illegal entrant against whom such an order had been made were apprehended, a government would have no option but to deport that person back to, perhaps, a Pol Pot-type situation. The Government has so tightened the rules in this respect that, except in the most tightly defined circumstances, we could find ourselves in a very embarrassing situation.

I ask the Minister again why we need to have another section in respect of the deportation of an illegal entrant. The Minister can deport anybody he deems suitable for deportation under section 18 as it stands. I would like to know why we need that second section and why people who need to be deported cannot be deported under section 18.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not support the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. I am not persuaded by the arguments that Senator Jenkins has just set forth. I understand her concerns, and those concerns led us to examine carefully the regulations that will be promulgated under section 17a of the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989. In fact, the only reference to section 17a in the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill is the positive measure which, clearly, all honourable senators in this chamber now support-that is, to insert the words, `after following the prescribed procedures'. Without those words I would have to say that there are many in the Opposition who would share the kinds of misgivings that Senator Jenkins referred to in her contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: But the assurance has been given that, following the addition of these words by this amending Bill, those regulations will be substantial and the safeguards that many of us want-that there will be due process and a set of exact, specified requirements before all the steps are completed to have mandatory deportation-will be legally followed. They will not be able to be evaded. That is the genius of the addition of the words on page four of the Bill in front of us, `after following the prescribed procedures'. Accordingly, there is no need for us to accept amendment No. 1 put forward by the Australian Democrats which would take the entire section 17a out of the Act. It is our view that, after due process, there needs to be a strengthening of the mandatory power to deport because this has been a problem area in the immigration program for some years, not least in recent months. Therefore we need proposed new subsection 17a and section 18-that is both a mandatory power and a discretionary power-for the reasons that have been set forth. I can only emphasise the importance of the additional words that I have referred to on page 4 of the Bill that we are debating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins has changed her position substantially between today and 30 May where she simply moved amendments to make the mandatory deportation revokable. Now she wants a deletion of the whole clause. Mandatory deportation is one of the two ways in which people can be deported from the country. Its first and shining virtue is its deterrent effect on anyone coming here in the first place but, secondly, only senior members of my Department and I will have the power to issue mandatory deportations; it will not be the average officer in the field. Of course, if some of the examples Senator Jenkins has raised do not come before us, the mandatory deportation order cannot be made. I guess that means that if it sits in my in tray for 12 months it is not made. That covers many areas where someone may be required to give evidence in court, or whatever else.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jenkins mentioned the Sergio Buschmann case but, of course, he was not mandatorily deported. I ordered his deportation under the other types of provisions in the Act because he was in breach of migration law in two specific instances. Just for the record, I gave him the option of leaving voluntarily and he did not go. It has always been our policy as much as possible to let people leave voluntarily. Why should we pick up the air fare? Also, as Senator Jenkins will notice in the regulations, it is much better to leave this country voluntarily, in terms of a penalty on return, than it is to be deported. After 19 December people will have 28 days in which to apply for a change of status on virtually all grounds. Even within the first year they can apply for a change of status, unless they have been arrested, on limited grounds. If they are arrested they may apply for refugee status.

Senator Jenkins brought up two examples of Afghans and Cambodians and what will happen with a change of Government. If they are in danger they are entitled to apply for refugee status. The regulation will make it quite clear that the officer has to ask the person, `Have you or do you wish to apply for refugee status?'. So it can be done within the first two days of arrest.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if they don't do it in those two days?

—The right is put to that person. It is not as if he has to initiate it and think of it all by himself. It is put to him, `Do you wish to apply for refugee status?'. If he does not avail himself of that, he runs the risk of possible deportation.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular amendment would delete all reference to mandatory deportation. I think that would be a major negative if it were to be supported. I believe that it is a great deterrent. It also makes other law enforcement agencies take deportation seriously, which they do not do at the moment. I cannot in any way support the amendment proposed by Senator Jenkins.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to point out to the Minister that, if he placed a mandatory deportation order on a person and that person volunteered to leave, the Minister would be obliged to deport him and pay all his expenses. It is for that reason that I really do not see the point in a mandatory deportation order where the Minister has the ability to place a deportation order which, after following the prescribed procedures, must then be carried out unless the Minister himself chooses to revoke it. I really cannot see the Minister's argument. We do not need two forms of deportation orders. I will stick by my amendment because the Minister can still deport whomsoever he sees fit after following the prescribed steps. I say to Senator Teague that the prescribed steps are there for both mandatory deportation under proposed new subsection 17a and deportations under proposed new subsection 18 of the Act. The steps still have to be followed. In the case of the mandatory steps which cannot be revoked, I sincerely believe that the Minister is placing himself in a situation which he might find regrettable. It is all very well for the Minister to say that he can leave that deportation order at the bottom of his in-tray, but this may not be possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I made about voluntary departure is that the point of arrest to the point where the mandatory deportation order is made is where the window of opportunity exists and where people will be encouraged to leave. That will be somewhat reinforced by the provisions, once they are regulated for, for the seizure of assets. So we will have these two things pushing people on arrest not to wait for mandatory deportation but to go. Mandatory deportation which is not reversible by the courts is far more likely to make them go. All the examples seem to be brought up in terms of when these people are in danger of going somewhere else. Under those circumstances they have the option of appealing for refugee status, which is something we have never once tried to circumscribe in this legislation. They are able to appeal on that basis in spite of the fact that many people so appealing will just use it as a device to extend their time in the country.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 4, Schedule 1, proposed amendment to section 8, new subsection 18 (1), leave out ``and no other matters'', insert ``and any other relevant matters''.
(3) Page 4, Schedule 1, proposed amendment, new section 10A, leave out ``and no other matters'', insert ``and any other relevant matters''.
(4) Page 4, Schedule 1, proposed amendment to paragraph 15 (a), new subsection 31A (1), leave out ``and no other matters'', insert ``and any other relevant matters''.

These amendments are all very similar. They reflect on the amendments put forward in the Migration Legislation (Consequential Amendments) Bill. The Government has added the words `after considering the prescribed matters and no other matters' with regard to the deportation of illegal entrants under proposed new sections 17A and 18 with regard to the execution of the deportation orders under section 20 of the principal Act and with regard to the requirement by the Minister that illegal entrants should leave Australia. In all these cases this Bill amends the sections to add the words `after considering the prescribed matters and no other matters'.

I wish to amend those amending clauses to state instead `after considering the prescribed matters and other relevant matters'. I do this because I can see that the Government wishes in these circumstances, when making these final decisions, to be restricted absolutely to matters which have been prescribed and codified down to the last dotted `i' and crossed `t'. The phrase `prescribed matters' remains. But I believe that if the phrase `and other relevant matters' is not included, there is a danger of correct natural justice not being carried out. This is a simple question of basic justice.

If we exclude consideration of all but certain precisely defined factors, the Government's proposed legislation will inevitably put the decision making process into a straitjacket. That makes the decision making process easier, I suppose, but if one is also not allowed to consider other relevant matters-and I think the operative word is `relevant'-the Department could be guilty of a significant injustice in a minority of cases. Here, as previously, I do not believe that we are talking about a lot of cases, but we are talking about cases which, as well as causing injustice, could be an embarrassment for the Government and perhaps blow the situation out of all proportion in the press. It could become an embarrassment to Australia. We do not want to find that we are so restricted by our own legislation that we put ourselves in the position where, even though we may want to act justly, fairly and sensibly, we may have to act unjustly, unfairly and irrationally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not support the three amendments moved by the Australian Democrats. The rejection of the words `and no other matters' means that, when an officer of the Department is enforcing a deportation order or any other circumstances that are outlined relevant to these words, that officer will be required to follow all the specific matters set out in the regulations but no others. I believe that that is appropriate. Because the regulations have not yet been published, nor will be widely seen until next Tuesday, the caveat must remain that the Parliament would give a very close scrutiny to those specific requirements, that is, the matters that are to be specifically considered by the enforcement officer and no others.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, to go beyond the matters that would be set out specifically in the regulations with the words that Senator Jenkins has suggested-`and any other relevant matters'-is, I would have to say, totally open-ended. Not only would it mean that the enforcement officer would put forward any matter that he thought was relevant or that he thought a subsequent court might regard as relevant, but it would also break down what is established in the Bill that is before us-a separation between the decision made on the criteria for a visa or entry permit from those who are to execute subsequent and quite different powers, that is, the enforcement procedures. The Opposition believes that it is reasonable and right to have a separation of such powers. Because the words `any other relevant matters' are so open-ended and would break down that separation, we will not support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed amendments 2, 3 and 4 run counter to the essential feature of the legislation to reform the Migration Act. The firm intention behind the reform was to separate the determination of permission to stay from the processes of enforcement of departure of non-citizens who have no permission to stay. The legislation provides for criteria of entitlement for entry permits. It provides for processes of review of decisions on entry permits by a review officer, in the first tier, and the Immigration Review Tribunal, in the second tier.

SPEECH.PARA: It also provides for residual power in the Minister under section 64u to intervene in favour of an applicant, notwithstanding the criteria. All those provisions, together with a period of grace under section 5j and the provision for judicial review of decisions on grant of entry permits under the general law, were intended to provide for a fair, consistent and conclusive determination of the question whether a non-citizen present in Australia should be allowed to remain in Australia. At the end of the day a non-citizen who does not obtain permission to remain in Australia by way of an entry permit or by way of refugee protection in Australia is expected to depart Australia. If he does not, the compliance process comes into play. The compliance process addresses the question of when and how to secure the departure of a non-citizen present in Australia who has not been granted permission to remain. It is not appropriate at that stage for the compliance process to review or reconsider the question of stay because the compliance process is a by-product of an earlier determination of that very question. To do otherwise would lead to a circular approach which is a mischief that the Parliament, in passing the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill, sought to cure. The proposed provisions in the Bill were intended to secure more firmly the separation of the determination of stay from the consequential processes of compliance with that determination and, of no lesser importance, to ensure that the compliance procedures followed due process.

The amendments proposed by Senator Jenkins throw that fundamental premise to the wind and invite the compliance process to review the review process in which all prior decisions, including the decisions by an independent Immigration Review Tribunal, are opened up for consideration. This is a case of getting the tail to wag the dog. Putting it another way, it is akin to asking a police officer seeking to enforce a taxation assessment to reassess the tax. The legislation reforms have put us on track to get the selection process right. A non-citizen who fails the selection process, including opportunities for merit and judicial review, should abide by the outcome. The compliance process is there to ensure that they do. I cannot accept Senator Jenkins's amendment. It is too open-ended. It fuzzies the edges between the decision as to whether a person should stay or go and the compliance of it. They are two entirely different processes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister's comparison with the Australian Taxation Office was a particularly unfortunate example because when the tax man is making a review he is prepared, very often against the client, to take all relevant factors into consideration. My amendment would be no more out of keeping with the legislation as it stands than is clause 64u itself. If we are attempting to produce in the Parliament the best possible form of migration legislation, on behalf of the Australian Democrats I state that we are disappointed that the Committee will not approve the amendment. It also seems to me inappropriate at this time that when Eastern bloc countries are moving away from red tape and having everything codified right down to the last dotted i and crossed t we are not prepared to consider when we review cases other relevant matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
OVERSEAS STUDENT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989
Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989
Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The publisher and editor of a high quality magazine, Australian Wellbeing-which may be known to some of my colleagues-was drawn to my attention by my colleague the Hon. Michael MacKellar, who had drawn to his attention by the magazine an Australia Post press release dated 14 April 1989. That press release was headed `Postal Charges to Increase'. It announced that postal rates, including the charges for registered publications, such as Australian Wellbeing, were to be increased from that date. I direct my remarks to those particular charges.

SPEECH.PARA: The press release claims-and I have it with me here-that Australia Post's losses in this area of business, that is, registered publications totalled $200m in 1987-88. In an answer to Senate Question on Notice No. 1226 which appeared in Hansard of 25 October 1989, the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly) stated that on information provided by Australia Post, the loss on registered publications business was estimated at $21m in 1988-89. I remind the Senate that the loss was $200m in the previous year and $21m in 1988-89. Since the press statement makes it clear that increased charges for registered publications were not to be imposed on most publishers until after October 1989, I would welcome an explanation from Australia Post as to how it managed to reduce its losses on registered publications by $17.9m in 12 months without the benefit of increased postal charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —It just moved the decimal point.

—My colleague says that it may have been some sleight of hand. In fact, such an achievement, if correct, must cast real doubt over the need for the drastic exclusions and the rate hikes implemented by Australia Post on registered publications.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to some exclusions which have been made in relation to this rate increase. I note that on 26 June 1989 the Chairman of the Australian Postal Corporation, Mr Bob Lansdown, announced that the postal rate would increase to 45c, and that publications with a cover price of more than $5 would not be eligible for that registration beyond 2 October 1989. The Chairman stated that the aim was:
to achieve a moderate reduction in the subsidy which these publications have enjoyed in the past.

Subsequently, Australia Post lifted the postal rate for registered publications to 47c. The impact of these decisions is best shown by quoting the effects on the publishers of Wild magazine.
