Media reports suggested that they will pay 47c postage per issue on a cover price of $4.95, which is just below the $5 limit. The price is about to be increased to over $5, and if this occurs they will lose their eligibility to be a registered publication and they will pay a postal rate of $1.65 per copy inside Victoria and $2.15 per copy elsewhere. This is a very substantial and, I have to say, to my way of thinking, an unreasonable penalty to pay for what might only be a 20c to 30c increase in the price of the magazine. The Chief Mail Manager of Australia Post, Mr Christopher Grosser, has responded, saying:
. . . publishers can offset the increases by raising advertising charges. Why should commercial operators be subsidised by ordinary postal users.

That is an excellent question, Mr Grosser, and I ask Mr Grosser why the commercial operators still enjoying the registered publications concession should be subsidised to the tune of $21m, if that is his argument. He has to be either completely consistent one way or completely consistent the other. But even more to the point, I am sure that the publishers of the approximately 150 publications which are to be excluded from the registered publications concession would like to hear Mr Grosser's justification for the special discount rates which Australia Post apparently offers to certain high volume clients.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Readers Digest.

—I am going to mention the Readers Digest. I thank Senator Puplick for mentioning the Readers Digest. It is widely speculated in the publishing industry that the Readers Digest, for example, has successfully negotiated a rate of between 20c and 25c per copy for its postage. So when Australia Post's chief mail manager asks-and I repeat the question-`Why should commercial operators be subsidised by ordinary postal users?', and that is what he wrote, I would respond by asking Mr Grosser again: why should some commercial operators be more heavily subsidised than others?

SPEECH.PARA: Australia Post's decision to use the retail counter price of a magazine as the criterion for retaining the registered publications concession does not appear to have been well thought out. It seems to have been an arbitrary decision and lacking in commercial logic, fairness or commonsense. Consider two magazines, both of approximately the same weight and volume and both pre-sorted into postcode areas. The cost to Australia Post of processing each magazine must be almost identical, yet one with a cover price of $4.95 can be posted for 47c while the other priced at $5.05-just 10c different-is posted at $1.65. I just cannot accept that Australia Post is able to offer any rational or acceptable explanation why, in this instance, the $5.05 magazine must subsidise its competitor selling for 10c less. That is what it is: it is a subsidy to the tune of $1.20 postal costs for each copy that is posted.

Let me go back to the special discounts which the publishing industry believes are in the order of 20c per copy for some high volume publications. My colleague Senator Puplick mentioned the Readers Digest. Australia Post admitted in the answer to Senate Question on Notice No. 1226 that the rate increase and the $5 exclusion decision was:
. . . part of a package designed to contain the loss on the registered publications service and reduce it by half over the next three years. The loss in 1988-89 is estimated at $21 million.

I have already mentioned that figure of $21m. So if the new registered publications rate of 47c per copy will leave Australia Post with ongoing losses of between $10m and $20m, how can Australia Post justify a special discount for high volume publications like the Readers Digest of about 20c? Australia Post in its answer will claim that it is economies of scale. If a registered postal rate of 47c will still incur losses of up to $20m per year-losses which we have to pay for-I invite Australia Post to convince me that the economies of scale achieved in handling high volume publications are sufficient to justify a discounted rate of over 50 per cent on top of that already low concessional rate of 47c.

I would like to think that Australia Post thoroughly researched its registered publications business before coming to a decision to increase the rate of 47c and to exclude all magazines priced at $5 or more. But all the evidence available to me suggests that this has not been done and that this was not the case. The $5 barrier is surely arbitrary, because Australia Post's chief mail manager justifies it by saying:
If people can afford to spend more than $5.00 on a magazine, they can afford to pay ordinary postal charges.

If there were some consistency to the treatment between different publications, we might understand, but there is no equality of treatment. So Australia Post is now into the business of making value judgments about the affluence of magazine buyers. That is what is going on. Will Australia Post decide next year that people who buy magazines with a cover price of $4 are also affluent enough not to warrant registered publication concessions; or will it be $3? Where will it end? What is Australia Post on about? It is nonsense for a commercial organisation to have to put itself into this position. Its mandate is to move postal articles from the sender to the receiver in the most efficient manner possible, and to do so at a profit. If a $5.05 magazine cannot be posted profitably for 47c, Australia Post has every right to increase the postal charges to a level which is profitable or to decide not to offer a concessional rate at all. The same criterion should be applied to the $4 magazine and to the high volume publications currently receiving negotiated discount rates. Otherwise, we will have a situation of unequal treatment in a very competitive commercial area.

Had Australia Post adopted the businesslike approach which I have just suggested there would at least be some fairness. But Australia Post has thrown into turmoil some sections of the highly competitive magazine industry. Some smaller operators face the prospect of closure. Others are considering re-formatted magazines and cheaper presentations to reduce costs and others are contemplating offshore printing. Still others will have to restructure the way they print in order just to get under whatever is the arbitrary limit set by Australia Post. It is still not too late for Australia Post to review its decision and change it. Australia Post could replace that decision as soon as possible with a fair and commercially acceptable and profitable rate structure for all its registered publications service. I want equality of treatment for all people trying to compete in this area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 6 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As new regulations require prospective students who wish to follow their English course with a course of further study to provide details of the selected course plus provisional acceptance from an Australian institution, and given that neither the Australian Embassy in Beijing, nor the Australian Consulate in Shanghai provides information or counselling services to prospective Chinese students nor are prospective students permitted to enter the Australian Embassy to consult academic handbooks, how does the Minister explain that this requirement can be fulfilled-particularly if the objective is for the pipeline to be processed by the end of this year?

(2) Can the Minister affirm that Chinese students (whose initial course of study concludes but who have been permitted to remain in Australia and work or study until 31 July 1990) will be able to revert to student status after 31 July 1990, provided they are enrolled in a further and accredited course of study?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Senator Vallentine raised a valid point about counselling services on study options available to prospective students overseas.

Educational institutions, including ELICOS institutions which will continue to market in China under the new arrangements, are responsible for marketing their courses overseas and for providing such information as required to enable prospective students to make decisions about further study. To assist institutions discharge this responsibility, the Government is considering a recommendation to establish up to 10 Australian Education Centres which could provide an independent advisory service on study options in Australia.

In the interim, it is in the interests of the students concerned, that the large backlog of applications received by the Embassy before the new arrangements were introduced be cleared. This is, and will remain, the primary focus of attention for the student section at the Embassy in Beijing.

(2) The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is responsible for making an assessment regarding the situation of all PRC nationals who have chosen to accept the Government's offer to remain in Australia until 31 July 1990.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 10 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of reports of the US State Department relating to mass murders and torture of civilians by the new military regime in Myanmar, what Australian intelligence reports are available relating to recent events in that country.
(2) What is the state of diplomatic and governmental relations between the Myanmar and Australian Governments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The present military regime in Myanmar, under General Saw Maung, came to power in September 1988 after suppressing popular demonstrations in favour of democracy in which an estimated 3,000 people, a large proportion of whom were students, were shot by security forces. The regime has announced that elections will be held on 27 May 1990 and that they will be ``free and fair''. However, repressive measures taken by the regime against its political opponents cast serious doubt on the credibility of the election process. In particular, the leaders of the main opposition party, the National League for Democracy, Aung San Suu Kyi and Tin U, have been held under a form of house arrest since 21 July and thousands of their supporters and other political activists have been detained. Reports of mistreatment and torture are commonplace. Also, severe restrictions have been placed on public gatherings and freedom of speech.

The regime has come to rely increasingly on the exercise of martial law. Military courts have been empowered to try civil offences and according to figures released by the authorities themselves, no less than 100 people have been sentenced to death, although it appears that to date none of these sentences have been carried out. There are also well substantiated reports of large numbers of people being press-ganged to work for the army as porters in the insurgent areas in conditions where they have suffered severely from starvation, disease and mistreatment.
(2) Australia maintains normal diplomatic relations with Myanmar. The question of recognition does not arise as Australia recognises states and not governments.

The Australian Government has never indicated support for the regime, the way it came to power, or its continued suppression of opposition groups. On the contrary, Australia has been at the forefront of those countries encouraging the Myanmar authorities to hold early general elections and to improve the observance of human rights.

In my statements of 21 July and 18 September, and on other more recent occasions in Question Time, I called for the lifting of the restrictions on political activity and for the release of Aung San Suu Kyi and other political prisoners in preparation for free and fair elections, and for respect for the human rights and fundamental freedoms of the people of Myanmar. I was able to further emphasise Australia's concerns on 4 October, when I met the leader of the Myanmar delegation to the UN General Assembly, Brigadier General Nyan Lynn, who is a member of the ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council. Representations on human rights issues have also been made regularly through our Embassy in Yangon and through the Myanmar Embassy in Canberra. These representations have included specific cases raised by the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International.

The Australian Government will continue to do all that it reasonably can do to encourage the military regime in Myanmar to meet the democratic aspirations of the people of Myanmar and to improve its observance of fundamental human rights.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 27 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. In relation to the Minister's reply to my Question on Notice No. 1088, (see Senate Hansard of 26 September 1989, page 1363) on what evidence is his comment based that, internationally, chalkbrood is not regarded as a major infectious disease of honeybees.
2. Does the Minister's comment that chalkbrood can lower production in weakened and/or badly managed hives imply that the disease does not lower production in strong and/or well managed hives.
3. Is it correct that of 15 samples of honey taken from shop shelves in New Zealand, 12 had chalkbrood spores.
4. Is there a danger of introducing chalkbrood through importation of honey; if so, why does proclamation No. 132a include bulk honey and honey pre-packs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Chalkbrood is not considered a major infectious disease of honeybees by the Office International des Epizooties (OIE), the recognised international reporting body on animal diseases and it is not listed in either of the OIE List A or List B categories. As Australia is free from the disease, however, quarantine restrictions are in place to address the risk of the disease reaching the Australian bee population. The import of bee products is currently under review due to concerns raised over the import of chalkbrood fungus in such products.
2. Chalkbrood may lower production in strong, well managed hives, but it is usually of less economic importance in such hives.
3. Informal advice is that a research project performed in New Zealand obtained this result.

4. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service awaits a final report of the research project performed in New Zealand. On receipt of this report it will make an assessment of the risk of chalkbrood entering Australia in honey and honey pre-packs.
